story:
Overview

My name is Robert Conway and I'm an independent filmmaker.  

Last year I had the honor and the privilege to write, direct and produce Eminence Hill with Lance Henriksen and Barry Corbin.  That film marked my return to Westerns after over a decade making horror movies.  With Skinwalker I’m drawing from my horror days and bringing elements of the world of the supernatural to the Wild West.

 

Most of the financing has been secured, but I'm in need of additional funds to cover my production cost.  So if you love Westerns, Supernatural Thrillers and really cool perks, then please consider saddling up by contributing to my campaign!  I owe the success of Eminence Hill to my amazing crowdfund contributors and with their help I was able to make a film I’m very proud of.  Lets make it happen again with Skinwalker!

 

Welcome to Red Mountain: A Synopsis

The year is 1883 and the place is the Arizona Territory.  As “Manifest Destiny” continued to engulf Native American land, a small consortium of different tribes followed a wise medicine woman to their new home on the sacred mountain.  Our story begins not long after her death when a pair of unsuspecting trappers unwittingly unleash her spirit onto the world.

Some experts theorize that all American supernatural myths are tied to the idea that people are living on land that does not belong to them.  White settlers are regarded as foreign invaders by the land itself.  The root of uniquely American horrors is traced back to America’s Original Sin, the genocide of Native peoples. 

 

Project Summary

Howdy,

Ever since I wrapped production on Eminence Hill, I’ve been itching to get back in the saddle and shoot another Western.  Now with Skinwalker, I’m hitting the trail again and adding a bit of supernatural flare to experience. Inspired by other great cross-genre films such as High Planes Drifter and Bone Tomahawk, Skinwalker aims to combine the the best elements of horror and the supernatural with the iconic imagery of the American West.  The film is currently in preproduction and will be filmed later this summer in Arizona. 

 

Meet the Players

In Skinwalker, I’ve enlisted many of Arizona’s best working actors to round out the colorful cast of hunters and hunted! Foregoing a traditional casting process, I simply got on the phone, called my friends and colleagues and set to work crafting a story that showcases each actor’s range in a fun, dynamic way. 

They are all working for free, dedicating their time and considerable talents to making this project a top notch thriller of which we can all be proud!

Eva Hamilton - Maisie 

Tackling the role of charismatic outlaw Maisie Jackson is magnetic leading lady Eva Hamilton. We're very excited to work with Eva and bring this dignified but dangerous woman to the screen!  Credits include "Ruin Me," "Death Kiss" and "Max Reload and the Nether Blasters"

Cameron Kotecki - Riggs

Last seen in Eminence Hill, the versatile actor leads Skinwalker’s cast as Nat Riggs, an idealistic young Marshall, tasked with the transport of a dangerous outlaw.  Cameron John Kotecki is an Arizona born actor, screenwriter and aspiring director. Credits include “Eminence Hill,”  “Senioritis,” and “Rhea.”

Amelia Haberman - Nellie

One of AZ’s most talented and prolific young actors, Amelia joins Skinwalker as Nellie, a young homesteader who calls the cursed mountain her home.  With performances ranging from the heartbreaking to the terrifying, Amelia has displayed her range time and again in such projects as “The Covenant,” “Krampus Origins,” “My Secret War,” and “The System.”

Jeff Yazzie - Proud Fist

AZ Actor Jeff Yazzie takes charge as Proud Fist, the Native Warrior joining Storm Talker in a dangerous quest to restore peace to their mountain.  Credits include "Eminence Hill" "Run for the High Country," and "Out West"

Victorio Pope - Storm Talker

AZ Actor Victorio Pope brings an intense complexity to the role of Storm Talker, a Native warrior tasked with a dangerous mission.  Credits include "Eminence Hill", "Out West" and "Run for the High Country"

Nathaniel Burns - Benny

The  role of “Benny,” a low down grave robber, will be played by AZ actor Nathaniel Burns. We can look forward to the raw humanity and intense presence Nathaniel brings to all of his roles.  Credits include “Eminence Hill,” “Battlefield 2025,” and “Krampus: the Reckoning.”

Dan Higgins - Bascom

The incomparable Dan Higgins hits the trail as tough-as-nails lawman, Marshall Bascom. Having last worked with Dan on “Breakdown Lane” in 2017, I’m thrilled to have him back to see him capture the grit and pathos of Bascom like no one else can.  Past credits include “Exit To Hell”, “The Encounter” and “There’s an Octopus in Your Head”

Daniel Link - Willard

Taking up the reins as Willard, a  Homesteader with a dark secret, is AZ actor Daniel Link. Daniel’s wide range brings just the right mixture of humanity and menace to this pivotal role in “Skinwalker.”  Daniel’s past credits include “Mind the Gap,” “Human Threads,” “The System” and “Krampus Unleashed.”

William “Bill” Connor - Hitch

Prolific and powerful AZ actor William “Bill” Connor portrays Vern in “Skinwalker.”  Bill’s strong screen presence and considerable talent make him the perfect choice to play this rugged outlaw with a heart of gold.  Bill’s credits include “Eminence Hill,” “Bloodthirst,” “Gearhead” and “Battlefield 2025.”

 

 

From Script to Screen 

By contributing to my campaign, you will be playing a pivotal role in bringing this film to life. Independent films without the benefit of big Hollywood budgets rely on local communities coming together and as proved on Eminence Hill, the support from patrons is essential for us to tell these stories well. 

In an age where most Hollywood fare is engineered by focus groups and catered for mass appeal, independent film is the place where we can push boundaries, take risks and find new and exciting ways to tell stories. 

We are very fortunate to live and work in this beautiful state, which is not only filled with incredible locations, but enthusiastic, generous and incredibly supportive people. This film is an Arizona affair through and through. We’ll be shooting all over the state, employing local cast and crew. We hope that by going back to work, we can help local businesses affected by the pandemic get back on their feet as well. We hope that “Skinwalker” can help the gifted actors, artists, musicians, writers and more that make up the  AZ creative community get back to doing what they do best. Creating. With your help, we can accomplish this. 

With everyone involved in the production working for substantially reduced rates, we are asking for donations to help meet production expenses such as livestock handling, set design and decoration, location and equipment rental fees. etc. 

Even a small donation goes a long way. Of course, the more you contribute the more you will be helping, but every amount helps and is greatly appreciated!

 With filming set to kick off next week, the plan is to run a three-week shoot followed two to three months of post production with a target completion date in October of 2020.

story:
YOU CAN STILL MAKE DONATIONS THROUGH ZELLE, CASHAPP AND PAYPAL!!!

ZELLE: Lamar.Usher@Gmail.com

CASHAPP: $LamarUsher

PAYPALL: Briannadevons22@Gmail.com

 

Thank you all for your continued support!!!

Director's Note

First of all, let me start by saying THANK YOU for even taking the time to hear our story! While doing a film about the anxiety of living with a loved one lost to suicide at any given moment can be triggering, I know this film is important because it gives visibility to the families that feel like they're alone. I know what it's like to plead with someone to want to live their life, pour love into them as much as you can, call every health care facility, behavioral therapist, holistic doctor - call anyone and everyone to try and find some solution but to only be met with a cycle of dead ends. The anxiety is constant but knowing you're not alone in this fight is so important and that is what this film provides.

The film takes place in one day, where both tragedy and opportunity align. On the same day that our protagonist (LAMAR) is prepping for one of the biggest auditions of his career, he receives a phone call that his brother (DEVIN) might have committed suicide. Moments away from being called in to audition, Lamar must grapple with the fact that he might not see his brother alive and there's nothing that he can do to change that. He's sent on a rollercoaster of emotions the thought of losing his brother nearly breaks him. However, when the words of his monologue reflect his internal battle,  he finds a way to repurpose his trauma to ultimately nail his audition. In the end, this film explores the fact that despite our biggest adversities, it's within our nature to rise up and stay resilient. 

 

What We Need 

Our budget is $10,000.


That $10,000 will be going to towards RENTING LOCATIONS for production, PAYING CAST & CREW members that will be providing their services, all the necessities needed to maintain a COVID safe environment,  POST-PRODUCTION such as editing, color grading, sound design, and graphics, and MARKETING the film so it can be seen world-wide!

 

 

Meet The Team!

Every single person in this world wants to know - do you hear me? Do you see me? Do I matter? While each of us are on our own personal journeys, we sometimes forget that our journey is connected to a larger one. Bringing over 7 years of filmmaking experience to the project, Brianna leverages her dynamic storytelling to bring the voices of the margins to the mainstream and offer a point of connectivity for us all. While Brianna works as a producer for NBCUniversal during the day, she uses her free time to create stories that will have an impact on the world. Her ultimate goal is to let anyone who’s ever felt stuck know that - we hear you, we see you, and you do matter.

Lamar Usher is a first generation Belizean American SAG-AFTRA actor born and raised in South Central Los Angeles. He received his theatrical training at The School Of Dramatic Arts at USC and he brings over 7 years of experience to the project. He has worked with some of Hollywood’s biggest names such as Eddie Murphy in Dolemite is My Name and John Singleton in Snowfall. While Lamar shines in front of the camera, he has an innate ability to bring authentic stories to life as a producer. Lamar’s experience both on and off screen make him an unparalleled asset to our team.

A Los Angeles native and a natural born storyteller. Leon is a writer/filmmaker, who has written, produced and directed several short films, including the award winning romance dramedy, Without Her and  the romance drama, Broke Lovers. Recently, he wrote, produced, directed and executive produced his first feature film, Welcome Matt, a dramedy starring Tahj Mowry and Deon Cole, about an agoraphobic filmmaker, who tries to make a film in his apartment, while taking therapy, so he can venture back out into the real world. The film has been distributed by Gravitas Ventures, for a nationwide release on May 28th 2021. Leon is currently developing his next feature film project, TBA, and is working to have it released in the summer of 2022.

Alexis Arago grew up in Houston, Texas and moved to Los Angeles to attend the University of Southern California. While in college, she worked in Development at De Line Pictures while also directing and producing documentaries and short films. Upon graduating with a B.S. in Business Administration with a minor in Cinematic Arts, she started working at Netflix, where she is now a Production Finance Coordinator. She now fuses her experience with development, physical production, and production finance to bring new stories to life.

From being a director on local LA sets to producing on a global scale, Neesin Williams has cut his teeth and honed his visual skills hands-on, experiencing any and everything that comes along with creating a project. Neesin takes pride in the fact that throughout the various roles he’s mastered on set, all of his projects are rooted in his desire to tell timeless stories. His main focus is to showcase all walks of life and culture, while highlighting and uplifting those around him. Neesin has over 10 years of experience and has previous work placed in CANNES Film Festival.

The Impact

This is not just our story. This is a story for all those who have had to stay resilient in the midst of their greatest adversity. There's so many people that have reached out to us after reading our screenplay to let us know they can see themselves in this story.

With your help, we can bring this story from script to screen and let people know they are not alone in their journey. 

 

 

If you cannot contribute financially, just know that sharing information about our campaign and our mission is as equally important. 
Please share this link with your family, friends, colleagues, and anyone else that you may think will have an interest in helping address mental illness and depression.

 

  • SHARE SHARE SHARE!
story_txt:
YOU CAN STILL MAKE DONATIONS THROUGH ZELLE, CASHAPP AND PAYPAL!!!ZELLE: Lamar.Usher@Gmail.com

CASHAPP: $LamarUsher

PAYPALL: Briannadevons22@Gmail.com

 

Thank you all for your continued support!!!Director's Note
First of all, let me start by saying THANK YOU for even taking the time to hear our story! While doing a film about the anxiety of living with a loved one lost to suicide at any given moment can be triggering, I know this film is important because it gives visibility to the families that feel like they're alone. I know what it's like to plead with someone to want to live their life, pour love into them as much as you can, call every health care facility, behavioral therapist, holistic doctor - call anyone and everyone to try and find some solution but to only be met with a cycle of dead ends. The anxiety is constant but knowing you're not alone in this fight is so important and that is what this film provides.

The film takes place in one day, where both tragedy and opportunity align. On the same day that our protagonist (LAMAR) is prepping for one of the biggest auditions of his career, he receives a phone call that his brother (DEVIN) might have committed suicide. Moments away from being called in to audition, Lamar must grapple with the fact that he might not see his brother alive and there's nothing that he can do to change that. He's sent on a rollercoaster of emotions the thought of losing his brother nearly breaks him. However, when the words of his monologue reflect his internal battle,  he finds a way to repurpose his trauma to ultimately nail his audition. In the end, this film explores the fact that despite our biggest adversities, it's within our nature to rise up and stay resilient. 





 
What We Need 
Our budget is $10,000.
That $10,000 will be going to towards RENTING LOCATIONS for production, PAYING CAST & CREW members that will be providing their services, all the necessities needed to maintain a COVID safe environment,  POST-PRODUCTION such as editing, color grading, sound design, and graphics, and MARKETING the film so it can be seen world-wide!

If you cannot contribute financially, just know that sharing information about our campaign and our mission is as equally important. Please share this link with your family, friends, colleagues, and anyone else that you may think will have an interest in helping address mental illness and depression.
 
SHARE SHARE SHARE!

story:
Seasons - Four Spine-Tingling Tales of Terror

Join the Subsoil Family and help us finish this amazing horror anthology:

  • Loaded with stars like, Jeremy London, Lisa Wilcox, Felissa Rose, Reggie Bannister & Lynn Lowry. Produced by Tim Melican, Jesse Kozel, Brandon E. Brooks.
  • With a solid script (written by Benjamin Swicker), a genre-specific cast, and amazing crew, we feel that we have one of the most marketable horror films on the planet.
  • This is a passion project for everyone involved and it will show in the final product.

What We Need & What You Get

Here's our plan:

  • For every $15,000 we raise, we will have just enough money to finish a segment.
  • We shot one complete segment in February and have 4 more to go.
  • The more money we raise, and the more stretch goals you help us meet, the better the overall quality of the film you'll get. 
  • Lastly, once the entire film is completed, you'll receive the killer perks!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute $$$, there's other ways you could help:

  • Follow Subsoil Films & Seasons all over social media (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Etc.)
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools and also share and like our posts all over social media!

story:
That's a wrap!

Production has officially finished, but It's not too late to still back the film and help cover the costs of production and post-production! 

 

About Me

My name is Jack Diehl, I’m a writer/director studying film, visual effects, and animation at Hampshire College. I worked as a visual effects production assistant on Marvel’s Ant-man & the Wasp and wrote/directed the horror short, “There’s Someone in the Closet.” I’ve been awarded grants from the Pope Foundation, Mayes Div III grant, Joslin Div III grant, and the Jackie Hayden Div III grant for “Spirit Hand,” but I could still use some help covering the costs of production.

 

The Inspiration for the Film

While I haven’t always liked the horror genre, I have always enjoyed ghost stories. Even as a kid I would listen with fascination to anyone that had a story involving the supernatural, although usually the story would result in me spending two weeks huddled in bed too afraid to go to sleep. To cope with being utterly terrified of ghost stories when I was younger, I turned to less frightening cryptids, like the Loch Ness Monster and Bigfoot.

It wasn’t until high school when I grew just a tad bit braver that I began watching horror movies. I started with monster movies and in college advanced to movies with full on apparitions, such as in films like The Conjuring or Hereditary. Horror is now one of my favorite film genres. While I am skeptical about the existence of ghosts and spirits, I love watching or hearing about supernatural occurrences and seeing the creativity from filmmakers when crafting a frightening scene that can still scare an audience in a world with an ever-growing list of horror to watch.

And as much as I love the aforementioned horror movies, they all portray ghosts and spirits as entities that hope to bring tragedy or misery to the protagonists. The idea for “Spirit Hand” came to mind when I started pondering what a friendly ghost encounter might look like. This thought brought me back to the basement of my parent’s house where my friend’s and I would hear strange noises or sounds during our sleepovers. My moms would say, partially joking, that perhaps those mysterious noises are the spirits of our past dogs or the spirit of my grandmother watching over us.

Within “Spirit Hand” I hope to explore how we initially perceive a supernatural event versus how malicious that supernatural event might actually be, if it indeed occurred.

 

Spirit Hand

The film follows Abigail, an aspiring artist who recently lost her girlfriend, Jessie, of six years to the coronavirus. A year after Jessie’s death, Abigail finds her grieving interrupted as mementos from her relationship with Jessie begin reappearing.

This is a story about loss and our perception of supernatural encounters during vulnerable moments of our lives.

I will shoot the film with a skeleton crew in order to keep the budget on the smaller side, and most importantly to insure the risks of Covid-19 are minimized and contained on set. Production will start at the end of January.

 

Actors/Crew

 

Crew Involved:

DP - Ben Heald

2nd Unit DP - James Woodbury

Sound Mixer - David Banta-Garcia

AC - Colin Munson

Gaffer - Evan Schneider

Grip - Noah Binette

PA - Kayara Hardnett-Barnes

PA - Eva Shannon-Dabek

PA - Raye Cleary

 

Funding

Pre-production costs:

Software: Milanote annual subscription

Prop creation

 

Production Costs:

Equipment - camera, lights, camera cage, tripod

Actors/Crew - food, travel

Additional - set dressing, location costs

Medical - face masks, face shields, Covid tests

 

Post-production Costs:

Music

Sound Design
 

 

Other Ways to Help

 

I appreciate any contribution, and no amount is too small. If you aren’t able to contribute, I would greatly appreciate it if you shared the campaign on Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram!

 

Link to share:   https://igg.me/at/spirithand

story:
Logline: Robin faces his past from before the Teen Titans when a mysterious challenger appears, as a newly-arrived Starfire tries to make amends with her neglected older sister, Blackfire, who seeks the throne of their home planet, Tamaran.

The Synopsis: An 18-year-old Robin has been leading the team known as the Teen Titans for three years now, through many a petty crime. Longing for their big moment, the Titans grow tired of Robin’s optimism.  However, when Robin finds a strange alien girl wearing in a purple dress and glowing green eyes, the lives of the team will change. After what seems like just another day on the job, now with the addition of Starfire, the team encounters Red X, which sends Robin on a journey to hunt this mysterious masked figure down. Now may be more than an opportunity than ever for the rest of the Titans to get the action they think they deserve, with Starfire's older vengeance-driven sister hot on her tail...

Our goal is to make a film that fans of any rendition of the Teen Titans can appreciate. From the original Teen Titans animated show, to Teen Titans: GO!,  to Titans, this is an even blend of cartoon humor with realistic action and themes. So no matter what your stance on each rendition is, this film will be something you can enjoy and take away from!

 

Who better to know how to make a film about teens... than teens?? And of course, a few HONORARY teens along the way! Downside Studios is a group of young filmmakers and actors that are dedicated to the project and the source material, and have put their hearts and souls into helping us get this off the ground.

The project is mostly sourced from all Teen Titans materials, including a bit of Guardians of the Galaxy and Ferris Bueller's Day Off. This is purely a super-fun action comedy film, and built entirely on a burning passion for the project... and, of course, just to have some sort of social interaction after the desolation of quarantine.

 

Well, we'll show you! All funds received here will go straight back into Teen Titans: Alpha, so as to allow for better equipment, bigger locations, more characters, better visual effects, and even more story! Let's break it down:

Now that you can rest easy knowing you'll be contributing to a valid cause, let's meet the cast!

 

 

We have some amazing rewards lined up for your donations, so now that you've had time to get to know our (absolutely perfect) cast, let's get into what YOU can get out of contributing to Teen Titans: Alpha!

$5: A Teen Titans: Alpha phone wallpaper, and your name in the credits!

$10: Live-stream thank you on our Instagram!

$15: Credit on IMDb and a CD copy of the soundtrack by Jared Walker & various artists!

$20: A personalized thank you video from the cast and crew!

$25: Early digital access to the film before its official release!

$30: A digital version of the film including commentary from several cast members!

$35: Starfire's screen-used gauntlets! Both of 'em!

$50: A digital concept costume art book with art from Joell Acevedo, our concept artist!

$50: The official mini-poster for Teen TItans: Alpha!

$55: SIGNED version of the official mini-poster for Teen TItans: Alpha!

$75: DVD copy of the film including behind the scenes footage, deleted scenes, and bloopers!

$100: A Q&A Zoom call with the cast and director!

$200: A signed copy of the script!

$400: You can CHOOSE three scenes from the film to be storyboarded and signed!

$1000: Executive producer credit in the film, INCLUDING all the non-limited perks from before!

 

By donating any amount to our Indiegogo, you're pushing us a step forward into making this film the best it can possibly be. Even if you only have a few dollars to spare, that means the world to everyone involved.

And heck, there are ways you can help even if you CAN'T donate!

     1. FOLLOW US on socials! Downside Studios on YouTube, @downsidestudios on Instagram, Facebook and TikTok, and @downsidestud1os on Twitter (how is there another Downside Studios ONLY on Twitter?? Beyond us...)!

     2. Tell your rich friends and family about Teen Titans: Alpha! Or, tell your regular friends and family! Both are great! Together, we can make Teen Titans: Alpha a reality, and the more people that know about it, the closer we get to making it happen!

 

We want to hear your thoughts. We want to work with you! This all would not be possible without the love and dedication everyone has put into this passion project, the love of the craft is immeasurable when you unite the Titans. And this cast... is VERY chaotic. Trust me, there's some good bloopers comin' your way.

 

We'll see you on set.

story:
The Gist

Heyo, I'm Max. My background is extremely boring, so I'll keep it brief. I make stuff and think it has some semblance of value, so I'd like to make more stuff, but need some help.

This is the latest (and biggest, most challenging) bit of stuff I'm making: A live-action feature film about a young woman who learns why her actions make her feel the way they do (not to spoil it for you). It's a big ol' 90 minute therapy session that will hopefully make you very happy, and sad, and uncomfortable with how these emotions strike you, keeping in tune with that theme. That's what people like to feel during a movie, right? Uncomfortable?

I'd recommend watching the above video about the project, then this below sizzle I cut together using other film & TV footage to convey the general tone & approach:

password: DATV
 

What We Need & What You Get

We currently have over $40k dedicated to the project, and we need $30k more to push that uphill boulder over the top and get principal photography rolling.

We plan on getting this money, or at least a comparable amount, no matter what -- whether through investors, loans, and/or good ol' fashioned credit card suicide. But this is best way to do it. It gives us 100% creative control, significantly softens our debt (which will be helpful for the next inevitable project), and make it so the people who are genuinely interested in the movie are the ones involved, rather than people purely interested in finances.

What you'll be getting as a result is the movie itself + lots of bonus aspects to the production. They're mostly digital, rather than tangible perks like mugs & hats, to ensure every dollar truly goes into the production itself. The tradeoff is that these digital perks are hopefully much more involving & rewarding, such as credits in the film itself, a custom doodle, a script PDF, an advanced screener link, and a download of the soundtrack.

The Team (so far)

Conversations are taking place with a bunch of different people at the moment, but here are some of the ones that are locked in to be involved in some capacity:

WRITER/DIRECTOR/PRODUCER/EDITOR - MAX WERKMEISTER

Mr. Werkmeister was artificially grown in a petri dish over the course of 1968, mostly scraped together from the leftover remains of other lab samples across upstate New York. After a fifty-six year stint as the host of a ghost-hunting program for Freeform (then known as Fox Family), an existential crisis brought him back to the world of independent film.

That's when the drinking started.

Who can say why, in absence of a child, the best substitute for cradling is a bottle of Henny? Maybe it's the comparable smooth texture with the added security of a tough exterior. The only audible weeping coming from that of the cradler; the cradled's cries being replaced by soft swishes of the liquid therapy whose whispers promise to make one forget. Perhaps the greater question is -- why did he ever give it up?

“DANNI” - ALEXANDRA LANDAU

Ms. Landau got her start performing in Shakespearean productions as a child in the late 1590s, portraying deceased bodies and old crones, due to a rare, backward-aging condition. This condition was thought to simply be hideousness until the aging rapidly kicked in at the start of the new millennium. Now, with the little time she has left before becoming a baby, Ms. Landau has opted to take on a role more challenging than those of her heyday -- a spritely young adult.

PRODUCTION DESIGNER - DANICA CAROTHERS

During the fall of 1998, a young girl named Carotha Danick went exploring through the harrowing Norwegian forests in pursuit of an unidentified satellite she had seen crashing down from the aurora borealis she'd been admiring earlier. Ms. Danick disappeared for the next six weeks, and, upon her miraculous return home, had changed her demeanor entirely. Insisting on now being called "Danica Carothers", she began a diet that consisted exclusively of rodents no lighter than two pounds and no heavier than four. This was just the beginning of an unsettling trend of erratic & dangerous behaviors. While there is no hard evidence, it is widely speculated that something unknown has taken up residence inside Ms. Danick, and is waiting for the perfect time to come bursting out.

COMPOSER - SEANDAN KELLY

The two-headed Mr. Kelly hails from the surliest of Irishmen, a stone-cold soul who’s hard to talk to without being assaulted by foul language, and harder to work alongside without being assaulted by even fouler blows. It took Max over 20 years to tame this beast in the workplace, an achievement he’s most proud of. As a result, the two have made beautiful music together, in a primarily nonsexual way.

“MARGARET” - CARON CLANCEY

As a former elephant feeder, Ms. Caron “Ron” Clancey has grown very tired of the manipulation, the politics, and the yearly zoo conferences that got her to the top. As a result, she has chosen to take all the pain she’s harbored from this life and channel it into heart-wrenching performances. This film will be the first time she’s been on a set, eaten from a snack table, and seen a camera, if you don’t count the documentary crew that’s been following her since birth (she is the youngest of 16).

Risks & Challenges

With filmmaking, every single day is packed with risks and challenges by virtue of the fact that collaboration + limited resources + limited time is a combination that invites them.

With this project in particular, however, the story is a very ambitious scale for something with its limitations. It includes a healthy amount of practical effects and expensive locations in the middle of a hot California summer with a potentially unhealthy amount of hands on deck.

The attempt to overcome these challenges before they truly hit is for us to show up as prepared as possible, with contingency plans if anything doesn't work out within our given constraints. Every scene is being storyboarded and shot lists are being worked out weeks in advance, allowing for improvisation, rescheduling, and cuts for when they inevitably become necessary.

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether you're in a position to financially help or not, you can still:

  • Share this campaign with people online (and in LIFE) so they can get all stoked up
  • Contribute in a production role if you're a film person as eager and as desperate as us (crew/extras/graphics/etc.)
  • Spread the word to trustworthy friends who are the above ^

I hope you hop aboard our ship, if only to see whether or not it sinks. Either way, it'll be a real hoot of a ride. If you still have questions, reach out, and you'll get answers!

Thank ya!
story_txt:
The Gist
Heyo, I'm Max. My background is extremely boring, so I'll keep it brief. I make stuff and think it has some semblance of value, so I'd like to make more stuff, but need some help.
This is the latest (and biggest, most challenging) bit of stuff I'm making: A live-action feature film about a young woman who learns why her actions make her feel the way they do (not to spoil it for you). It's a big ol' 90 minute therapy session that will hopefully make you very happy, and sad, and uncomfortable with how these emotions strike you, keeping in tune with that theme. That's what people like to feel during a movie, right? Uncomfortable?
I'd recommend watching the above video about the project, then this below sizzle I cut together using other film & TV footage to convey the general tone & approach:

password: DATV
 

What We Need & What You Get
We currently have over $40k dedicated to the project, and we need $30k more to push that uphill boulder over the top and get principal photography rolling.
We plan on getting this money, or at least a comparable amount, no matter what -- whether through investors, loans, and/or good ol' fashioned credit card suicide. But this is best way to do it. It gives us 100% creative control, significantly softens our debt (which will be helpful for the next inevitable project), and make it so the people who are genuinely interested in the movie are the ones involved, rather than people purely interested in finances.
What you'll be getting as a result is the movie itself + lots of bonus aspects to the production. They're mostly digital, rather than tangible perks like mugs & hats, to ensure every dollar truly goes into the production itself. The tradeoff is that these digital perks are hopefully much more involving & rewarding, such as credits in the film itself, a custom doodle, a script PDF, an advanced screener link, and a download of the soundtrack.

The Team (so far)
Conversations are taking place with a bunch of different people at the moment, but here are some of the ones that are locked in to be involved in some capacity:
WRITER/DIRECTOR/PRODUCER/EDITOR - MAX WERKMEISTER
Mr. Werkmeister was artificially grown in a petri dish over the course of 1968, mostly scraped together from the leftover remains of other lab samples across upstate New York. After a fifty-six year stint as the host of a ghost-hunting program for Freeform (then known as Fox Family), an existential crisis brought him back to the world of independent film.
That's when the drinking started.
Who can say why, in absence of a child, the best substitute for cradling is a bottle of Henny? Maybe it's the comparable smooth texture with the added security of a tough exterior. The only audible weeping coming from that of the cradler; the cradled's cries being replaced by soft swishes of the liquid therapy whose whispers promise to make one forget. Perhaps the greater question is -- why did he ever give it up?
“DANNI” - ALEXANDRA LANDAU
Ms. Landau got her start performing in Shakespearean productions as a child in the late 1590s, portraying deceased bodies and old crones, due to a rare, backward-aging condition. This condition was thought to simply be hideousness until the aging rapidly kicked in at the start of the new millennium. Now, with the little time she has left before becoming a baby, Ms. Landau has opted to take on a role more challenging than those of her heyday -- a spritely young adult.
PRODUCTION DESIGNER - DANICA CAROTHERS

Ms. Danick disappeared for the next six weeks, and, upon her miraculous return home, had changed her demeanor entirely. Insisting on now being called "Danica Carothers", she began a diet that consisted exclusively of rodents no lighter than two pounds and no heavier than four. This was just the beginning of an unsettling trend of erratic & dangerous behaviors. While there is no hard evidence, it is widely speculated that something unknown has taken up residence inside Ms. Danick, and is waiting for the perfect time to come bursting out.
COMPOSER - SEANDAN KELLY
The two-headed Mr. Kelly hails from the surliest of Irishmen, a stone-cold soul who’s hard to talk to without being assaulted by foul language, and harder to work alongside without being assaulted by even fouler blows. It took Max over 20 years to tame this beast in the workplace, an achievement he’s most proud of. As a result, the two have made beautiful music together, in a primarily nonsexual way.
“MARGARET” - CARON CLANCEY
As a former elephant feeder, Ms. Caron “Ron” Clancey has grown very tired of the manipulation, the politics, and the yearly zoo conferences that got her to the top. As a result, she has chosen to take all the pain she’s harbored from this life and channel it into heart-wrenching performances. This film will be the first time she’s been on a set, eaten from a snack table, and seen a camera, if you don’t count the documentary crew that’s been following her since birth (she is the youngest of 16).

Other Ways You Can Help
Whether you're in a position to financially help or not, you can still:

Share this campaign with people online (and in LIFE) so they can get all stoked up
Contribute in a production role if you're a film person as eager and as desperate as us (crew/extras/graphics/etc.)
Spread the word to trustworthy friends who are the above ^

I hope you hop aboard our ship, if only to see whether or not it sinks. Either way, it'll be a real hoot of a ride. If you still have questions, reach out, and you'll get answers!Thank ya!

story:
Writer/Actress - Gemma Harvey

There is a need in the entertainment industry for change and growth when it comes to casting and story, however sadly, this isn't always fulfilled.  As an actress I am often frustrated with the work out there for myself,  but rather than complain about the problem, I want to be part of the solution. My continuous work with award winning learning disabled theatre company, Access All Areas and autistic actor Julius Robertson, was my inspiration to write this film. Born from our genuine interactions, his honesty, humour and fresh look at the world compelled me to write something that doesn't just highlight a "disability" - but shows an everyday situation of unrequited love.

While we plan to work with friends and call in favours where we can, it’s not always possible to make a film freely or cheaply. After careful budgeting for equipment rentals, locations and looking after cast and crew properly, we are hoping to raise £8000.  We want the best possible film to be made and to see that money ‘up on the screen’ but have also factored in film festival costs, as the main objective is to raise awareness and for the film to be seen.  If we don’t reach our budget goal, we will still plan to make the film, maybe tightening our belts in certain areas, but also continuing to raise funds.

While making films isn't necessarily in the same realm as medical breakthroughs and saving lives, provoking change in the industry is still very important. Your donations are essential in making these changes happen.  Diversity may be the current word on everyone's lips, but this film will be an example for other learning disabled actors and allow them to see themselves being portrayed on screen in an accurate way.  

I am an actress first and foremost and will be acting opposite Jules in this film. I have partnered with a creative team who between them have decades of experience in various backgrounds through TV, film and theatre – a creative collaboration that won’t fail.

story:
The Story

Autumn Into Fall is about Neel who’s turning 35 and still hasn’t found purpose. Even if he did, he doesn’t have anyone to share life’s beautiful moments with. He hopes that a trip to Bogota provides the spark he needs. Meanwhile, Violet studied abroad there and brings her two best friends to recreate the fun she had in hopes to soften the blow when she gets married and moves away. Their worlds collide when they bump into each other. As they grow closer, it could spell disaster for their lives back home.

Why Colombia?

I (Phil Svitek) have a friend named Edgar who lives in Bogota and one of the main actresses is Colombian. And it’s a place I’m deeply fascinated by given its rich history and culture, far beyond the drugs and violence many of us associate with Colombia. I want to showcase that. In addition to my own research and insights, I’m leaning heavily on those I mentioned to make sure the film is authentic and respectful of their country.

What We Need

You contribution helps us with:

  • Purchasing flights, booking accommodations, providing transportation while there 
  • Allow us to hire key members to make pre-production, production and post-production easier and smoother
  • Equipment costs (hard drives, props, etc)
  • Food, location costs, etc
  • Legal fees and insurance
  • Software costs (StudioBinder for scheduling & planning, Adobe Creative Suite, etc)
  • Music rights (we want to showcase as many songs from Colombia as we can in the film)

If we don't reach our overall goal with this crowdfund, fear not—the movie will still be made. Depending on where we land on the final amount, we'll adjust accordingly to make it work. Over the years, I've been become an expert at reverse engineering things to bring them to life. Knowing the amount we have to work with, allows me that opportunity.

What You Get

In addition to making it possible for us to bring to life a movie about Colombia many of us never see portrayed in media, you'll also get be rewarded with these perks (access to these depends on your level of contribution):

  • Behind-the-scenes footage of rehearsals, filming and editing
  • A copy of the script (either digital or physically signed copy, depending on your donation)
  • Direct updates about film festival screenings and other major announcements
  • A coaching session with me
  • A Zoom Q&A with the cast & crew
  • Access to our "Bogota Guidebook," which is our term for a master document full of information about traveling to Bogota, the places we film at and general dos and don'ts to make your future trip to Colombia worthwhile
  • A photo diary of our time there filming the project
  • Credit in the movie (may range from special thanks all the way to executive producer depending on amount given)
  • Early access to view the film, or portions of the film, and participate as a test screening audience (this means you'll be able to provide us feedback on what you think works and where improvements could be made)

Other Ways You Can Help

You can be a part of the journey and help us reach our goal by selecting one of the perks on this page.

If you can't make a contribution, no worries at all! You can still help us out in many ways:

  • Emailing this campaign link to friends or family who you think would be interested in our film
  • Posting about this on your social media
  • Do you know any businesses who'd love to support a project like this (local or national)? Please let us know (phil@philsvitek.com)
  • Are there film grants you know of we should be looking into? We applied to a few but there's plenty I'm sure we accidentally overlooked during our search

Thank you so much to you for checking out this page! We are exceedingly grateful for all of your support in any form and truly cannot wait for you to see this film!

Additional Info

If you're curious to learn more about me, visit my website https://philsvitek.com/who-is-phil/. And you can reference my past work here:

  • My first feature film (Idyll): https://philsvitek.com/idyll/
  • A sci-fi film I'm developing (In Search of Sunrise): https://philsvitek.com/in-search-of-sunrise/
  • My first novel (Elan, Elan): https://philsvitek.com/elan-elan/
  • A self help book geared towards creatives (Master Mental Fortitude): https://philsvitek.com/book/

story:
What is this story about?

All I Hear is Static is an absurdist/science fiction short film about a paranoid introvert named Blake who’s lack of belonging is exploited after a mysterious tube television appears on his porch. As Blake’s denials are ignored, and the tube television continues to reappear, its ominous origins come both further and farther into focus. 

This story is a fictional retelling inspired by a true story. Don’t believe me?

In 2018 in Henrico, Virginia over 60 families awoke to find vintage tube televisions left on their porch. Upon inspection of security footage, local authorities discovered an unknown deliverer dawning a television helmet dropping all of these tv's off with no explanation in the middle of the night. The assailant was never caught.

Why do I want to tell this story?

Absurdist tales have always been in my interest. For the last year all of us have had our lives changed permanently due to the pandemic. The isolation is what's stuck with me. Things have gotten better, and it's made me deeply appreciate the friends and family who've supported me. This film serves as an allegory for where that isolation can lead you without support. Although not fully comedic in tone, this film aims to be a trip through the uncanny valley explored through a satirical and artsy story, that you aren’t soon to forget.

Where does the money go?

Filmmaking is expensive. Even for student productions like this the costs can add up.  Your contributions help pay for cast and crew members, catering, gear, locations, production insurance, post production, film festival submissions, and marketing, and so much more.  

What you get out of it?

We have reward tiers set up so you get some exclusive goodies for supporting us. We're giving out perks like a Special Thanks in the credits of the film, digital Behind the Scenes Reel and Photo Access, Signed Copies of the script (from writer/director), Co-Producer, and Executive Producer credits, and for >$100, you get entered into a raffle to receive one of three exclusive production props from the set as well as everything else!!

**All of our rewards will be disbursed/shipped at or after the Griffon Film Festival at Missouri Western State University in the late Spring of 2022. 

Get to know some of the crew!

Charles Whitmill is a creative producer born and raised in St. Joseph, Missouri. He is entering his final year at Missouri Western State University before attaining his Bachelor’s of Applied Arts, with a Concentration in Cinema. He has worked on a variety of video content over the past four years including work on commercial productions and over sixty short films. He has experience in multiple positions including Screenwriting, Producing, Directing, Assistant Directing, Script Supervising, Editing, Visual Effects, and Photography.  He is excited to bring his college experience to a close with a culmination of his skillset, shown through an uncanny sci-fi production. 

Jor-El Washington is a producer and alumni of Missouri Western State University, after pursuing a Bachelor’s of Theatre & Cinema with a Concentration in Cinema. He works full time on commercial and narrative productions as a producer and associate producer in Kansas City, Missouri. He has been involved in the industry in multiple positions with ample experience in a variety of areas, and has a high standing reputation within the KC film community for being exceptional at his craft, professional, and dependable. He is excited to use his network and influence to help produce All I Hear is Static this upcoming fall.

Cooper Herrington is a Director of Photography currently studying at Missouri Western State University working towards a Bachelor’s of Applied Arts, with a Concentration in Cinema. Cooper has been a certified cinephile for most of his life, and has spent countless hours studying film long before and during his college experience. He has worked as a cinematographer on a variety of short film narrative content as well as commercial productions. Cooper has a particular eye and style for cinematography, honed in by a love of indie and horror works spanning across decades. 

Jean-Jacques Corbier is an Assistant Director, Screenwriter, Director and Actor based in Kansas City, MO. He is a graduate of the University of Kansas, with a Film and Media Study since 2018. For JJ, film is a lifelong passion. He works as a freelance filmmaker in Kansas City and is ecstatic to be on board with the "All I Hear is Static" crew as AD. His job is to help with scheduling, running time tables, and make sure the shoot runs smoothly and Charles' vision comes to fruition.

Amelia Reeves is a Production Designer working out of Kansas City, Missouri. She is a Graduate from the University of Missouri and Kansas City as of 2019 with a Bachelor’s of Communications with an emphasis in Film and Media Arts. She was raised in St. Louis, MO and has been making films since she was a kid. She has been working in the industry for over four years and works full time on a variety of projects both commercial and narrative as a Production Designer. She gravitates towards surrealist and horror projects, and she has even been a part of projects such as The Stylist, which is a feature film available to watch through Amazon Prime. Amelia can be described as a team player, hardworking, creative, and thorough. She is excited to be on board for All I Hear is Static and help to bring the visual look of the film to life with her skillset.

Adrian Schiavi is a graduate from the Colorado Film School with an Associates of Applied Science and a Concentration in Cinema. He is a local and full time audio mixer and Sound Operator working out of Kansas City, Missouri. He’s worked on a plethora of commercial and narrative projects over the years, and has been working in the industry in various capacities since 2015 in such roles as producer, writer, director, and of course audio. He is excited to bring his work flow to All I Hear is Static and shape the soundscape of the film.

 

Alexander Coutts is a graduate of Missouri Western State University with a Bachelor’s of Theatre & Cinema with a Concentration in Cinema. Over the years, Alexander has spent countless hours perfecting his skills as an editor by working on a multitude of short films in various genres. He is sucker for indie productions and has a distinct love for unnerving cinema. He is excited to use his knowledge in pacing to smooth the metamorphosis from on-set footage into a finished and edited production.

Nathan D. Gonder is a filmmaker and film critic based out of Kansas City, MO. He is a graduate from Missouri Western State University with a Bachelor of Applied Arts with a Concentration in Cinema. Growing up in southern Missouri, Gonder developed a deep obsession for cinema and performing at a very early age, and as of today, his love for the art knows no bounds. He has worked in all capacities on various commercial and narrative projects as a writer, director, producer, and editor. He is currently exploring career options as a visual effects editor, and as VFX Supervisor he will oversee all scenes shot with VFX elements to ensure a smooth transition into post production and editing.

Spliff Temple is a band based out of Kansas City, Missouri. It consists of members (listed in order from left to right) Roswell, Mün, Saint Paul, and Saminull. They blend a variety of electronic styles and bring a unique sound to each piece they produce. The group has been making private and public works for the past five years, and is now branching further into soundtrack composition. Spliff Temple scored PMO PRODUCTION’s previous film, LITTLE FAVORS.They are excited to bring their unique soundscape to All I Hear is Static to enhance the experience.

How are we spending the $$$?

Despite us only asking for >$3,500 dollars, our budget is actually closer to $9,000. We've raised over half of the funds already! But with your contributions we'll be able to afford all of the expenses listed below. Here's what our budget breakdown looks like: 

$1,000 - Catering, snacks, and beverages. 

$750 - Industry Standard Sound Department Stipend

$750 - Industry Standard Production Designer Stipend

$1,700 - Camera Equipment Rentals & Purchases

$1,700 - Production Design, Props & Wardrobe

$500 - Location Rentals

$300 - Transportations

$500 - General Liability Production Insurance

$500 - Industry Standard Post Audio Mixing 

$1,250 - Marketing and Film Festival Submissions

Barring unexpected expenditures, all funding collected that exceeds budget is to be distributed as crew stipends to various crew members currently signed on as deferred.

Risks & Challenges

Covid 19 has rocked the world of cinema with our standards for safety and wellness. Thanks to the industry being pro-active, we have standards set in place to ensure everyone's safety and compliance with CDC guidelines. We aim for most cast/crew members to be vaccinated, and as a fail safe we will be checking temperatures and following social distancing protocols throughout the full duration of the set. 

One of the most difficult challenges with student productions is the cost of production. Often times, no matter how much you believe in a project certain aspects come down to money.  Without it, you are left to sacrifice the production quality of the film, or you sacrifice the ability to take care of crew.

Charles and the PMO PRODUCTIONS team aims to cover both of these bases, and this is difficult task. As most of the crew are working for reduced or deferred rates, he aims to offer substantial meals and a professional set experience to boost the skills of everyone involved. Charles works on professional commercial and narrative projects and has seen first hand the quality of the industry. He is committed to maintaining those standards even with a student production. This allows fellow classmates and underclassmen a chance to advance their portfolios on a student film that sets its standards on par with productions that have multiple times the budget. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate, that doesn't mean you can't contribute. Sharing the campaign on your social media helps spread the word about the project and helps showcase all of the crew members that are diligently working on this short film.

Why do I want to tell this story?
Absurdist tales have always been in my interest. For the last year all of us have had our lives changed permanently due to the pandemic. The isolation is what's stuck with me. Things have gotten better, and it's made me deeply appreciate the friends and family who've supported me. This film serves as an allegory for where that isolation can lead you without support. Although not fully comedic in tone, this film aims to be a trip through the uncanny valley explored through a satirical and artsy story, that you aren’t soon to forget.
Where does the money go?
Filmmaking is expensive. Even for student productions like this the costs can add up.  Your contributions help pay for cast and crew members, catering, gear, locations, production insurance, post production, film festival submissions, and marketing, and so much more.  
What you get out of it?
We have reward tiers set up so you get some exclusive goodies for supporting us. We're giving out perks like a Special Thanks in the credits of the film, digital Behind the Scenes Reel and Photo Access, Signed Copies of the script (from writer/director), Co-Producer, and Executive Producer credits, and for >$100, you get entered into a raffle to receive one of three exclusive production props from the set as well as everything else!!
**All of our rewards will be disbursed/shipped at or after the Griffon Film Festival at Missouri Western State University in the late Spring of 2022. 

Get to know some of the crew!

Charles Whitmill is a creative producer born and raised in St. Joseph, Missouri. He is entering his final year at Missouri Western State University before attaining his Bachelor’s of Applied Arts, with a Concentration in Cinema. He has worked on a variety of video content over the past four years including work on commercial productions and over sixty short films. He has experience in multiple positions including Screenwriting, Producing, Directing, Assistant Directing, Script Supervising, Editing, Visual Effects, and Photography.  He is excited to bring his college experience to a close with a culmination of his skillset, shown through an uncanny sci-fi production. 

Jor-El Washington is a producer and alumni of Missouri Western State University, after pursuing a Bachelor’s of Theatre & Cinema with a Concentration in Cinema. He works full time on commercial and narrative productions as a producer and associate producer in Kansas City, Missouri. He has been involved in the industry in multiple positions with ample experience in a variety of areas, and has a high standing reputation within the KC film community for being exceptional at his craft, professional, and dependable. He is excited to use his network and influence to help produce All I Hear is Static this upcoming fall.

Cooper Herrington is a Director of Photography currently studying at Missouri Western State University working towards a Bachelor’s of Applied Arts, with a Concentration in Cinema. Cooper has been a certified cinephile for most of his life, and has spent countless hours studying film long before and during his college experience. He has worked as a cinematographer on a variety of short film narrative content as well as commercial productions. Cooper has a particular eye and style for cinematography, honed in by a love of indie and horror works spanning across decades. 

Jean-Jacques Corbier is an Assistant Director, Screenwriter, Director and Actor based in Kansas City, MO. He is a graduate of the University of Kansas, with a Film and Media Study since 2018. For JJ, film is a lifelong passion. He works as a freelance filmmaker in Kansas City and is ecstatic to be on board with the "All I Hear is Static" crew as AD. His job is to help with scheduling, running time tables, and make sure the shoot runs smoothly and Charles' vision comes to fruition.

Amelia Reeves is a Production Designer working out of Kansas City, Missouri. She is a Graduate from the University of Missouri and Kansas City as of 2019 with a Bachelor’s of Communications with an emphasis in Film and Media Arts. She was raised in St. Louis, MO and has been making films since she was a kid. She has been working in the industry for over four years and works full time on a variety of projects both commercial and narrative as a Production Designer. She gravitates towards surrealist and horror projects, and she has even been a part of projects such as The Stylist, which is a feature film available to watch through Amazon Prime. Amelia can be described as a team player, hardworking, creative, and thorough. She is excited to be on board for All I Hear is Static and help to bring the visual look of the film to life with her skillset.

Adrian Schiavi is a graduate from the Colorado Film School with an Associates of Applied Science and a Concentration in Cinema. He is a local and full time audio mixer and Sound Operator working out of Kansas City, Missouri. He’s worked on a plethora of commercial and narrative projects over the years, and has been working in the industry in various capacities since 2015 in such roles as producer, writer, director, and of course audio. He is excited to bring his work flow to All I Hear is Static and shape the soundscape of the film.
 

Alexander Coutts is a graduate of Missouri Western State University with a Bachelor’s of Theatre & Cinema with a Concentration in Cinema. Over the years, Alexander has spent countless hours perfecting his skills as an editor by working on a multitude of short films in various genres. He is sucker for indie productions and has a distinct love for unnerving cinema. He is excited to use his knowledge in pacing to smooth the metamorphosis from on-set footage into a finished and edited production.

Nathan D. Gonder is a filmmaker and film critic based out of Kansas City, MO. He is a graduate from Missouri Western State University with a Bachelor of Applied Arts with a Concentration in Cinema. Growing up in southern Missouri, Gonder developed a deep obsession for cinema and performing at a very early age, and as of today, his love for the art knows no bounds. He has worked in all capacities on various commercial and narrative projects as a writer, director, producer, and editor. He is currently exploring career options as a visual effects editor, and as VFX Supervisor he will oversee all scenes shot with VFX elements to ensure a smooth transition into post production and editing.

Spliff Temple is a band based out of Kansas City, Missouri. It consists of members (listed in order from left to right) Roswell, Mün, Saint Paul, and Saminull. They blend a variety of electronic styles and bring a unique sound to each piece they produce. The group has been making private and public works for the past five years, and is now branching further into soundtrack composition. Spliff Temple scored PMO PRODUCTION’s previous film, LITTLE FAVORS.They are excited to bring their unique soundscape to All I Hear is Static to enhance the experience.
How are we spending the $$$?
Despite us only asking for >$3,500 dollars, our budget is actually closer to $9,000. We've raised over half of the funds already! But with your contributions we'll be able to afford all of the expenses listed below. Here's what our budget breakdown looks like: 
$1,000 - Catering, snacks, and beverages. 
$750 - Industry Standard Sound Department Stipend
$750 - Industry Standard Production Designer Stipend
$1,700 - Camera Equipment Rentals & Purchases
$1,700 - Production Design, Props & Wardrobe
$500 - Location Rentals
$300 - Transportations
$500 - General Liability Production Insurance
$500 - Industry Standard Post Audio Mixing 
$1,250 - Marketing and Film Festival Submissions
Barring unexpected expenditures, all funding collected that exceeds budget is to be distributed as crew stipends to various crew members currently signed on as deferred.

Risks & Challenges
Covid 19 has rocked the world of cinema with our standards for safety and wellness. Thanks to the industry being pro-active, we have standards set in place to ensure everyone's safety and compliance with CDC guidelines. We aim for most cast/crew members to be vaccinated, and as a fail safe we will be checking temperatures and following social distancing protocols throughout the full duration of the set. 
One of the most difficult challenges with student productions is the cost of production. Often times, no matter how much you believe in a project certain aspects come down to money.  Without it, you are left to sacrifice the production quality of the film, or you sacrifice the ability to take care of crew.
Charles and the PMO PRODUCTIONS team aims to cover both of these bases, and this is difficult task. As most of the crew are working for reduced or deferred rates, he aims to offer substantial meals and a professional set experience to boost the skills of everyone involved. Charles works on professional commercial and narrative projects and has seen first hand the quality of the industry. He is committed to maintaining those standards even with a student production. This allows fellow classmates and underclassmen a chance to advance their portfolios on a student film that sets its standards on par with productions that have multiple times the budget. 

Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you can't donate, that doesn't mean you can't contribute. Sharing the campaign on your social media helps spread the word about the project and helps showcase all of the crew members that are diligently working on this short film.

story:
ENERGY: A DOCUMENTARY ABOUT DAMO SUZUKI

Damo Suzuki reflects on his life as he confronts cancer and attempts to resume a never-ending tour.

...........

July 17th New Perk Update

Thanks everyone for sharing! 

New Perk Size Guide

                                                                               .........................

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cIV2wR7Dyhw

30 June - Damo Suzuki, Elke Morsbach and Michelle Heighway chat with John Toolan about the making of the documentary.

                                                                             ........................

Energy : A Documentary About Damo Suzuki

Critically-acclaimed director Michelle Heighway has been working with iconic musician Damo Suzuki since 2014, culminating in ENERGY. 

The film shows five years of Suzuki’s life in Germany and the United Kingdom as he confronts cancer and attempts to continue a never-ending global tour. 

We are now crowdfunding for the final phase of the film: archival copyright fees and music licensing which will allow us to honor Damo’s story with the documentary it deserves.

“ENERGY is a wonderful story of hope,” says Heighway. “It’s a personal portrait of an iconic musician, a nomad and a person who connects others all around the world.”


The film examines the past, present and future of Suzuki’s influential music, from his beginnings with legendary band CAN, to his singular outlook on life, creativity, and protest.
 

   

A chance to purchase an original signed photo of Damo Suzuki here and help us with final edits in the film.

What your support will enable:

  • Music licensing 
  • Archival photos and footage rights 
  • Graphics
  • Sound mixing
  • Mastering
  • Colour/Sound Correction
  • Other Post-Production Costs
  • Distribution

 

We are also looking to raise funds for full Dolby surround and grading, DVD release and festival submissions, and for BBFC Classification for cinema screening and DVD and VOD release. 

We were blessed with a great group of contributors from our last campaign.

By backing ENERGY you can choose from a selection of perks including:

 

  • Limited edition T-shirts designed by Sound Carrier Juan Barabani
  • Limited edition coffee cups
  • Photography signed by Damo Suzuki
  • Limited edition poster prints
  • Storyboard and production memorabilia

Please help spread the word!

We’ve collected so much content and can't wait to share it with you.

You can help by sharing this page or any posts from ENERGY online, or by featuring the film in articles of your own.

Press Enquires : Contact

Damo Suzuki Live @ The Hope & Ruin, Brighton 2016 (Recovery Gig). Photo taken by Michelle Heighway.

 

Please share on FB /Twitter /Insta and all social media.

We also have a website: www.energythefilm.co.uk

 

          

Limited Edition T-Shirt.

"Music is the Universe" Design by Juan Barabani

 

 

 

 

T SHIRT SIZING : 

Team 

Michelle Heighway - Director

Michelle is known for her critically acclaimed documentary Mr. Somebody?, a rare intimate portrait filmed over four years and premiered at Sheffield Doc Festival and Leeds International Film Festival in 2014.

Michelle is also a events photographer and has work published via Redwood Publishing, MixMag, Look, Orion Books, DIY Magazine, The Guardian, Clashmusic.com, MyDaily etc.

Her film work has been seen on Channel 4, 40D, Choon TV and worldwide via GeoNet.

Ned Netherwood - Associate Producer / Promoter

 

Ned is the author of Electric Storm: Daphne, Delia & The BBC Radiophonic Workshop. He is also the founder of wasistdas.co.uk, the Krautrock album review database and its related activities.

 

Andrew McKee - Editor

Film Editor/Cinematographer based in Manchester.

Benedict Lawrence - Executive Producer

Benedict Lawrence was born in Ootacamund (also known as Ooty) in South India , an undisputed Bollywood film centre.  Ben developed his passion for film by watching Bollywood movies being shot right on his doorstep.

Michael Schmidt - Executive Producer 

Michael Schmidt was born and raised in Germany and has been working all around the globe for the last 20 years while living in the UK and the USA. He is a consultant and entrepreneur in the Life Science industry, working in Switzerland and the US to help clients understand how technology will transform the healthcare system from treatment to prevention, and how to bring better medicines to those patients in need.

He is a huge collector of vinyl records, specifically in the areas of Jazz and Progressive/Krautrock, and has been following Damo Suzuki and his career for decades. 

Peter Warnock - Award Winning Sound Designer  

London-based sound engineer.

Golden Reel Award / BAFTA Award / British Animation Award Winner.

https://www.pwarnocksound.com/

 Juan Barabani -Animator based in Argentina

 

 My partner and I perform in Buenos Aires and have met so many experimental musicians here.  I am part of The Damo Suzuki Network and have had the chance to play with Damo Suzuki.  

Kiran Acharya - Associate Producer

Writer at the Quietus and a freelance Editor based in London.

Please share this campaign with others and help us to reach our target. We will be posting exclusive updates and news across our social media channels - keep up to date with the production by liking our Facebook page and following us on Twitter and Instagram. We also have a website: www.energythefilm.co.uk

story:
The Story

Tara Manning seems to have it all--a job she loves, a best friend who sticks with her through thick and thin, and a wealthy lifestyle. The only problem is the wealth is provided by the mother Tara loves, but one who is needy and somewhat secretive. Everything changes when Tara meets an architect named Johnny.  They fall in love, and Johnny asks her to move in with him.  Her heart tells her to say yes, but much to her mother's dismay, Johnny lives 600 miles away, in a house once owned by the Italian artist, Lyvia. 

The Tuscan-style villa sits in front of a walnut orchard in the rural California town of Oak Creek. According to the locals Tara meets, Lyvia loved her house, and spent months painting the interiors with beautiful murals. But, one day, out of the blue, she simply leaves, selling everything on the cheap to Johnny, whom she'd hired to design her pergola.  In Tara's new neighborhood, the talk of Lyvia's disappearance is dismissive, even irritable.  But Tara suspects that, somehow,  Lyvia is connected to murders committed twenty years earlier by a serial killer who died in prison.

Slowly, Tara begins to doubt her sanity. But is she truly experiencing a dissolving sense of reality, or is she simply unaware of the tortured and pathological relationships of those she 's so sure she knows?

***

I was compelled to write Lyvia's House after reading about a peach farmer who discovered twenty-five bodies buried in those same orchards where the house is located.  A beautiful setting. A gruesome secret. As one of the characters says, "Death in a place of life." The hold-your-breath suspense of copycat murders are a contrast to the beautiful surroundings and poignant love.  Who's lying, who's keeping secrets, and who's telling the truth?

"Gaslighting" is a form of emotional abuse that can be perpetrated by a family member, a spouse, or even a co-worker.  A gaslighter tells you that what you know you heard them say they didn't say, what you're sure you saw them do they didn't do. "You're exaggerating." "That's not how it happened." "It's all in your head."  After a while, you start to believe them. The term comes from the play and movie, Gaslight.  Gaslighting weighs heavily into the plot of LYVIA’S HOUSE. That’s why at the same time we're raising funds for the film, we allocating a portion for SAFE House.  

If you make a contribution, you'll get some fun goodies.  But...

Here’s What Else Your Contribution Will Do

•    You’re sponsoring a female-written thriller, headed by females. How cool is that? At the same time, you’re helping us spread awareness about "gaslighting", the poisonous mind game of abusers.  
•    You’re an educator. Everything in this film is authentic. Our audience will experience a genuine farming community, versus life at a lovely desert lake in the western part of the USA. Many extras are the actual folks who run the farms and the establishments you'll see in the film.
•    You’re helping to promote the small businesses featured in this film. As we know, small business has been most impacted by Covid lockdowns. 

I and those working with me have a track record for success. The actors attached to the project are extraordinarily talented. LYVIA’S HOUSE screenplay has been approved of by pros, the genre is extremely popular, and we have a great marketing plan to ensure the film gets viewed by many. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Okay, you have no dollars to spare. We get that, for sure. Here’s what you can do instead that will still add currency value to this production:

•    Share our posts, use our hashtags #lyviashouse #psychologicalthriller #indiefilm #gaslighting. Especially that first one. This generates SEO, and get more eyes on our fundraiser. 
•    Suggest sponsors.  Know anyone who'd like a product placement opportunity? We've got some great ones. Case in point, we’re looking for a winery who’d like their label displayed on the bottle from which the main character drinks. (After what that girl discovers, she needs a good bottle of wine.)
•    Leave us comments when we post. Show us you care about LYVIA, so that if we don’t get all the money we need, we’ll feel encouraged to persevere until we do. 
•    And of course, share this page, using the IndieGoGo share tools. 

 

Many, many thanks, and much love, 
Patricia V. Davis
