story:
Welcome to the Cave!

We're making another film and this time we want to invite you to be part of the journey. We're expanding our production in multiple departments and with your help it's going be a bloody good time. 

Ba'al Out

Recently unemployed and frustrated with where his life is headed, a debt burdened millennial’s future is at a crossroad. On his search for truth he finds himself on the spiritual battleground with an ancient archon.

This is going to be a short story that we intend to build upon as a launching pad for a rich immersive world that will expand over time. We're going to be bringing in some top tier talent that has just as much love for the horror genre as we do. We will be showcasing the folks helping bring the project to life throughout the duration of the campaign.

This project is estimated to cost roughly $4,000. If we can raise half of that we would be in great shape for being able to finance the film without selling our soul to Ba'al. 

Here are a couple specific areas that we intended to allocate campaign funds:

  • Creature design - We have killer concept for manifesting Ba'al, but it's going to cost roughly a quarter of our budget to have it done right. The demon's share of the funding will go to costuming including the wardrobe, masking, make-up, and prosthetics.
  • Casting - We're brining in seasoned actors with a genuine passion for the genre and we're going to compensate them accordingly. 
  • Crew - Our crew support the cause as a labor of love, but their technical expertise deserves just as much credit and compensation as the acting talent.

Risks & Challenges

For those who may not be familiar, Cave House Studios has been around since 2005. We've produced over a hundred projects throughout the years including a paranormal mockumentary web series (Mystery Adventure Crew), feature length music documentaries, and most recently a horror short (Succubi Scry) and dystopian thriller (Third Wave). All of our projects have been successfully completed on time and within the budget we had in our pockets.

Yes we're scaling up a little with this project, but in a very manageable way with folks who we have established solid relationships. There are little to no foreseeable risks with our project, aside from eternal damnation. If we don't hit our fundraising goals we'll simply charge it to the debt collectors and hope we get Ba'al'd Out down the road. Ba'al WILL BE released from his dark chamber and he asks that you join him for his reign of terror.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand the world is in a weird place. Hell, that's kinda the main plot point of our film. If you aren't able to contribute financially there are other ways to support the campaign that are just as important, share it with your friends and spread awareness to help gear the big tech overlord's algorithm in our favor.

story:
FOLLOW US ON INSTAGRAM

Short Summary

WHEN WE FACE BEREAVEMENT, HOW DO WE MOVE ON?

On top of the pandemic, I was faced with the horrifying act of finding a missing friend from my LGBTQIA+ circle. I was worried. We all were. Our friend had a history of suicide in their family and the pandemic shook their mental wellbeing. The spectrum of heavy emotions wasn't the only challenge. It also occurred when I requested to file a missing persons report. the police officer asked, "what if they don't want to be found?"

This line tortured me for days. I kept wondering on repeat, “what if I called and checked on them more?” I was heartbroken. Simultaneously, I kept seeing strange clouds that resembled UFOs. It was all too eerie. It was as if a bigger message was trying to come through…

Suicide and mental health are not foreign topics for LGBTQIA+ folx. Most of the time, we only hear about the individual who had suffered or who passed. What about the loved ones who are left behind? The loss creates a fractured mirror, reflecting their grief like ghosts that haunt us.

Although my friend was thankfully found, they left an indelible mark on me. It was a mark of trauma and a mark of healing, resilience, and eventually hope. I'm grateful I had support to move through this challenging time, but I often think about the people who don't have access to therapy or bereavement groups. Where do they turn to when all hope seems lost?

This is Found. A sci-fi story of LGBTQIA+ mental awareness and those who are left behind. With a majority queer womxn creative team, we aim to tell a universal story of bereavement: of finding, forgiving and committing to yourself after adversity. and by doing so, reclaiming your inner peace.

The Story

Rowan is grieving.

We meeting Rowan in her car, holding a bouquet of white roses and chugging her flask. There's a photograph a  woman on her dash--and a looming UFO in the sky. From the car radio, we learn it's the first anniversary of seven UFOs appearing across the world. To this day, no one knows what or why they're here.

A phone call interrupts, it's Rowan's friend and she's  PANICKED.  Their friend Sadie has been missing after switching her depressants two week ago. 

After a series of lost calls, Rowan finally gets connected with the police. She tries to file a missing persons report but the officer chillingly responds, "when they go missing, they don't want to be found."

Suddenly, there's a deafening silence that grows into an otherworldly sound. Rowan tries to escape but something forces her body to drive toward the UFO. Once she arrives at the craft, Rowan surrenders to a fate darker than her grief. She lies down under UFO. Intense BRIGHT LIGHTS shine on her skin--

Rowan wakes up to a surprisingly peaceful scenery and a WOMAN-- the same woman from the dash photograph. It's JILL, her partner who went missing over a year ago. Jill tells Rowan that "they wanted to find you." Jill confesses "It didn't matter how much you loved me. When I left, that was on me. Not you." Rowan sobs. This is what she needed to hear. After their goodbye, the intense lights shine on them, climaxing to a blackout.

When Rowan gets back to her car, her skin strangely starts to glow. She finally found what she was looking for: peace within.... and a phone call from Sadie.

Meet the Creative Team

WRITER + DIRECTOR

JEAN GRANT (she/they) is a Los Angeles based writer, filmmaker and performer. Originally from Portland, she has been performing since 8 years old. Jean is a graduate from Australia's top drama school, The Victorian College of the Arts.

Jean's works include Birth of a Pomegranate, Shauna Lee and other short form content. Recent theatre includes Exhuming Johnny, a sci-fi speculation that she was invited to co-devise and perform in for The Year of Chicago Theatre. Jean is a proud member of Women In Film and was selected for their Actor-Content-Creator Mentorship in 2019-2020.

When not making art, Jean facilitates breathwork meditations and tarot readings, investigates consciousness and the cosmos, hikes in the hills, and adores being a pet and plant parent with her partner.

STORY CONSULTANT

TOM BISSELL was born in Escanaba, Michigan, in 1974. His short fiction has won two Pushcart Prizes and has been published in multiple editions of The Best American Series. He has also written eight works of nonfiction, including Apostle and (with Greg Sestero) The Disaster Artist, as well as many screenplays for video games and television. Bissell lives in Los Angeles with his family.

"ROWAN"

MARNEE CARPENTER's notable credits include CRIMINAL MINDS and GOOD GIRLS; and her Supporting role in the Lifetime Indie Feature WILD OATS opposite Jessica Lange and Shirley MacLaine. Carpenter is currently a series regular in the role of Catherine Martin on CBS’s CLARICE. She is repped by LA Talent and MRK Management.

DIRECTOR OF PHOTOGRAPHY

AKINA VAN DE VELDE is a freelance cinematographer based in Los Angeles. She has spent the last 10 years working in film and video production in New York City freelancing as a video producer/shooter, AC and DP, creating videos for nonprofits and commercial clients such as Adidas, Greenpeace, Fitbit, NYLON, VICE, HULU and Conde Nast.

Akina also worked as an Assistant Editor for award winning Director Madeleine Olnek, whose films were both nominated for Independent Spirit Awards as well as having Sundance Film Festival premieres.

Akina completed her MFA in Cinematography from UCLA. Her work can be seen at www.akinavan.com

EDITOR

Originating from Haiti, RALPH JEAN-PIERRE moved to America as a child. He began his love for the arts and film at the tender age of 7. A graduate of AFI conservatory, Ralph's notable credits include Lost in Space (Netflix), Workaholics (Comedy Central), and SCOOB! (Warner Bros). Currently, he is an editor for Servant (Apple TV+).

SOUND DESIGNER

NICOLAS PACHECO is a sound designer, sound mixer, and music composer born in Bogota, Colombia, now based in Los Angeles, CA. After 10 years of experience with putting out records, and live playing with different bands, in 2013 he started getting involved with the audiovisual world when he worked as composer's assistant and music editor for a TV show that aired on one of Colombia’s biggest TV networks. After that experience, he decided to focus on becoming a composer for visual media. He moved to Los Angeles in 2015 to study Film Scoring at UCLA Extension. Soon after finishing his studies, he began to build a parallel career as a sound designer and mixer. He then created his own full-service audio and music company called Frametone, and since he´s been composing music, sound designing, and mixing for almost every single form of media out there. He was worked in advertisement with clients like Careem, Stee Lauder, KFC, Infiniti, Barilla, GCDS, Los Angeles county fair, and more. In music videos, with artists like Bad Bunny, Kygo, Juice Wrld, Pomo, and more. In fiction and documentary on projects like YG Stay Dangerous, Birth Of A Pomegranate, Expedicion Sensorial, Beachwood, Just Married, and Paul Revere is Dead. See his entire work at www.frametonemusic.com 

PRODUCER / "JILL"

Born and raised in Southern California, SUSAN LUCAS tells stories through film, music and fine art. As an emerging musical artist, she’s currently writing her album and building her own publishing company to develop production sound, songwriting and visuals. After attending Northwestern State University, she immediately began training with Deborah Aquila at the Aquila Studio and still practices her acting craft currently. Naturally, Susan began to get involved in production from feature films, shorts to plays and commercials. She loves working with emerging writers and directors to tell unique and current stories that we experience in the world. Her vision is to share her music and creative work on a global scale and tell stories that move and help heal people, and honestly explores the human experience that helps us recognize ourselves and others. She is focused, committed and excited to be able to continue this journey and purpose.

PRODUCER

LAURA SCARANO moved to Los Angeles in 2018 after living in Brooklyn, NY for over a decade. After receiving her B.A. in History of Art & Design at Pratt Institute, she worked in nonprofits, including her alma mater and Columbia University School of the Arts, fundraising for students to become the next generations of fine artists, filmmakers, and writers. Throughout her career, her mission has been to elevate artists, giving them a platform to showcase their work and implement change in the world. She has produced a repertoire of short films and is currently in pre-production on a feature film and a documentary. Laura is forever a New Yorker at heart, and in her spare time, enjoys ballet, drawing, and taking her one year old labrador retriever to the beach.

What We Need 

We need help with production cost and post production to help get our queer sci-fi movie made!

With our fundraising goal of $8K, we will donate 5% of all proceeds to The Trevor Project, a charity that provides crisis and suicide intervention for LGBTQIA+ youth.

The funds will go towards production—from camera rental to a vintage picture car—but will principally go toward post-production which includes editing composer fees, sound design and editing. The creative team wants to make sure this film is seen to help with our social awareness cause! In order to do that, the funds will also be used to submit the film to festivals around the world. Additionally, we're aiming to use this short to be developed into a feature.

The Impact

As a sci-fi lover, there was always one thing I felt was missing: queer representation. From classic Spielberg sci-fi to Arrival and Annihilation, if there was LGBTQIA identities, they were in the shadows. This short film aims to not only raise awareness for LGBTQIA+ bereavement, but show a story where queer womxn and allies are at the forefront in front of the camera and behind.

As the writer and director of Found, I have made short form content over the last seven years. What marks the difference with this story is that it's my directorial debut. I'm so proud of my amazing team. They all are diverse creatives who have notable film and tv credits, along with talented emerging artists. 

Your contribution helps change the dialogue of queer stories. Found strives to normalize queer protagonists within sci-fi, and with your help, together, we can make an impact on this genre.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that after the hard financial year, people may not be in a safe place to donate--and we hear you! We would appreciate it if you used your voice to help spread the word about our film, along with LGBTQIA+ bereavement and The Trevor Project. After all, it is PRIDE month! What better way to use our voice however your identify!

You can share this campaign via e-mail and your social media platforms. Remember, you can use Indiegogo share tools!
story_txt:
FOLLOW US ON INSTAGRAM
Short Summary
WHEN WE FACE BEREAVEMENT, HOW DO WE MOVE ON?
On top of the pandemic, I was faced with the horrifying act of finding a missing friend from my LGBTQIA+ circle. I was worried. We all were. Our friend had a history of suicide in their family and the pandemic shook their mental wellbeing. The spectrum of heavy emotions wasn't the only challenge. It also occurred when I requested to file a missing persons report. the police officer asked, "what if they don't want to be found?"
This line tortured me for days. I kept wondering on repeat, “what if I called and checked on them more?” I was heartbroken. Simultaneously, I kept seeing strange clouds that resembled UFOs. It was all too eerie. It was as if a bigger message was trying to come through…
Suicide and mental health are not foreign topics for LGBTQIA+ folx. Most of the time, we only hear about the individual who had suffered or who passed. What about the loved ones who are left behind? The loss creates a fractured mirror, reflecting their grief like ghosts that haunt us.
Although my friend was thankfully found, they left an indelible mark on me. It was a mark of trauma and a mark of healing, resilience, and eventually hope. I'm grateful I had support to move through this challenging time, but I often think about the people who don't have access to therapy or bereavement groups. Where do they turn to when all hope seems lost?
This is Found. A sci-fi story of LGBTQIA+ mental awareness and those who are left behind. With a majority queer womxn creative team, we aim to tell a universal story of bereavement: of finding, forgiving and committing to yourself after adversity. and by doing so, reclaiming your inner peace.
The Story
Rowan is grieving.
We meeting Rowan in her car, holding a bouquet of white roses and chugging her flask. There's a photograph a  woman on her dash--and a looming UFO in the sky. From the car radio, we learn it's the first anniversary of seven UFOs appearing across the world. To this day, no one knows what or why they're here.
A phone call interrupts, it's Rowan's friend and she's  PANICKED.  Their friend Sadie has been missing after switching her depressants two week ago. 
After a series of lost calls, Rowan finally gets connected with the police. She tries to file a missing persons report but the officer chillingly responds, "when they go missing, they don't want to be found."
Suddenly, there's a deafening silence that grows into an otherworldly sound. Rowan tries to escape but something forces her body to drive toward the UFO. Once she arrives at the craft, Rowan surrenders to a fate darker than her grief. She lies down under UFO. Intense BRIGHT LIGHTS shine on her skin--
Rowan wakes up to a surprisingly peaceful scenery and a WOMAN-- the same woman from the dash photograph. It's JILL, her partner who went missing over a year ago. Jill tells Rowan that "they wanted to find you." Jill confesses "It didn't matter how much you loved me. When I left, that was on me. Not you." Rowan sobs. This is what she needed to hear. After their goodbye, the intense lights shine on them, climaxing to a blackout.
When Rowan gets back to her car, her skin strangely starts to glow. She finally found what she was looking for: peace within.... and a phone call from Sadie.

Recent theatre includes Exhuming Johnny, a sci-fi speculation that she was invited to co-devise and perform in for The Year of Chicago Theatre. Jean is a proud member of Women In Film and was selected for their Actor-Content-Creator Mentorship in 2019-2020.
When not making art, Jean facilitates breathwork meditations and tarot readings, investigates consciousness and the cosmos, hikes in the hills, and adores being a pet and plant parent with her partner.

He has also written eight works of nonfiction, including Apostle and (with Greg Sestero) The Disaster Artist, as well as many screenplays for video games and television. Bissell lives in Los Angeles with his family.
"ROWAN"
MARNEE CARPENTER's notable credits include CRIMINAL MINDS and GOOD GIRLS; and her Supporting role in the Lifetime Indie Feature WILD OATS opposite Jessica Lange and Shirley MacLaine. Carpenter is currently a series regular in the role of Catherine Martin on CBS’s CLARICE. She is repped by LA Talent and MRK Management.
DIRECTOR OF PHOTOGRAPHY
AKINA VAN DE VELDE is a freelance cinematographer based in Los Angeles. She has spent the last 10 years working in film and video production in New York City freelancing as a video producer/shooter, AC and DP, creating videos for nonprofits and commercial clients such as Adidas, Greenpeace, Fitbit, NYLON, VICE, HULU and Conde Nast.
Akina also worked as an Assistant Editor for award winning Director Madeleine Olnek, whose films were both nominated for Independent Spirit Awards as well as having Sundance Film Festival premieres.
Akina completed her MFA in Cinematography from UCLA. Her work can be seen at www.akinavan.com
EDITOR
Originating from Haiti, RALPH JEAN-PIERRE moved to America as a child. He began his love for the arts and film at the tender age of 7. A graduate of AFI conservatory, Ralph's notable credits include Lost in Space (Netflix), Workaholics (Comedy Central), and SCOOB! (Warner Bros). Currently, he is an editor for Servant (Apple TV+).
SOUND DESIGNER

After 10 years of experience with putting out records, and live playing with different bands, in 2013 he started getting involved with the audiovisual world when he worked as composer's assistant and music editor for a TV show that aired on one of Colombia’s biggest TV networks. He was worked in advertisement with clients like Careem, Stee Lauder, KFC, Infiniti, Barilla, GCDS, Los Angeles county fair, and more. In music videos, with artists like Bad Bunny, Kygo, Juice Wrld, Pomo, and more. In fiction and documentary on projects like YG Stay Dangerous, Birth Of A Pomegranate, Expedicion Sensorial, Beachwood, Just Married, and Paul Revere is Dead. story:
Short Summary

I'm determined to raise awareness of the crisis in education created by the turning of colleges and universities into gig employers, of the resulting damage, and of the brave and risky work being done to solve the crisis. Two years and over 100 interviews into filming, I'm passionately committed to finishing this important film. We'll be following several key characters in this film, and hearing from both experts and those in the trenches of higher ed. You can join supporters like Canada's National Film Board, the Ontario Public Service Employees Union, the Federation of Post-Secondary Educators of BC, ACIFA, CAFA , CUPE and others in making that happen through your generous sponsorship. See film website: http://professorprecarious.com

What You Get

Wonderful perks, including copies of the film and credits in the film that will live on and demonstrate your ongoing commitment to fair working conditions and quality in higher education. You will also be a key part of the team raising public awareness of higher education's "dirty little secret". And sharing with the public both the challenges and the progress being made towards transforming colleges and universities into better employers. Plus you'll receive our eternal gratitude!

What We Need 

We need to finance:

Filming of narration.

Post-Production: Editing, sound design and mix, graphic and text design, music composition, colour grading, stock footage royalties

A promotional package for the completed film for sending to campus groups.

 

The People:

Real-Life Heroes

In this full-length documentary you will meet:

Pam, dancer-choreographer, longtime precarious contract faculty and activist worried about her coming retirement years, working with Contract Faculty Forward to advocate for better conditions for her colleagues and students, and later a strike leader in the biggest strike in Canadian education history.

Sandra, longtime precarious faculty fighting a 22% pay cut that devastates her and her colleagues, and working to make conditions better for all her precarious contract colleagues..

Marco, precarious English prof, author and trombone artist, leading an effort to help his faculty association see that attention must be paid to the urgent needs of the majority of its members: precarious contract faculty, most of whom work for poverty level pay.

Jen, textbook co-author, PhD candidate, mother of two and longtime precarious contract faculty at one of the lowest-paying universities in the country, struggling to find time to finish her thesis and dreaming of getting one of the rapidly disappearing permanent jobs in her field.

Amy, trying to support three children while wrestling with the idea of leaving the teaching she loves so that she can find a job with adult-level pay, benefits and job stability. 

Our Production & Post-Production Team

Gerry Potter, Director-Producer: Precarious faculty for 27 years at 3 universities, award-winning professional director and producer in theatre for over 30 years and film for over 15 years. Gerry has already committed 2 years full-time to this project, has travelled the country filming and interviewing, and is passionately committed to finishing and making this film the best it can be.

Ray Harper, Editor: Ray has worked in film and television since 1975 on over four hundred documentaries and series for organizations such as Access Television and Canada's National Film Board.  He has earned numerous national and international awards including the Japan Prize, and a New York Film Festival Award. 

Jan Randall, Composer: A lifetime musician, known as a composer, keyboardist and sound designer, Jan has composed original soundtracks for over 30 documentaries and has created award-winning music and sound for film, television, radio and theatre.

Jerry Krepakevich, Sound Design and Mix: Producer of more than 130 films for the National Film Board of Canada, Jerry won a Gemini Award for Best Nature Documentary and an Emmy nomination for Outstanding Youth Special. Jerry has worked on more than 200 productions as a sound recordist, editor, designer and/or mixer. 

The Impact

You can be a key part of the movement to improve higher education by raising awareness of the appalling conditions under which the non-tenured majority of faculty, in spite of their love of teaching, struggle to teach--and students try to learn. You can join in the brave work being done to address the issues and make conditions better. It's my fervent hope that through raising awareness we can persuade both campus and public of the urgent need for solutions. Through these solutions, future faculty, students and societies will reap the benefits of a fair and high-quality education system. An improved system will not only more effectively prepare students for the jobs of the future, but will develop the creative and critical thinking skills we need in our leaders and our citizen voters in this new age of demagogues.

Risks & Challenges

We have already faced down many challenges, including false stereotypes of professors, misleading and well-guarded branding by our institutions, opposition from conservative and reactionary elements. We've also had to grapple with the risks that unfortunately must be taken by precarious faculty who dare to speak out about their experiences: a few of our interview subjects, fearing repercussions from administrators, have even worn masks or asked that their faces be digitally rendered unrecognizable. We will doubtless meet the challenges to come in finishing this film--a project which is so important to our team. And we have the team to do that: alongside my many years as a university teacher and activist, I have worked as director and producer in film and theatre for most of my life and been recognized with numerous awards, including Canada Council Artist Awards and a place in Edmonton's Cultural Hall of Fame. And my teammates have even more professional experience and recognition than I do.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also help by sharing this campaign via email, blog or social media, either on your own or by simply using Indiegogo's handy sharing tools.

You can also help the cause by researching the issues. Talk to precarious contract faculty at your local college or university, and check out these reports on the Canadian situation: https://www.caut.ca/sites/default/files/cas_rep...

or https://www.policyalternatives.ca/publications/...

Or for the U.S situation, visit http://www.newfacultymajority.info

or pick up this excellent book: http://muse.jhu.edu/book/28599

Internationally, check out COCAL: http://cocalinternational.org

If you're a student, you can ask your teachers about this issue, which affects you in ways you may not even know. If you're a teacher in higher education, talk to your colleagues and your faculty association or union local, if you have one. If you don't have a union or a truly democratic faculty association, get your colleagues to share their experiences with one another, and build from there. Together we are strong. To that end, I recommend Joe Berry's foundational organizing book: http://www.reclaimingtheivorytower.org

Please get involved. Buy a perk or make a donation, share and spread the word, and work with us for a fairer and better education system. My team and I will be eternally grateful!

story:
Me and My Film...

My name is Roxy. I am a student filmmaker who is passionate about animal and climate activism. I have a first-class honours degree in BSc Zoology (INT) and am now enrolled on the UWE MA in Wildlife Filmmaking. Alongside my studies, I have utilised social media, with my personal brand @roxythezoologist, to share stories about wildlife and conservation, to encourage others to reconnect with the natural world.

When I was 10 I visited Borneo with my family and saw orangutans in the wild and fell in love with them. Upon returning home, I promised my family that one day I would return to help save them. Now, at 24, that time has come.

In June, (NOTE - this date may be pushed back due to covid-19) I will be travelling to the Leuser Ecosystem, in Sumatra, to make a film, to try to help save Sumatran orangutans. Last year alone up to 3,000 orangutans were shot, as the result of human-wildlife conflict. This conflict is on the rise as orangutan's home continues to be diminished for palm oil, pulp, paper, and road development, forcing them to forage elsewhere. A particular favourite food of theirs is durian (a fruit seen as a delicacy throughout Asia). But the farmers do not like this 'crop-raiding', as it is a loss of livelihood for them, so they retaliate, as they have not been shown an alternative solution. In my film, I will be teaming up with a local ranger named Jasson to highlight the workshops that he runs within the local community; a proven solution that I intend to support to become more widely implemented, enabling humans and wildlife to live and thrive alongside one another for years to come

 

Why Now?

There are only 14,500 Sumatran orangutans remaining, 90% of which call the Leuser Ecosystem their home. This ecosystem is also the only remaining place on earth where orangutans, elephants, rhinos, sun bears, and tigers still co-exist. 4 million people living alongside it rely on the ecosystem services that it provides and, globally, it acts as a critical carbon sink. However, this ecosystem is being destroyed at an unprecedented rate. Up to 2 million hectares of it have already been lost and turned into agricultural or urbanised land.

As the Leuser Ecosystem continues to be destroyed, more and more animals are lost forever. Orangutans are critical for the functioning of this ecosystem, acting as 'gardeners of the forest', dispersing seeds over great distances, so the loss of them as a species would have a knock-on effect on many other taxa. As their home continues to be destroyed, they are forced to adapt and find other ways of surviving. Seemingly luckily for them, they exhibit great ecological flexibility and are able to survive off of monocultural (single-crop) plantations. A particular favourite of theirs is durian. However, this poses yet another risk to their life.

Human-orangutan conflict is increasing and despite their protected status, this conflict goes unpunished, due to a lack of law enforcement. Orangutans are killed for food, the illegal pet trade, and due to agricultural conflict. I will be aiming to offer a form of resolution to this agricultural conflict with my film. A study of over 800 farmers in Sumatra (Campbell-Smith et al., 2010) revealed that they are afraid of orangutan and receive no help, so don't know any alternative way of resolving the conflict, other than by shooting at them. But there IS a solution to this. A solution which Jasson has created and has proven to work.

Scientific References...

Campbell-Smith, G., Simanjorang, H., Leader-Williams, N. and Linkie, M. (2010). Local attitudes and perceptions toward crop-raiding by orangutans (Pongo abelii) and other nonhuman primates in northern Sumatra, Indonesia. American Journal of Primatology, 72(10), pp.866-876.

Meijaard, E., Wich, S., Ancrenaz, M. and Marshall, A. (2011). Not by science alone: why orangutan conservationists must think outside the box. Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences, 1249(1), pp.29-44.

Rainforest Action Network. (2018). The Leuser Ecosystem - Rainforest Action Network. [online] Available at: https://www.ran.org/issue/leuser/ [Accessed 25 Jan. 2020].

SOS – Sumatran Orangutan Society. (2020). The Crisis - SOS – Sumatran Orangutan Society. [online] Available at: https://www.orangutans-sos.org/crisis/ [Accessed 13 Feb. 2020].

 

What I Need & What You Get...

I am receiving no external funding for this film, so, as a student and first-time filmmaker, I literally cannot make this film and achieve my mission of helping to save the orangutans, without your support. So from the bottom of my heart, I want to thank you in advance for any support you are able to give, and I can't wait to be able to share this journey with you.

If, like me, you are shocked at how much it costs to create a film, I have created an infographic explaining my budget (see below) to clearly demonstrate where the costs for the film are going. The majority of the costs fall in obtaining visas and permits for filming within the national park, travel, filming alongside the rangers, running workshops for the local people, indiegogo fees, and marketing for the film (to ensure that as many people as possible will see 'One Step Beyond', maximising the positive impact that it will have).

However, there is good news - donations also come with perks, as a token of my gratitude for your support with my project!

Rewards range from social media shout-outs, to photography prints, to invites to a screening, to a named credit in the final film. Full details on rewards can be found in the panel to the right-hand side of this main body of text.

There are even some limited one-off rewards, kindly donated by some amazing people that I know, including a tattoo, plant-based nutrition consultation, and eco-friendly t-shirts!

Even if you are unable to contribute financially, there is so much more you can do to help: please share this with your friends, family, colleagues...anyone you know, and help me to raise awareness about this cause and this project. Anything you can do to help will be greatly appreciated.

 

The Concept in Detail...

In this presenter-led documentary, I will travel to Sumatra to join Jasson, a local ranger from Batu Rongring. Set within the extremely biodiverse Leuser Ecosystem, the viewer will be taken on a journey of beauty, sadness, and hope: from witnessing these beings in their natural habitat, to viewing the conflict they experience, to ending with a long-term solution by running a cannon-making workshop for the local farmers.

This is a story about local people, following a team of rangers, and the farmers that live along the border of the national park. Some farmers have said they feel hurt about how much support goes to orangutan conservation, when they themselves are living on less than $2 per day. They are afraid, they are given no help, and they are desperately searching for a solution. 

I will be highlighting Jasson's long-term solution for human-wildlife conflict mitigation. I want the film to encourage viewers to take action to support them as well, remembering that activism works, and that each of us can make a difference.

Deliverables:

  • 1 x 12-15minute film due 30.09.2020
  • 1 x 1minute trailer
  • 1 x 2minute BTS video
  • Multiple pieces of short-form video content

The Impact...

I really want this film to have a long lasting impact for the conservation of this beautiful species.

I believe that outreach and storytelling goes hand-in-hand and that for a story hoping to inspire change to be a success, there has to be a creative digital strategy to run alongside the film. As such, I will be distributing this film and its surrounding content as far and wide as I possible can.

My main goals are to:

- Inspire people to make positive changes.

- Instill hope for the future of wildlife conservation.

- Provide a long-term solution to local people.

- Help to buy an area of protected land which will restrict government development in the ecosystem.

 

Follow My Journey...

Throughout the creation of my film, I will be posting regular updates, BTS (behind the scenes) clips, and other short-form content, on my social media pages to ensure you come with me every step of the way on this journey to making this film a reality! This social media content will not only highlight the beautiful animals that I encounter, but also the local people who need our support, and delve deeper into the process of running a successful conservation initiative that provides a long-term solution.

For updates follow me on Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/roxythezoologist/

For video-related content check out my YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/roxythezoologist

Or via my Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/roxythezoologist/

Or you can check out my website at: https://www.roxythezoologist.com

Please tell other animal-lovers! Or conservationists! Please tell your friends and your family! I really do need all of the help I can get and more importantly, the orangutans need us too!

 

Risks & Challenges...

Given the current state of the planet, there are possible risks to the project that could be potentially hard to avoid. Currently, the biggest risk to the project is corona virus. Many of us are now in self isolation and global travel has been seriously limited. I am hoping that by June, things will have cleared up and that the trip can still go ahead as planned. However, if this is not the case, I can push filming right back into August or even postpone until the following durian season in November/December if needed. Whatever happens, I will still make this film.

 

Collaborations...

If you represent a brand or company and would be interested in sponsoring this project, please contact me via the link below to find out more about potential collaborations.

Contact me via my website: https://www.roxythezoologist.com

 

UWE MA Wildlife Filmmaking & My Team...

This film is being made for my final submission for my Masters in Wildlife Filmmaking at the University of the West of England, run by Peter Venn, in collaboration with the BBC Natural History Unit. They will be providing me with technical support throughout the duration of the filming process, so I want to take this time to thank and acknowledge them for all I have learnt from being enrolled on this course.

As part of this, after completion, my film will be being screened at the Everyman Cinema in Bristol to a range of industry experts and professionals. I will also enter it into film festivals and create a digital halo campaign surrounding the film.

I would also like to thank Tom Ross and Charlie Dean who will be joining me on location to capture this story, both of whom are extremely skilled camera operators.

Meet Tom!

Tom Ross - https://www.instagram.com/the_wild_operator/

 

Meet Charlie!

Charlie Dean - https://www.instagram.com/charlie._.dean/

 

Thank you again for your support,

Roxy x

story:
What is this film about? 

ATMWOB is an LGBTQ sci-fi short film set in Scotland. It's about a man named Ricky, who travels to a parallel universe in search of his boyfriend, Adam. The only problem is that he only has ten minutes before his body will shut down, so in that time he has to convince the alternative version of Adam to travel back to his own universe.

It's a story deeply rooted in the hard sci-fi genre, using hypothetical technology within the universe to explore the themes and ideas we want to express. In this case, the film centers around the issue of grief, using interdimensional travel as a way of bringing a grieving couple back together, and exploring what that dynamic would be like. LGBTQ sci-fi is a genre that is severely underrepresented, not just in mainstream cinema and TV, but also in the indie world. With your help we can help change this fact and make a film that is honest, bold and exciting.

 

Why do we need your help? 

In an ideal world (or universe for that matter) we would be able to shoot this film for absolutely nothing and just put it out for the world to enjoy.  Believe me when I say that we have tried that before, numerous times in fact. The reality however is that we need people's support to get our film both made and seen. 

People like yourself! We need your help to make what we believe to be a truly unique short film in a world cluttered by rehashed and play-it-safe ideas. However big or small a contribution you can make, whether that be simply getting involved with our social media, or making a financial contribution, we would really, really value your support.

 

Exactly how much money do we need?

In order to make this project fully come to life, we hope to raise up to £6,000 GBP. Ambitious, yes, but we really believe in this project and that number represents our total commitment and faith in this film.

Our talented team of producers have managed to minimise the budget by using most of our own equipment and by relying on the ultimate holy grail of indie filmmaking: favours! However, there are still essential costs that must be accounted for before we can start rolling. These include locations, transportation, food, production design, props, makeup, wardrobe, and of course, the cast and crew.

Furthermore, as well as making sure our cast and crew are well-fed, warm and can get home safe and sound, we also have to ensure that we have enough money leftover for the post-production process. This includes a professional score, a fine-tuned sound mix, colour grading and the obligatory film festival costs so that this short can be seen by as many people as possible. Because of course, every film needs to find its audience and we want our film to find its own as well.

If we don't reach our intended goal, we still have contingency plans in place to get the film made on a more minimal budget. After all, it's as much about the people and the talent involved in this project and not the budget alone. But, of course, having a reasonable budget would be an ideal situation and that is our goal.

 

 

 

Who the hell is Hamish Robertson? 

Hamish Robertson is the writer and director of A Trillion Miles West of Bradford (or ATMWOB for short).

As you saw in the video above, I'm not an actor, nor am I someone who can travel through dimensions, much to my disappointment. I'm just a passionate filmmaker who wants to make a really good movie. That's the ultimate goal here and if I'm being completely honest with you, I just want to make something unique and interesting that people will ultimately enjoy.

Roughly two years ago, I graduated from university with the goal of only making films that I am truly passionate about. Last year I made a short thriller called Hideous that I'm extremely proud of, which did well among the festivals and critics we managed to get it seen to. Since then, I've been busy writing and preparing ATMWOB, and we are now ready to get this film made. 

This autumn, alongside an incredibly talented and motivated team, I'm hoping to use all the skills I've learned over the years to make a really compelling sci-fi short that focuses on the human drama above all else.

 

Meet the crew

We will be updating our crew list over the course of the campaign and look forward to introducing you to more of the talented team we have at our disposal! 

 

 

 

 

 

And once it's all done? 

Once the film is complete, we would love if you'd join us in Glasgow for a cheeky White Russian. Truly, it's our hope that you can join us on the journey of helping this film find its audience. It is our goal to get this film shown at film festivals across the globe, and we would love it if we could share that journey with you.

As a Scottish filmmaker, I'm also committed to getting Scotland showcased as an inspiring setting that transcends cultural stereotypes and tax havens for blockbusters. Great films have been made here, and with your help we can be a small part of that bigger story.

Hideous, my previous short, was named by Indie Shorts Mag as "One Of The Best Scottish Thrillers Out There". My hope is that A Trillion Miles West Of Bradford will have a similar impact for the Scottish LGBTQ sci-fi genre.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We do understand that we're asking for a lot from you guys, and we don't expect everyone to contribute monetarily.

If you can offer financial support, that's great and we'd be very grateful, but you don't have to. Other ways in which you can support us includes the following:

  • Tell your friends! Tell your work colleagues! Get the word out about ATMWOB.
  • Spread the word about our campaign by sharing this Indiegogo page.
  • Follow along on the film's journey through any of our social media pages:
    • https://www.facebook.com/ATMWOB 
    • https://www.instagram.com/atmwob
    •  https://twitter.com/ATMWOB 
  • Talk to us! Reach out to the team, we'd love to hear from you and get your thoughts on this ambitious new project.

 

And that's really all there is to it, just get involved however you can, and we promise to make the best short film we humanly can.

Thanks again for taking the time to read this fundraising campaign and for helping us make A Trillion Miles West of Bradford a reality!

Once the film is complete, we would love if you'd join us in Glasgow for a cheeky White Russian. Truly, it's our hope that you can join us on the journey of helping this film find its audience. It is our goal to get this film shown at film festivals across the globe, and we would love it if we could share that journey with you.
As a Scottish filmmaker, I'm also committed to getting Scotland showcased as an inspiring setting that transcends cultural stereotypes and tax havens for blockbusters. Great films have been made here, and with your help we can be a small part of that bigger story.
Hideous, my previous short, was named by Indie Shorts Mag as "One Of The Best Scottish Thrillers Out There". My hope is that A Trillion Miles West Of Bradford will have a similar impact for the Scottish LGBTQ sci-fi genre.
 
Other Ways You Can Help
We do understand that we're asking for a lot from you guys, and we don't expect everyone to contribute monetarily.
If you can offer financial support, that's great and we'd be very grateful, but you don't have to. Other ways in which you can support us includes the following:

Tell your friends! Tell your work colleagues! Get the word out about ATMWOB.
Spread the word about our campaign by sharing this Indiegogo page.
Follow along on the film's journey through any of our social media pages:

https://www.facebook.com/ATMWOB 
https://www.instagram.com/atmwob
 https://twitter.com/ATMWOB 


Talk to us! Reach out to the team, we'd love to hear from you and get your thoughts on this ambitious new project.

 And that's really all there is to it, just get involved however you can, and we promise to make the best short film we humanly can.Thanks again for taking the time to read this fundraising campaign and for helping us make A Trillion Miles West of Bradford a reality!

story:
About Cheeto and One-Eyed Booger

This is the story of an unlikely friendship. Cheeto is a slovenly, egotistical narcissist while One-Eye is an altruistic idealist...kind of a humble, wandering warrior for good. Their lives collide as the result of two separate, unfortuntate situations. From there, the world is their oyster!

  • Ruedas Films last film, Happy Guy, had incredible success on the film festival circuit and we expect this film to be no different.
  • Our story is not unlike the ultimate buddy film. We met as kids in our high school drama class and have been friends for more than 30 years. We continued creating great art over all these years in NYC, Houston, L.A., Toledo through mediums of film, theatre, directing, writing, choreography, and photography. 
  • A contribution to this campaign means more than just a monetary donation, but also allows us to continue to tell great stories through film in the future. 

How You Can Help

Your contribution goes to the following:

  • Set dressing/props/wardrobe
  • Transportation and lodging (we are coming from all over the country to film this production in Shreveport, Louisiana)
  • Equipment and crew costs
  • Food for cast and crew
  • Insurance
  • Film Festival entry fees

Check out our sweet perks just for you when you help us make this dream a reality!

Can't contribute right now, but want to support us?

  • Check us out on Facebook and Instagram @cheetoandboogerfilm and share!
  • Share this IndieGoGo Campaign

YOU are the key to making this happen and we are so very grateful for any support you give at this time. THANK YOU!

story:
Hello Jason Voorhees Fans! 

Madco Films are excited to welcome you to our Friday the 13th  Fan Film crowdfunding campaign! Our short film will be called JASON UNLEASHED.

Hi I am Brian J. Maddison, a filmmaker from Stoke, England. We are planning on shooting a short Friday the 13th Fan Film called “Jason Unleashed” in August/September. The film will be made regardless if we raise the money or not, but any help will definitely improve our production. 

The film will have a short run time of around 15 minutes.

The story Billy and his Dad go camping in the woods, close to where camp crystal lake used to be. When the father and son go to their tent for the night, they are disturbed by something in the woods. The father and son go missing. Fast forward 6 months and we are introduced to the missing Father’s brother who is currently searching for his brother and nephew. Will he find them alive or are have they become the victims of Jason Voorhees?

A little background about myself. I made a short Halloween fan film back in 2018 called “Halloween H40” What started out as a bit of a laugh went on to get over 135k views on youtube. We followed it up with another fan film called “IT: The search for Georgie” which has just hit 95k views.

 

Last year saw us do an original horror short called “CreepyJack” which was nominated for BEST FILM at the Hellbound Horror Festival”.
 

We want to tackle the Friday the 13th franchise now. 

We are looking to raise only £700 which will pay for  a good Jason Costume, props and gore. We own most of our filming equipment so we should be alright in that department.

We will be offering a few perks that will consist of downloads, posters, and on screen credits. If our campaign proves popular we may introduce a few more perks which we are currently looking into.

We are amateur filmmakers by the end of the day. We may not be the best filmmakers or actors but we promise that everything we do we put our heart and soul into. Our passion for horror is our strong point.

story:
About Georgia Peach

Georgia Peach follows the interactions between Georgia, a young, inexperienced nurse, and John, her disabled, misogynistic patient. John, a veteran, grew old in systems dominated by traditional thoughts of what a "man" should be, gets his kicks out of preying on Georgia. However, his routine harassment is upended when, to his surprise, Georgia pushes back, leading the two down a dark, difficult road that forces Georgia to ask herself what makes a life worth saving.

Georgia Peach is a story about the disguises we don every day to mask aspects of ourselves we’re afraid of admitting to the world, but more specifically, what happens we take off these masks and what we look like when we’re stripped bare. As our culture has leaned towards surface-level judgements and an us-versus-them mentality, Georgia Peach shines a light on choosing empathy, even when empathy is hard.

 

What We Need & What You Get

This crowdfunding campaign was created as a way to support our team of headstrong creatives in our attempt to tell a story that speaks to the power of accepting our faults as an aspect of ourselves rather than vilifying one another for what makes us human.

 

Every donation, no matter how small, helps. Here’s where your money will go:

 
  • Camera equipment (body & lenses)
  • Grip/electrical equipment
  • Production design
  • Location fees
  • Transportation, craft & catering
  • Festival distribution
 

Everything you donate will help the film, and to say thanks, we have some perks to offer you!

 

$10 - A personalized thank you note

 

$25 - Your name included under “Special Thanks” in the credits*

 

$50 - Streaming link for early viewing and a copy of the film’s script prior to release*

 

$100 - An A3, risograph printed poster*

 

$150 - Limited edition multi-color variant poster* 

 

$500 - Associate Producer credit* (name on IMDB)

 

$1000 - Item from set*

 

$2000 - Executive producer credit* (name on IMDB)

 

* all previous perks included

 

We are aiming to shoot in the Spring of 2021, with the goal of finishing the film in Fall ‘21/Winter 22’. All perks requiring shipment/delivery will be made on time with the film’s premiere!

For updates, make sure to follow @georgiapeachfilm on Instagram, or look up Georgia Peach on Facebook!
 

Posters!

The GEORGIA PEACH team loves nothing more than an incredible graphic movie poster, and that's why we teamed up with the amazing Molly Magnell (@mollymagnell)!

Each of our posters sized A3 (11.7 × 16.5 inches) and will be risograph printed on heavy cardstock. This isn't your typical flimsy poster, but a piece of art to be framed and displayed in your home. Risograph printing ensures color accuracy and an incredible texture, plus, no two prints will ever come out quite the same! You can see our multicolor print below!

 

The Impact

With your donation, you will be funding a film that’s ready and willing to examine the uglier truths and unspoken thoughts we all have. This is a film void of blame, a movie that emphasizes the incredible power of empathy and understanding. This film aims to capture everything we’ve all been feeling recently, the isolation, apathy and disconnect, and use it as a way to emphasize connection and unity in our everyday lives.

With your donation, you'll be an active contributor to not only the careers of experienced, headstrong artists, but that of the local Chicago independent film scene, which has been going through many trials and tribulations as a result of the coronavirus pandemic. Now more than ever, as colleges and studios have distanced themselves from independent film, artists are being forced to rely not only on each other, but their greater communities at large.

 

Who’s making this thing?



Jonah Ocuto - Writer/Director

Jonah Ocuto is an award-winning filmmaker born and raised in Chicago, IL. Obsessed with the difficulties we face everyday, Jonah doesn't like to make movies that allow people to escape reality, but rather, stories that give us better insight on how difficult our everyday lives really are. He believes that storytellers have a responsibility to tell redemptive stories that encourage us to be better, both to ourselves and to each other. Scripts and short films he's made have gone on to win awards in competition across the nation -- a testament to his work ethic and dedication to the craft of filmmaking.

 

Previous work: https://jocuto.myportfolio.com/work

 

Gerrit Fahr - Director of Photography
Gerrit Fahr is a cinematographer currently in his final year at Columbia College Chicago. Gerrit has an incredible amount of experience under his belt in the world of cinematography having shot movies both on film and digitally.

Graysen Conklin - Production Designer

Graysen Conklin is a production designer hailing from Louisiana. She was attracted to Georgia Peach by how easily she could personally relate to it’s characters. With a wealth of experience under her belt on both student and professional sets, she hopes to bring a personal touch to John's house, while highlighting the effect Georgia has on it.


Kiki Shelton - Line Producer
Kiki Shelton is a senior at Columbia College Chicago receiving a BA in Producing. As one of the most experienced producers studying at Columbia, Kiki brings a sharp eye and a production-orientated mindset to Georgia Peach, helping us find the best way to get this story told.

 

Jordan Guerette - Composer

Jordan is a composer based in Portland, Maine. He is primarily known for his work with neoclassical group Forêt Endormie and black metal group Falls of Rauros. He was attracted to work on Georgia Peach because it presented the opportunity to musically examine the themes of isolation and the loneliness epidemic through these characters, who feel like people we've all met before.

 

Visual Style

 

While the film is grounded in reality, it’s important to us that this film carries with it hints of something more. As our characters come face to face with secrets they’ve buried for years of their lives, we feel that opening up our film to a more expressionistic, transcendent space is the best way to communicate their journey. The way this film looks will toe this line as we begin to see the spiritual emerge from these grounded moments.

 

To reflect the incredible complexity of the story at hand and the layered, nuanced nature of our characters, camera work will be utilized in a precise manner to allow our audience to understand the fundamental differences in Georgia’s and John’s view of a shared situation. Taking inspiration from films such as FIRST REFORMED, A GHOST STORY and FACES, we aim to shoot these scenes with both a critical eye and an empathetic heart.

 

Last but not least… COVID

 

Of course, we have to acknowledge the elephant in the room -- COVID. It’s our priority to run a safe set that minimizes close-contact between cast and crew, while of course keeping production as efficient as possible. We plan to allocate 1/3rd of our total budget to COVID/safety precautions in order to meet this goal.
 

We will require masks on set, implement social-distancing measures between cast and crew, and place mandate testing in the days approaching, during and after production in coordination with SAG-AFTRA guidelines.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everybody is able to donate to a film, especially when money is tighter than ever for some as a result of the ongoing pandemic. If you can share this fundraiser, that’s more than enough! We truly appreciate your help.

story:
My name is Bryan Ferriter. I was born and raised in Montana. It was in the lush, beautiful landscape of my backyard in Helena, where my imagination was enriched, that I began to write and play out stories as a child.

Hamlet, the timeless tale, first spoke to me when I was a child, and when I began to explore acting officially as a 19-year-old college student at Carroll College, I remember blowing off the dust of a battered script I found at the library. I opened the play, and immediately stumbled on to the famous “Get thee to a nunnery” scene. Instantly compelled, I wanted to know and learn everything I could about this tragic prince exploring his own morality and his quest for vengeance.

Through many trials and tribulations, including the loss of my own father at the age of 20, I brought the full play to the stage. With the professors placing so much faith in me, allowing a 22-year-old college student to take on the monolithic role, I was absorbed and became connected on such a deep and profound level that forever changed my life.

For many months, I received letters from people expressing how moved they were by our production. I knew then that I was doing work outside myself, and through acting and filmmaking was the way I could render my service to the world. From this foundation, I founded my film company, Interwoven Studios.

The goal of Interwoven Studios is to bring stories to life that reach out, speak to, and move a wide array of audiences. Our hope is that after viewing this latest film, as well as those before, audiences can walk away with new ideas and perspectives.

As it is named, Interwoven Studios stands as a symbol of connectivity between people. Through these films, we hope to achieve personal connection between everyone involved, including you, and show that although everyone is different in their own way, we all share a powerful connection with one another.

More than a decade has passed, and sometimes it seems like I blinked and here I am, knowing it is time to return and bring this story full circle. I am ready. I look at Hamlet as bringing an end to a chapter of my life but also opening a new one. I have plans to continue crafting films with talented and incredible artists for the rest of my life.

I am so excited to bring Hamlet to life one more time for the world!

 

 

In filming Hamlet, Interwoven Studios plans to do a minimalistic approach without losing its expected grandiose look for the feature film, while also being able to provide for our intrepid cast and crew:

Subcontracted Services; Cast and Crew    $ 12,000

Insurance Expenses                                           $    3,200

Equipment Rental                                               $   11,000         

(Camera/ Lighting/Microphones)

Production Set                                                     $    7,500

Expendables                                                         $    5,400

Fees and Permits                                                $    5,400

Meals and Entertainment                                $    5,400

Travel: Lodging, Flight, Fuel                             $  10,600

Utilities                                                                   $    1,500

Total                                                                        $ 50,000

All costs listed are an estimate, and will be allocated accordingly, depending on the total received from this campaign.

 

 

Apart from the deep gratitude of we "starving artists," who will sing your praises on every social platform, we have many perks and rewards, including but not limited to:

  • One-on-one time with myself, as well as the cast & crew of Hamlet!
  • Official, personalized works documenting the making of the film!
  • Time ON THE SET; watching it all come to life before your eyes!

 

 

As with every single film, from A-list to independent, multi million dollar to shoestring budget, there is always a great risk. Many wonderful films, even with all the money, may not ever be seen for one reason or another, and everyone is left hanging.

We at Interwoven have an amazing track record to share with you:  every single film we have set out to do has. Been. Done! No matter the hurdle or obstacle, despite it taking longer than usual, Interwoven's films have always been completed, and every contributor has received more than their perks. They have become an integral part of each project, and are proud to know, whether  they see it on the big screen or a mobile device, that they helped bring this cinematic wonder to life.

Our third film, Wuthering Heights, for all the long and hard trials needed to release it, has garnered awards at every festival it was shown, and a distribution deal is not far behind.

See for your self in the teaser below:  

 
Here are the official trailers of our other productions for your pleasure:
Crimson Winter, and What Separates Us
 
 
 

Every success has given us a deeper working knowledge of this crazy risky world of filmmaking. We are ready for it, and with every contribution, you will guarantee the production of Hamlet for the world, and especially yourself, to enjoy for generations.

 

 

We understand not everyone is in the position to financially support this film. However, if you like what you see above, please forward this campaign to family and friends who may be interested. Also, keep an eye out for our theatrical and DVD release!

 

 

Mary has honed her acting craft and talents through tenacity, focus, deep intuition, and a scrappy resourcefulness she developed from growing up in a low-income family. She also attributes her acting abilities to her connection with the wilds of Montana outdoors and the strong sense of community she creates for herself.

Her acting toolbox includes more than 18+ years of theatre, seven independent films, a western web series, several professional film shorts, two documentaries, and several local commercials. She's complemented her experience with film acting education and auditioning skills from the Margie Haber Studio in LA, Lindsay Frame with AMAW in Portland/LA, and Crystal Carson in LA/Atlanta.

Riitano is noted for her vibrant energy, strength, and versatility. Her work has been referred to as captivating and capable as "channeling her inner Glenn Close" and to Julia Roberts, specifically her luminous and infectious spirit. 

 

 

Acting has been a part of Ryan Pfeiffer’s life since Jefferson High School in Boulder, Montana, as a member of their nationally recognized troupe. After his service in the US Army, Ryan came to Carroll College in Helena and continued his acting journey in stage & student film productions, while also appearing in plays around the community.

Ryan’s journey finally led to becoming a part of Interwoven Studios as an actor, writer, editor, production assistant, associate producer, and many various roles; his work appears in all the Interwoven’ s productions:  Crimson Winter, What Separates Us, and Wuthering Heights.

Now residing in Portland, Oregon, Ryan’s acting journey has been twofold as a sanctuary; a place to revive & thrive, and as the perfect platform for creating & telling the greatest of stories to the delight of audiences, no matter their size.

 

 

Peta McKenna hails from Perth, Australia. She recently graduated from the University of Florida this May after having designed sets for the university productions of Pippin the Musical, Red Velvet, Luna Gale and more. She is excited to pursue her career in film stage/costume design and looks forward to working on Hamlet with Interwoven Studios.

 

On behalf of this film's entire crew and cast, thank you for your time and support!

For many months, I received letters from people expressing how moved they were by our production. I knew then that I was doing work outside myself, and through acting and filmmaking was the way I could render my service to the world. From this foundation, I founded my film company, Interwoven Studios.
The goal of Interwoven Studios is to bring stories to life that reach out, speak to, and move a wide array of audiences. Our hope is that after viewing this latest film, as well as those before, audiences can walk away with new ideas and perspectives.
As it is named, Interwoven Studios stands as a symbol of connectivity between people. Through these films, we hope to achieve personal connection between everyone involved, including you, and show that although everyone is different in their own way, we all share a powerful connection with one another.
More than a decade has passed, and sometimes it seems like I blinked and here I am, knowing it is time to return and bring this story full circle. I am ready. I look at Hamlet as bringing an end to a chapter of my life but also opening a new one. I have plans to continue crafting films with talented and incredible artists for the rest of my life.
I am so excited to bring Hamlet to life one more time for the world!
 

 
In filming Hamlet, Interwoven Studios plans to do a minimalistic approach without losing its expected grandiose look for the feature film, while also being able to provide for our intrepid cast and crew:
Subcontracted Services; Cast and Crew    $ 12,000
Insurance Expenses                                           $    3,200
Equipment Rental                                               $   11,000         
(Camera/ Lighting/Microphones)
Production Set                                                     $    7,500
Expendables                                                         $    5,400
Fees and Permits                                                $    5,400
Meals and Entertainment                                $    5,400
Travel: Lodging, Flight, Fuel                             $  10,600
Utilities                                                                   $    1,500
Total                                                                        $ 50,000
All costs listed are an estimate, and will be allocated accordingly, depending on the total received from this campaign.
 

 
Apart from the deep gratitude of we "starving artists," who will sing your praises on every social platform, we have many perks and rewards, including but not limited to:

One-on-one time with myself, as well as the cast & crew of Hamlet!
Official, personalized works documenting the making of the film!
Time ON THE SET; watching it all come to life before your eyes!

 

 
As with every single film, from A-list to independent, multi million dollar to shoestring budget, there is always a great risk. Many wonderful films, even with all the money, may not ever be seen for one reason or another, and everyone is left hanging.
We at Interwoven have an amazing track record to share with you:  every single film we have set out to do has. Been. Done! No matter the hurdle or obstacle, despite it taking longer than usual, Interwoven's films have always been completed, and every contributor has received more than their perks. They have become an integral part of each project, and are proud to know, whether  they see it on the big screen or a mobile device, that they helped bring this cinematic wonder to life.
Our third film, Wuthering Heights, for all the long and hard trials needed to release it, has garnered awards at every festival it was shown, and a distribution deal is not far behind.
See for your self in the teaser below:  

 
Here are the official trailers of our other productions for your pleasure:

Crimson Winter, and What Separates Us

 


 



 
Every success has given us a deeper working knowledge of this crazy risky world of filmmaking. We are ready for it, and with every contribution, you will guarantee the production of Hamlet for the world, and especially yourself, to enjoy for generations.
 


 
We understand not everyone is in the position to financially support this film. However, if you like what you see above, please forward this campaign to family and friends who may be interested. Also, keep an eye out for our theatrical and DVD release!
 



 
Mary has honed her acting craft and talents through tenacity, focus, deep intuition, and a scrappy resourcefulness she developed from growing up in a low-income family. She also attributes her acting abilities to her connection with the wilds of Montana outdoors and the strong sense of community she creates for herself.
Her acting toolbox includes more than 18+ years of theatre, seven independent films, a western web series, several professional film shorts, two documentaries, and several local commercials. She's complemented her experience with film acting education and auditioning skills from the Margie Haber Studio in LA, Lindsay Frame with AMAW in Portland/LA, and Crystal Carson in LA/Atlanta.
Riitano is noted for her vibrant energy, strength, and versatility. Her work has been referred to as captivating and capable as "channeling her inner Glenn Close" and to Julia Roberts, specifically her luminous and infectious spirit. 
 

 
Acting has been a part of Ryan Pfeiffer’s life since Jefferson High School in Boulder, Montana, as a member of their nationally recognized troupe. After his service in the US Army, Ryan came to Carroll College in Helena and continued his acting journey in stage & student film productions, while also appearing in plays around the community.
Ryan’s journey finally led to becoming a part of Interwoven Studios as an actor, writer, editor, production assistant, associate producer, and many various roles; his work appears in all the Interwoven’ s productions:  Crimson Winter, What Separates Us, and Wuthering Heights.
Now residing in Portland, Oregon, Ryan’s acting journey has been twofold as a sanctuary; a place to revive & thrive, and as the perfect platform for creating & telling the greatest of stories to the delight of audiences, no matter their size.
 

 
Peta McKenna hails from Perth, Australia. She recently graduated from the University of Florida this May after having designed sets for the university productions of Pippin the Musical, Red Velvet, Luna Gale and more. She is excited to pursue her career in film stage/costume design and looks forward to working on Hamlet with Interwoven Studios.
 
On behalf of this film's entire crew and cast, thank you for your time and support!

story:
Moonwater 

Deep in the forest, Peter Goodman has retreated to his family’s hunting cabin to drink himself into oblivion. When he finds his late father’s long-abandoned moonshine still he sets out to revive it for one final batch, reconnecting with his brother and his father’s legacy in the process.

 

Indiegogo to get us over the hump

As a team we already have raised $25,000 for "Moonwater." We need your help to raise the last $5,000 to get this movie made. Any contribution large or small will help make the movie that much better.

The Short

MOONWATER, the short film, had its world premiere at the Indie Shorts Awards Cannes 2021. Moonwater will continue its festival run this year at Beverly Hills Film Festival, Lift- Off Film Showcase, Tonkawa Film Festival (where it won Best Short Drama) and more.

 

 

The Feature Film

 “Moonwater is a stirring and intimate portrait of a man who carries on his father’s legacy in the only way that’s been passed down to him. Small moments of humanity shine throughout. Peter is a heartbreaking but compelling character who, despite his flaws, has tiny intricacies that make him endearing to the audience “  - Slamdance Screenplay Competition

MOONWATER, The feature film will expand on the short film it is based on. The film follows Peter and Thomas as they rebuild their father’s old moonshine still together, and in the process they rebuild their fractured relationship.

 

Why Is This Unique?

This will be a truly grassroots film, from concept to creation. The story is about homegrown moonshine and we intend to make this film the same way - on our own. We will utilize family-owned property and locations with a cast and crew made up primarily of friends and family. However, we intend to elevate this grassroots endeavor with ambitious filmmaking centered around a powerful and well-crafted story by award winning filmmakers.

 

 

Why do we want to make this film?

We believe this movie is important. People have an innate need to see themselves reflected in stories. We need to see characters who share our flaws, who harbour our innermost desires, and grapple with our most intense struggles. These stories help us realise we are not alone. They help people grow and heal. They give people hope. 

 

We come from a small rural town on the border of Pennsylvania. Growing up we saw many characters around us. There were people who were often good and often bad, and in many ways flawed. As we got older we rarely saw these characters given a chance at redemption on screen.

 

We want to change that. Moonwater is a story of a rural man coming to terms with his flaws. The main character is grappling with his past and his future. He is a small town man that doesn’t want to lose his heritage in the new world, but feels he must come to terms with his future. It’s a story we think has gone untold for a long time, but resonates on a deep and universal level.

 

Moreso, Moonwater focuses on a particular part of American culture that is fading - Moonshine. We believe this is a unique part of American heritage. It is a tradition that was formed in the early twentieth century during Prohibition. It is a tradition that has largely been passed down between family members, and like many things, is at risk of being forgotten in a modern world. 

 

Movies are important to people. They can give us a way to start to understand ourselves and the world around us. That’s the movie we want to make. A movie that helps people, that shows us something about ourselves that maybe we never realized, and that maybe helps us grow as people. We hope you want to help us.

 

 

 

Why We Need You

This movie is about moonshine. We need to raise funds to make this movie the same way the moonshine it centers on is made: on our own. The only way we can make this movie truthful is if we do it independently, without the interference of an institution. This is the true meaning of grassroots. Made the old school way, with heart and passion.

 

 

 

How You Can Help

This is where you come in! Here's a look at where your contribution will go. 

Everybody involved is passionate about the project and willing to help make this film happen on an indie budget.

$5,000 will us to pay our cast and crew at a time when creatives are really struggling.

Funds will go towards:

Cast and Crew

Production Design 

Costumes

Locations (Small House, Front Porch, Hardware Store, Liquor Store, Hunting Shop)

Camera and Sound Equipment

Insurance

Housing

Food

Post production (editing and sound design)

Festival fees

 

If you are unable to help by backing the project, perhaps you may be able to help us with any of the above. If so, please get in touch with Tyler or Mark!

 

Risks and challenges

There are many unknown factors in making an independent film. However, we have already made the short film as a proof of concept for what we are capable of with half the resources we will have for the feature film. This film means everything to us and we will do everything in our power to make it the best film it can be.

 

Don’t Think We Can Pull It Off?

We already have! We’re essentially making the feature the same way we made the short, with the addition of a few more teammates.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that the last year has been incredibly challenging and not everyone has the financial resources to help out. If you cannot contribute financially, there are still ways you can help!  

Perhaps you can help with donating locations, equipment or food.

Or perhaps you can share this page with anyone who may be interested in supporting this project and follow and share our official instagram @moonwater_film\

 

Who We Are

Writer/Director: William Tyler Wiseman

Tyler grew up in Tioga, New York. He studied theater in college then moved out Los Angeles to be an actor. He found his way into small parts on shows like  “This is Us”, and “Angie Tribeca,” but found his true passion was behind the camera. He wrote and directed his first ever short last year, MOONWATER, which was based on the feature screenplay. The short premiered at The Indie Shorts Awards Cannes Festival in March and is currently touring festivals right now. 

 

 

Director of Photography: David Siciliano

David is an award winning cinematographer and editor from Southern California. He has been lucky to work with some amazing creators on projects that have been seen at festivals and on TV and streaming platforms. Some career highlights include shooting and editing Flunkyball by Tess Forestieri, which won "Best of Fest" and "Outstanding Achievement in Editing" at Buck's County Festival; shooting and editing Echoes of a Winter Sunshine by Oniffe White David has worked with a wide range of brands on commercials and social content, including Budweiser, NBC, HBO Max, and more. He is the co-founder and creative director of Savvy Studios. When not behind the camera or computer, you can find him in the mountains camping with his wife Jessica and their dog Luna.

 

 

Producer:  Mark Wiseman

 

Producer: Lisa Mamazza

 

Producer: LJ Duey
