story:
Short Summary

We're in the last days of post production on 'Embodyment', an ambitious, impactful film about three dancers in the last rehearsal for an upcoming show.  It's been an incredible labor of love for everyone involved, and now we want so much to be able to send it around to a variety of film festivals (domestic and international) over the coming year.

What We Need & What You Get

The catch is that every festival has a submission fee, and they certainly add up quickly!  We want to be able to give this film its best chance at discovering its audience, and we're looking at an average cost of $50 per festival.  The more we raise, the more festivals we'll be able to submit for, and the more we can promote our film in other ways.

A donation to this fundraiser, of any amount, will get you access to watch the film on our website after our premiere party on July 10.

The Impact

In helping us cover these costs, you'll play a direct role in helping our film reach its audience, which is so important in so many ways. 

If we submit and are selected, participating in the festivals will take our film around the world, and give it a chance to be seen by so many more people than a small production company like ours could usually expect.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially we'll absolutely appreciate any support you can give this project for free.  If you want to help you can:

  • Follow Mnemocine Pictures on Instagram and Twitter!
  • Subscribe to our YouTube channel!
  • Check out mnemocinepictures.com!
  • Share this fundraiser, this film, or anything on our social media with your friends and family!
story_txt:
Short Summary
We're in the last days of post production on 'Embodyment', an ambitious, impactful film about three dancers in the last rehearsal for an upcoming show.  It's been an incredible labor of love for everyone involved, and now we want so much to be able to send it around to a variety of film festivals (domestic and international) over the coming year.

What We Need & What You Get
The catch is that every festival has a submission fee, and they certainly add up quickly!  We want to be able to give this film its best chance at discovering its audience, and we're looking at an average cost of $50 per festival.  The more we raise, the more festivals we'll be able to submit for, and the more we can promote our film in other ways.
A donation to this fundraiser, of any amount, will get you access to watch the film on our website after our premiere party on July 10.

The Impact
In helping us cover these costs, you'll play a direct role in helping our film reach its audience, which is so important in so many ways. 
If we submit and are selected, participating in the festivals will take our film around the world, and give it a chance to be seen by so many more people than a small production company like ours could usually expect.

Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you can't contribute financially we'll absolutely appreciate any support you can give this project for free.  If you want to help you can:

Follow Mnemocine Pictures on Instagram and Twitter!
Subscribe to our YouTube channel!
Check out mnemocinepictures.com!
Share this fundraiser, this film, or anything on our social media with your friends and family!

story:
Hello horror fans, welcome to the Indiegogo campaign for Retro Redux Entertainment & Peter Anthony Production's - The Fall of Camp Blood

First of all, let’s make this clear right away - this is a NO HARM, NO FOUL campaign. The Fall of Camp Blood will be releasing in 2021 with or without the success of this campaign. We are opening up this campaign to allow anyone who wishes to support the film and receive a blu-ray reward before the film is rendered and 100% complete. 

Check out the official trailers for "The Fall of Camp Blood"!

 

In The Fall of Camp Blood, we pick up following the events of Friday the 13th: The Final Chapter. Camp Blood has been shut down after the gruesome murders occurred. Before the demolition of the site, a group of teenagers must venture to empty their parent's cabin before it's destroyed. It doesn't take long before they remember why it was shut down in the first place. These are Jason's woods, and anyone who enters must deal with the consequences.

 

Here is a breakdown of how your funds will be utilized:

PRODUCTION: This will cover all of the equipment that we will use in the limited remaining production of the scene such as; cameras, sound, lighting, ambulance & property insurance, etc. 

POST PRODUCTION: These expenses will help cover our editing and visual effects added after the entire film is shot, and will add any finishing touches to the project.

INDIEGOGO FEES AND REWARD FULFILLMENT: We will need this to help cover our expense in getting the rewards to our loyal fans. We cannot thank you enough for donating to our project!

ZERO PROFIT will be made as a result of this film or campaign. 

Taja Kartio was born in 1998, in Burnsville, Minnesota. After moving to Ramsey, she spent a lot of time writing stories and acting them out. In high school, Taja participated in several student films which sparked her interest for film acting. In 2017, while living in Atlanta, Georgia for a short time, she acted in her first credit film, The CleanZing of Lake Lanier. Outside of acting, Taja spends majority of her time writing her own stories. She is currently working on the second book of a zombie apocalypse series she started back in high school titled, The First 400 Days. She plays Courtney, a confident young woman who can hold her own, and the girlfriend of Steven. Follow Taja on Instagram - https://www.instagram.com/tajakartio 

Ethan Spickler is always eager to answer the call to act for us. He has been starring in our short films, commercials, and anything we needed to film together since we were 9 years old. Ethan will be playing Steven, a man who spent his summers on the grounds of Camp Crystal Lake, and is the boyfriend of Courtney. He is currently studying marketing at Iowa State University. Follow Ethan on Instagram - https://www.instagram.com/ethan.spickler 

Peter Anthony is a lifelong Friday the 13th fan and marketing guru, being a driving force behind Friday the 13th Vengeance and Steve Dash: Husband, Father, Grandfather. He is an incredible asset to the independent horror genre, and is the perfect addition to The Fall of Camp Blood team! Peter will also be playing James Dier, the revenge-seeking sibling to the late Rob and Sandra Dier. James' journey is a key one in The Fall of Camp Blood. Will he finally take down the man that murdered his brother and sister, or will the only living Dier sibling undergo the same fate? Follow Peter on Instagram - https://www.instagram.com/thepeteranthony & follow his film Rose Blood - https://www.instagram.com/f13roseblood

Lavonte Morton is a man who needs no introduction - he will make himself known. He plays Marcus, a college athlete who's personality echos Lav's to a degree (in a good way). Lavonte currently works for a roofing company, which keeps him in shape for the role. Follow Lavonte on Instagram - https://www.instagram.com/lavontemorton_

Caleigh Huber is currently a student at Belmont University studying Commercial Music Performance, and one half of the music group "Cal & Izzy B". She will playing the part of Samantha in The Fall of Camp Blood. She is a great fit to this already amazing cast! Follow Caleigh on Instagram - https://www.instagram.com/caleighhuber

Karly Slone is an actress from Akron, Ohio, who graduated from John Casablancas Model and Talent school in Columbus. She is also an extra in the upcoming film adaptation of “All the Bright Places". In addition to acting and modeling, she enjoys photography, where she aspires to "seek beauty in the simplest forms". Follow Karly on Instagram - https://www.instagram.com/karly_slone

Ken Slate is very well known in the Friday the 13th community. Ken is an Executive Producer of Vengeance, as well as Co-Producer and Actor in 13 Fanboy,  and Peter Anthony's "Roseblood". His role as Sheriff Kagen was intended to be a side character in The Fall of Camp Blood, but with Ken's experience as a Former Federal Reserve Law Enforcement Officer and Former Armored Guard for Dunbar & Brinks Armored, his strong performance naturally led to Sheriff Kagen's role expanding in the film. Follow Ken on Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/KenSlate13

Griffin Thatcher has had an extreme interest in horror since he was a kid, and his love for Jason has shined brightly while on-screen. While still following close to the film, Griffin has managed to work full-time and is even on his way back to earn a college degree. Follow Griffin on Instagram - https://www.instagram.com/thatcher33

Brent Edgett hails from Alaska, resides in Iowa, and is a veteran haunted house worker and horror cosplayer. Growing up in the golden age of horror cinema, he grew to have an appreciation for the character of Jason, as well as the make-up effects of the Friday the 13th films. He has over 10 years of Jason Voorhees acting and cosplaying credits in his community. Meeting Brent at a horror convention, we had no idea that one day he would end up becoming the perfect actor to help us complete The Fall of Camp Blood, when we needed a Jason actor to finish up the film. Follow Brent on Instagram - https://www.instagram.com/goregalor

 

Every backer will receive exclusive updates and production information! We also have "killer" rewards as a thank you for supporting our project! These include The Fall of Camp Blood blu-ray, as well as many digital items to choose from!

Retro Redux Entertainment is a small, low budget film and photo production company based just outside of Chicago, IL. We specialize in horror shorts; however, our work spans from podcast work, to documentary filmmaking. While some of our videos are made for tutorial and teaching purposes, most are made for pure entertainment. Our crew is full of many energetic members with extremely hard-working and determined mindsets.

Director Riley Lorden has been making films since a very young age and continues to study film and media, while pursuing his dream of becoming a film director. He's also responsible for all of the editing for all of the shoots, while also being involved in most of the writing.

Producer Nic Christian is definitely the mastermind behind many projects. His charisma and determination has led to many successful projects, including the 2016 Friday the 13th Fan Film, JACK, along with our podcast - Slash ‘N Cast and the Slash 'N Cast Podcast Network. 

Producer Peter Anthony is a lifelong Friday the 13th fan and marketing guru, being a driving force behind Friday the 13th Vengeance and Steve Dash: Husband, Father, Grandfather. He is an incredible asset to the independent horror genre, and is the perfect addition to The Fall of Camp Blood team! Peter is also taking on a main acting role in the film. He is also the writer and director for the upcoming Friday the 13th Fan Film Rose Blood.

Director of Photography Emma Clair graduated from Beloit College in 2019 with a B.A. in Media Studies. She is interested in pursuing fictional narrative work in films that explore concepts of identity through an authentic lens. She has worked with the Beloit based production company, Ethos Films, as a Production Assistant and is currently a producer for Doorstop Productions.  

We are proud to announce that C.J. Johnson is officially signed on to compose the score for The Fall of Camp Blood! C.J. is known for his work in the horror genre, including just last year, when he worked on a film by Blumhouse called "Hurt". He is also composing for Peter Anthony's Rose Blood. He’s definitely a perfect fit for The Fall of Camp Blood, and we couldn’t be more excited to have him onboard!

Please donate or share this page with your friends and family. We appreciate any support you can give us. Thank you for supporting not just us, but independent filmmaking as a whole! 

Feel free to contact us with any questions you may have.

CONTACT/SOCIAL MEDIA  

Use #TheFallofCampBlood #FallofCampBlood or #FOCB

Facebook Group:  https://www.facebook.com/groups/873582376341232/

Twitter: https://twitter.com/SlashNCast

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/slashncast/

YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/rjlproductionsprops

Email: slashncastbusiness@gmail.com ~ Use Subject "Fall of Camp Blood"

Risks and Challenges

Retro Redux Entertainment / Slash ‘N Cast / Peter Anthony Productions are in no way affiliated with Paramount Pictures, New Line Cinema, or anyone one else associated with the Friday the 13th Franchise. If anyone from those entities takes issue with what we are trying to accomplish, we will happily comply with whatever is asked of us by those parties.

The budget for this project is to cover expenses needed to complete the film. We are not trying to profit or compete with the existing franchise. This film is strictly for the fans, from the fans. The final product will be made available to everyone via various web outlets. Backers will receive an exclusive first look at the completed film and updates including behind the scenes over the course of production.

story:
If you had three wishes, what would you wish for? Would you do it - even if you thought it could have consequences?

On a rainy winter's evening at the turn of the century, the White family await their dinner guest. Sergeant-Major Morris has just returned from two decades as a soldier serving in India. His old friend Mr. White is eager to hear stories of his exotic travels... but it's not the stories he holds of foreign landscapes that Mr. White wants his family to hear about.

The Sergeant-Major carries with him a trinket: a cursed monkey's paw that he acquired overseas. It was cursed by an old fakir and can grant the owner three wishes. Despite warning them all of the downfall that befell all those who wished upon it, the White family contemplate taking their chances.

Is it magic? A curse? Or pure coincidence?
 

Why Support This Project?

This is a classic story designed to spook, creep out, and make you think. What would you do if you knew your wishes might be cursed? 

A study of desire, greed, and consequences might feel like it was written yesterday - but this 1902 story taps into the things that really drive human behaviour. We want to bring this story to a modern audience with a high-quality, engaging short film - and that's where we need your help.

We need the final funds to ensure a top-quality production is delivered. Our core funds are confirmed, meaning you can rest assured that this production is going ahead. You will see our cast and crew are confirmed - with recognisable names from British TV, film, and theatre. We also have endorsement from Hammer Films, the grandfather studio of horror, which means you can be a part of horror history by investing in our project.

 

Who You'll Be Supporting

Your donation to our short film is in good hands, with a highly experienced team led by award-winning director Ben Caplan. Here are some of the people involved in creating The Monkey's Paw:

Ben Caplan - Director

Ben Caplan trained as an actor at Royal Central School of Speech and Drama. His credits include Band of Brothers, Call the Midwife, The RSC, and many more spanning twenty years on stage and screen. His interest in horror piqued after working on feature film Caveat - leading him to the discovery of The Monkey's Paw story.

Combined with his extensive acting experience, Ben has also been directing since 2007. After the success of his award-winning Lockdown Lives short films, created during the 2020 lockdown, he wanted to pursue more directing projects - and that's how The Monkey's Paw short film was born.

As a Director credits include:

Theatre: Snapshot Shakespeare (RSC), SNAP.CATCH.SLAM (Pleasance, Edinburgh), The Collector(Underbelly Edinburgh and Arcola London)

Short films: Intelligence (winner Best Dark Comedy short Independent Shorts Awards), Embraceable You (Best Isolation Short Film LAMP), Silence (Capsule Award Winner), Panic Buy, Park Life, Hope, Intern, Man’s Best Friend, Kung Fu Action Chic, Wilting.

Lockdown Lives: In 2020, when the world shut down, Ben Caplan directed four short films: the Lockdown Lives. He worked with a number of actors remotely, moving within the constraints of social distancing and other pandemic restrictions. 

Check them out here.

Ian Gelder - Mr. White

Ian Gelder is a British actor, best known for his roles as Mr. Dekker in Torchwood: Children of Earth, and as Kevan Lannister in the HBO series, Game of Thrones.

Further credits achieved through an esteemed and long career include roles in series such as London's Burning and Agatha Christie's Poirot, as well as stage credits in London's West End and with Shakespeare's Globe Theatre.

Ian's most recent television appearance was as the villain Zellin in Jodie Whittaker's second Doctor Who series.

Mary Keegan - Mrs. White

Ben first directed Mary in 'SILENCE', an award-winning short created for the Lockdown Lives series. Mary has experience across theatre, radio, film, and television, with credits including the National Theatre, BBC Radio 4, Doctors, Eastenders, and Father Brown.

Mary's credits also include a role in Sam Mendes' The Ferryman (West End), The Mousetrap, and TV credits in The Bill, Ladies of Langham Place, My Hero, and Perfect Scoundrels.

 

 

 

George Rainsford - Herbert

George Rainsford was born in Huddersfield in Yorkshire in 1982, and later attended Repton School in Derbyshire. He joined the National Youth Theatre in 1999 and later became involved with student theatre whilst reading for a Bachelor of Arts degree in Drama at the University of Manchester.

In 2003 he won a Goldman-Sachs Scholarship to the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art (LAMDA). On graduation in 2006 his first professional engagement was as D'Artagnan in the Bristol Old Vic's Christmas production of 'The Three Musketeers'.

He is known for his regular performances in, amongst others, "Casualty", "Call The Midwife" and "Waking The Dead", as well as numerous theatre roles (including plays at the Royal Court, RSC and National Theatre).

Peter Sullivan - Sergeant Major-Morris

Peter is a familiar face on our screens, with recent roles in Baptiste, Poldark, The Borgias, Marcella, The Accident, Curfew, Silent Witness, Strike, The Limehouse Golem and many more. His most recent project, Around the World in 80 Days, is released on the BBC later this year.

Peter is excited to be part of this project to bring the Sergeant-Major - a complex, mysterious character - to life on the screen.

 

 

 

Tristram Wymark - Mr. Shreeves

Tristram not only has a long and esteemed acting career, but is also the great-grandson of the author of The Monkey's Paw, W. W. Jacobs! He's excited to be part of this project that will bring his great-grandfather's famous story to life.

Tristram is currently General Nelson Thursday in Starzplay's Pennyworth, and has a long history of TV, stage, and film credits including Tank Malling, Another Country, Victoria, and Phedre at the National Theatre.

 

 

 

Colin Coomber - Director of Photography

Colin Coomber is a talented Director of Photography working across Drama and Factual genres. As an experienced collaborator and visual storyteller, Colin's main passions lie in narrative storytelling, with broader experience in TV, Documentary, Promos, Commercials.

He is excited to bring the world of The Monkey's Paw to life with Ben and the team.

Recent narrative work includes: Horror-short Midnight Snack (Snapper Films) - British Society of Cinematographers Short Film Cinematography Competition 2020 - Top 10 selection. Award-winning The Gnome (136 Films) - currently touring festivals, Award winning Remind Me Yesterday (BAFTA Micro-shorts) - currently touring festivals, The Dam (Channel 4 Random Acts & LSFF Official Selection) and Daylight (136 Films) - a heist thriller currently in post production.

Colin is a member of the BAFTA Crew programme  and a technical guru in the sector, crafting his specialist knowledge of cameras and lenses into collaborative film projects. www.colincoomber.com

Lisa Zagone - Paw Designer

Lisa is an artist working primarily in costume and set design. Her work is playful, densely textured, and full of detail and fantasy. Since earning her MFA and BA in Fine Art from SFSU in California, Lisa has worked on a number of theatre and film projects - you can find more on her website here.

Lisa came on board The Monkey’s Paw project after working with Ben on a feature film, Caveat. Her creepy bunny creation for that film has achieved cult status – and now, she’s making the star of the short film: the Monkey’s Paw itself.

(You could own one of Lisa’s Monkey Paw creations – look for the Executive Producer and Paw reward!)

 

 

Jonathan Lipman - Costume Designer

Olivier award nominee Jonathan Lipman is on board to design the costumes for our project! Starting at Angels costume house in 1984 as an apprentice to Roger Tonks, he's worked with the costumier ever since and is now Production Director. He's worked on West End, TV and film productions including The Witches, Inspector Morse, and Four Weddings and a Funeral. In 2020, Jonathan was nominated for Best Costume Design for the Sir Trevor Nunn-directed Menier/West End stage show, Fiddler on the Roof.

 

 

Kate Unwin - Production Designer

Kate has worked as a freelance set and costume designer for over 20 years. Her art direction includes music videos for Scouting for Girls and Example and an unreleased horror film. Working predominately in theatre, Kate has worked for the National Theatre, London’s West End, regional theatres all over the UK and designed many touring and outdoor productions. She also designs site specific work, installations, bespoke costumes, events and created www.themoonandthefurrow.co.uk over lockdown.. A lifelong fan of horror film and fiction, Kate can’t wait to start working on The Monkey’s Paw. www.kateunwin.co.uk

 

 

Torquil Munro - Composer

Torquil trained formally at the Royal Academy of Music in London, studying piano, composition, conducting and commercial music. As a pianist, Torquil has recorded with countless artists, recently including Ed Sheeran and Andrea Bocelli.

Torquil’s music has been heard on major TV networks and film. In 2005, he received a Golden Trailer nomination for best original music for a motion picture trailer for the worldwide campaign for Warner Bros’ Ocean’s Twelve.

He has scored two feature films: True Love (Antic Pictures) and What We Do (Skyrock Entertainment), along with numerous shorts and commercials. He is also a guest conductor for theatre, currently The Lion King, The Tina Turner Musical, and Hamilton.

Annie Grace - Producer

Annie Grace is a screenwriter and producer. Her latest scripts placed in major contests, most notably as a semi-finalist in the Nicholl Fellowship 2021. She is also the founder of Script Correct, a proofreading and editing service for screenwriters, and is a reader for several festivals.

She’s worked with Ben on developing the script for The Monkey’s Paw and is also a producer for the short film. Currently, Annie is on the post-production team for an upcoming BBC drama series.
 

 

Where Your Money Goes

We need to raise the final £5,000 to reach our budget target. This will mean we can use high-level equipment such as an Arri Alexa camera and related kit, and invest more in production design to make the period era pop on screen. 

Risks and Challenges

Any production comes with its own unique risks and challenges. Here’s what we anticipate we’ll face – and what we’re doing to mitigate risk.

Insurance

We're covered by the required insurances on this project to mitigate risk against accidents, unforeseen circumstances, and other potential issues.

Crew Challenges 

Post-Covid means crew are in high demand as productions that were put on pause have now restarted all at once. 

We’re planning the shoot of this short film for November 2021, allowing plenty of time to secure reliable and experienced crew.

Should Covid-19 still be a challenge at the time of filming, and any crew member is unable to attend at short notice due to isolation guidance, we have an extensive network of experienced crew to ensure continuity of the shoot.

Diversity Challenges

We recognise that the screen industries are historically limited in access to opportunities through non-traditional routes and all forms of diversity.

Those involved with the production will come from a range of backgrounds, including neurodiverse, disabled, and other under-represented minorities. This includes, where possible, opportunities for those starting out in TV and film from non-traditional routes to assist, shadow, or participate to gain experience and be a valuable part of the production. 

Kit Challenges

Using high-quality kit is only as good as the person operating it. That’s why we’ve secured Colin Coomber, an experienced DoP with in-depth understanding of how to make the most of the kit on a limited budget. 

Covid-19 Challenges

Production is scheduled for November 2021 in the hope that much of the current threat of Covid-19 is in the past.

In addition, cast and crew will adhere to guidelines in place at the time of filming, such as social distancing. Masks and hand sanitiser will also be available to all cast and crew throughout the production period. Where required, additional cleaning of the location will take place. Lead crew members will also have taken the “Coronavirus basic awareness in production” training provided by ScreenSkills UK.

Budget Challenges

We’re creating a period piece on a limited budget to avoid overspend on unnecessary production items and maximise the potential of your investment seen on the screen itself. 

We’ll operate on a limited crew, and have only five cast members and one single location. This keeps the budget as small as possible whilst remaining faithful to the original story.

If possible, our location will include accommodation for some cast and crew to reduce costs. 

Project Delays and Other Challenges

As we’ve all seen since 2020, sometimes things can go awry. We’ll ensure we’re as prepared as possible by covering the production with all required insurances to mitigate risk caused by unforeseen accidents, incidents, weather, or other difficulties.

Sustainability and Environmental Impact

We’re determined to ensure our production is as sustainable and environmentally-friendly as possible. This includes:

  • Using a location close to the majority of cast and crew to reduce travel miles
  • Shooting at a single location with production base on-site
  • Online meetings and script readings instead of in-person
  • Using public transport and shared vehicle journeys where possible
  • Hiring materials and props where possible
  • Paper-free where possible and recycling paper materials
  • Sustainable catering including plastic-free containers where possible
  • Training with We Are Albert (funded by industry organisations) to ensure sustainability awareness during pre-production, shoot, and post-production
     

How Else Can You Help?

Your generous donations help us to make our short film a reality – but there are other ways you can help, too!

Spread the word on social media with the #MonkeysPawFilm hashtag, tell your friends and family about our project – and why you’ve chosen to support us. Enthusiasm is contagious!

If you know any businesses who could make the most of a corporate sponsorship with the film, get in touch and let us know! We are happy to discuss potential branding, credits, and marketing agreements, including mention in press releases and promotional materials.

Do you think you could offer an in-kind donation? Maybe you’re able to offer transport, props, or even amazing rewards for our donors! If you think you’ve got the skills, services, or products that could help us, get in touch.
 

Share Us on Social Media!

You can find us on Twitter at @MonkeysPawFilm, Instagram at @MonkeysPawFilm and our Facebook Page. 

We’re using the hashtag #MonkeysPawFilm so please remember to share it far and wide when you tell everyone about our campaign!
story_txt:
If you had three wishes, what would you wish for? Would you do it - even if you thought it could have consequences?On a rainy winter's evening at the turn of the century, the White family await their dinner guest. Sergeant-Major Morris has just returned from two decades as a soldier serving in India. His old friend Mr. White is eager to hear stories of his exotic travels... but it's not the stories he holds of foreign landscapes that Mr. White wants his family to hear about.The Sergeant-Major carries with him a trinket: a cursed monkey's paw that he acquired overseas. It was cursed by an old fakir and can grant the owner three wishes. Despite warning them all of the downfall that befell all those who wished upon it, the White family contemplate taking their chances.Is it magic? A curse? Or pure coincidence? Why Support This Project?This is a classic story designed to spook, creep out, and make you think. What would you do if you knew your wishes might be cursed? A study of desire, greed, and consequences might feel like it was written yesterday - but this 1902 story taps into the things that really drive human behaviour. We want to bring this story to a modern audience with a high-quality, engaging short film - and that's where we need your help.We need the final funds to ensure a top-quality production is delivered. Our core funds are confirmed, meaning you can rest assured that this production is going ahead. You will see our cast and crew are confirmed - with recognisable names from British TV, film, and theatre. We also have endorsement from Hammer Films, the grandfather studio of horror, which means you can be a part of horror history by investing in our project. Who You'll Be SupportingYour donation to our short film is in good hands, with a highly experienced team led by award-winning director Ben Caplan. Here are some of the people involved in creating The Monkey's Paw:Ben Caplan - DirectorBen Caplan trained as an actor at Royal Central School of Speech and Drama. His credits include Band of Brothers, Call the Midwife, The RSC, and many more spanning twenty years on stage and screen. His interest in horror piqued after working on feature film Caveat - leading him to the discovery of The Monkey's Paw story.Combined with his extensive acting experience, Ben has also been directing since 2007. After the success of his award-winning Lockdown Lives short films, created during the 2020 lockdown, he wanted to pursue more directing projects - and that's how The Monkey's Paw short film was born.As a Director credits include:Theatre: Snapshot Shakespeare (RSC), SNAP.CATCH.SLAM (Pleasance, Edinburgh), The Collector(Underbelly Edinburgh and Arcola London)Short films: Intelligence (winner Best Dark Comedy short Independent Shorts Awards), Embraceable You (Best Isolation Short Film LAMP), Silence (Capsule Award Winner), Panic Buy, Park Life, Hope, Intern, Man’s Best Friend, Kung Fu Action Chic, Wilting.Lockdown Lives: In 2020, when the world shut down, Ben Caplan directed four short films: the Lockdown Lives. He worked with a number of actors remotely, moving within the constraints of social distancing and other pandemic restrictions. Check them out here.Ian Gelder - Mr. WhiteIan Gelder is a British actor, best known for his roles as Mr. Dekker in Torchwood: Children of Earth, and as Kevan Lannister in the HBO series, Game of Thrones.Further credits achieved through an esteemed and long career include roles in series such as London's Burning and Agatha Christie's Poirot, as well as stage credits in London's West End and with Shakespeare's Globe Theatre.Ian's most recent television appearance was as the villain Zellin in Jodie Whittaker's second Doctor Who series.Mary Keegan - Mrs. WhiteBen first directed Mary in 'SILENCE', an award-winning short created for the Lockdown Lives series. Mary has experience across theatre, radio, film, and television, with credits including the National Theatre, BBC Radio 4, Doctors, Eastenders, and Father Brown.Mary's credits also include a role in Sam Mendes' The Ferryman (West End), The Mousetrap, and TV credits in The Bill, Ladies of Langham Place, My Hero, and Perfect Scoundrels.   George Rainsford - HerbertGeorge Rainsford was born in Huddersfield in Yorkshire in 1982, and later attended Repton School in Derbyshire. He joined the National Youth Theatre in 1999 and later became involved with student theatre whilst reading for a Bachelor of Arts degree in Drama at the University of Manchester.In 2003 he won a Goldman-Sachs Scholarship to the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art (LAMDA). On graduation in 2006 his first professional engagement was as D'Artagnan in the Bristol Old Vic's Christmas production of 'The Three Musketeers'.He is known for his regular performances in, amongst others, "Casualty", "Call The Midwife" and "Waking The Dead", as well as numerous theatre roles (including plays at the Royal Court, RSC and National Theatre).Peter Sullivan - Sergeant Major-MorrisPeter is a familiar face on our screens, with recent roles in Baptiste, Poldark, The Borgias, Marcella, The Accident, Curfew, Silent Witness, Strike, The Limehouse Golem and many more. His most recent project, Around the World in 80 Days, is released on the BBC later this year.Peter is excited to be part of this project to bring the Sergeant-Major - a complex, mysterious character - to life on the screen.   Tristram Wymark - Mr. ShreevesTristram not only has a long and esteemed acting career, but is also the great-grandson of the author of The Monkey's Paw, W. W. Jacobs! He's excited to be part of this project that will bring his great-grandfather's famous story to life.Tristram is currently General Nelson Thursday in Starzplay's Pennyworth, and has a long history of TV, stage, and film credits including Tank Malling, Another Country, Victoria, and Phedre at the National Theatre.   Colin Coomber - Director of PhotographyColin Coomber is a talented Director of Photography working across Drama and Factual genres. As an experienced collaborator and visual storyteller, Colin's main passions lie in narrative storytelling, with broader experience in TV, Documentary, Promos, Commercials.He is excited to bring the world of The Monkey's Paw to life with Ben and the team.Recent narrative work includes: Horror-short Midnight Snack (Snapper Films) - British Society of Cinematographers Short Film Cinematography Competition 2020 - Top 10 selection. Award-winning The Gnome (136 Films) - currently touring festivals, Award winning Remind Me Yesterday (BAFTA Micro-shorts) - currently touring festivals, The Dam (Channel 4 Random Acts & LSFF Official Selection) and Daylight (136 Films) - a heist thriller currently in post production.Colin is a member of the BAFTA Crew programme  and a technical guru in the sector, crafting his specialist knowledge of cameras and lenses into collaborative film projects. www.colincoomber.comLisa Zagone - Paw DesignerLisa is an artist working primarily in costume and set design. Her work is playful, densely textured, and full of detail and fantasy. Since earning her MFA and BA in Fine Art from SFSU in California, Lisa has worked on a number of theatre and film projects - you can find more on her website here.Lisa came on board The Monkey’s Paw project after working with Ben on a feature film, Caveat. Her creepy bunny creation for that film has achieved cult status – and now, she’s making the star of the short film: the Monkey’s Paw itself.(You could own one of Lisa’s Monkey Paw creations – look for the Executive Producer and Paw reward!)  Jonathan Lipman - Costume DesignerOlivier award nominee Jonathan Lipman is on board to design the costumes for our project! Starting at Angels costume house in 1984 as an apprentice to Roger Tonks, he's worked with the costumier ever since and is now Production Director. He's worked on West End, TV and film productions including The Witches, Inspector Morse, and Four Weddings and a Funeral. In 2020, Jonathan was nominated for Best Costume Design for the Sir Trevor Nunn-directed Menier/West End stage show, Fiddler on the Roof.  Kate Unwin - Production DesignerKate has worked as a freelance set and costume designer for over 20 years. Her art direction includes music videos for Scouting for Girls and Example and an unreleased horror film. Working predominately in theatre, Kate has worked for the National Theatre, London’s West End, regional theatres all over the UK and designed many touring and outdoor productions. She also designs site specific work, installations, bespoke costumes, events and created www.themoonandthefurrow.co.uk over lockdown.. A lifelong fan of horror film and fiction, Kate can’t wait to start working on The Monkey’s Paw. www.kateunwin.co.uk  Torquil Munro - ComposerTorquil trained formally at the Royal Academy of Music in London, studying piano, composition, conducting and commercial music. As a pianist, Torquil has recorded with countless artists, recently including Ed Sheeran and Andrea Bocelli.Torquil’s music has been heard on major TV networks and film. In 2005, he received a Golden Trailer nomination for best original music for a motion picture trailer for the worldwide campaign for Warner Bros’ Ocean’s Twelve.He has scored two feature films: True Love (Antic Pictures) and What We Do (Skyrock Entertainment), along with numerous shorts and commercials. He is also a guest conductor for theatre, currently The Lion King, The Tina Turner Musical, and Hamilton.Annie Grace - ProducerAnnie Grace is a screenwriter and producer. Her latest scripts placed in major contests, most notably as a semi-finalist in the Nicholl Fellowship 2021. She is also the founder of Script Correct, a proofreading and editing service for screenwriters, and is a reader for several festivals.She’s worked with Ben on developing the script for The Monkey’s Paw and is also a producer for the short film. Currently, Annie is on the post-production team for an upcoming BBC drama series.  Where Your Money GoesWe need to raise the final £5,000 to reach our budget target. This will mean we can use high-level equipment such as an Arri Alexa camera and related kit, and invest more in production design to make the period era pop on screen. Risks and ChallengesAny production comes with its own unique risks and challenges. Here’s what we anticipate we’ll face – and what we’re doing to mitigate risk.InsuranceWe're covered by the required insurances on this project to mitigate risk against accidents, unforeseen circumstances, and other potential issues.Crew Challenges Post-Covid means crew are in high demand as productions that were put on pause have now restarted all at once. We’re planning the shoot of this short film for November 2021, allowing plenty of time to secure reliable and experienced crew.Should Covid-19 still be a challenge at the time of filming, and any crew member is unable to attend at short notice due to isolation guidance, we have an extensive network of experienced crew to ensure continuity of the shoot.Diversity ChallengesWe recognise that the screen industries are historically limited in access to opportunities through non-traditional routes and all forms of diversity.Those involved with the production will come from a range of backgrounds, including neurodiverse, disabled, and other under-represented minorities. This includes, where possible, opportunities for those starting out in TV and film from non-traditional routes to assist, shadow, or participate to gain experience and be a valuable part of the production. Kit ChallengesUsing high-quality kit is only as good as the person operating it. That’s why we’ve secured Colin Coomber, an experienced DoP with in-depth understanding of how to make the most of the kit on a limited budget. Covid-19 ChallengesProduction is scheduled for November 2021 in the hope that much of the current threat of Covid-19 is in the past.In addition, cast and crew will adhere to guidelines in place at the time of filming, such as social distancing. Masks and hand sanitiser will also be available to all cast and crew throughout the production period. Where required, additional cleaning of the location will take place. Lead crew members will also have taken the “Coronavirus basic awareness in production” training provided by ScreenSkills UK.Budget ChallengesWe’re creating a period piece on a limited budget to avoid overspend on unnecessary production items and maximise the potential of your investment seen on the screen itself. We’ll operate on a limited crew, and have only five cast members and one single location. We’ll ensure we’re as prepared as possible by covering the production with all required insurances to mitigate risk caused by unforeseen accidents, incidents, weather, or other difficulties.Sustainability and Environmental ImpactWe’re determined to ensure our production is as sustainable and environmentally-friendly as possible. This includes:

Shooting at a single location with production base on-site
Online meetings and script readings instead of in-person
Using public transport and shared vehicle journeys where possible
Hiring materials and props where possible

Sustainable catering including plastic-free containers where possible
Training with We Are Albert (funded by industry organisations) to ensure sustainability awareness during pre-production, shoot, and post-production

Enthusiasm is contagious!If you know any businesses who could make the most of a corporate sponsorship with the film, get in touch and let us know! story:
The Story

Imagine waking up into the world, and it's on fire....

Lost Phoenix is the story of an amnesiac who awakens from a five month coma barely survived the deadly virus.  He has no memory of a time before the pandemic and no records proving his identity.  Now on the run, he sets out to reclaim his true identity and piece together his fractured past.  But when a break in his search leads to a deadly encounter, he finds himself being hunted by a group of heavily armed extremists and a mysterious femme fatale with a sniper rifle.

Now he has to make a choice:  dive into the darkness of his forgotten past or run like hell.

What We Need & What You Get

We just crossed the halfway point of our production and are gearing up for the 2nd half of our shoot this fall.  We want to make this movie the best it can be and need your help to make it happen.  We have some great material in the works:

  • Large scale protest scenes with lots of extras.
  • Intense one-on-one fight scenes involving fists, feet, improvised weapons and a little Capoeira.
  • An extended finale where all parties collide in a flurry of bullets, blades and explosions.

The Impact

Your contribution will help us make a film that lives up to its potential.  Ingenuity is the name of the game in independent film, but with extra funds we'll be able to cut fewer corners and really make these scenes shine.  Your contributions will go to great use:

  • Help cover the cost of props and costumes.
  • Pay for food / drinks for our hard working cast and crew.
  • Rent a second camera for the bigger, more complex shoots.
  • Secure access to great locations.

Risks & Challenges

Let's be honest, independent film is tough.  There are a lot of factors that can go wrong on any project.  At this point in our production, we have solidified a great team dynamic and have successfully met every challenge we've faced.  In most cases, the film has become BETTER as a result of adversity we've faced.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, you can help us by spreading the word about Lost Phoenix.  We're all extremely excited about the film we're creating and would love for you to join us on this adventure!

story:
This campaign is simple. 

We finished our most recent short film One Last Call and would like to share it with the world.  It's a dark supernatural thriller filmed with anamorphic lenses on a claustrophobic movie set. The story is an emotionally intense hat-tip to Twilight Zone and Hitchcock; it tells the tale of a father trapped in a downward spiral of grief as he receives the same phone call every day for thirty years.. from his dead son.

 

The help we need is easy.

We would like help covering the expenses of submitting to film festivals. It's not that they are super expensive, we'd just like to submit to as many as possible. As this is our last short film, it would be exciting to try and win an award for it.

  • Chicago International Film Festival - $70
  • Sundance - $40
  • Dallas International Film Festival - $50
  • Atlanta Film Festival - $35
  • Aspen Shortsfest - TBA
  • New York Shorts International Film Festival - $55
  • Cannes Short Film Festival - $42

There are lots more but you get the idea.

We set our funding goal at $500 to keep it simple. If we raise more than what we need, and it's possible to attend one of the festivals, we'll document our experience and share it with you!

 

The win - win scenario

Our #1 goal is for more people to watch our short films.  So what we're offering is this: donate to help build awareness to our film, we'll immediately send short films for you to watch and enjoy. 

 

Donate $3 dollars, get a private link to the short film One Last Call.

 

 

 

Donate $6 dollars, we'll send you private links to One Last Call ... but also Requital, a psychological suspense thriller short film shot during Covid-19 limitations.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Donate $9 dollars, we'll add on a private link to Tree In a Forest, a compelling dramatic "one scene" ten minute short film produced seven years ago.

 

 

 

 

 

 

Donate $15 dollars, we'll add on the part one and part two of Patient Zero.... The horror short films which inspired a feature film of the same name. The feature production was filmmaker Samuel Haun's first larger budget film as a Director of Photography. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Donate $20 dollars, we'll send you all of the above PLUS a link to Hank and Jim. A mad little descent into the dark horror comedy world filmed 10 years ago. It's weird & funny.. and a whole lot of demented.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

So that's it.

Help us cover the fees for submitting to as many festivals as possible, and we'll send you fun stuff to watch. No waiting several months in hopes the production is completed or the project disappearing once the money is raised. We've done the work so you can enjoy the films.

 

We are venturing into the feature film world for our own stories, so if you'd like to follow to keep updated - find us online at:

https://www.facebook.com/dreamsketchfilms

 

 

Want to know more about Filmmaker Samuel Haun?

 

Samuel Haun is an emerging Texas independent filmmaker born and raised in East Texas. He began traveling the world out of high school as a steelworker building satellite Earth stations around the globe. He then enlisted in the U.S. Navy and served on the Joint Task Force "Horn of Africa" campaign, aboard the USS Mount Whitney.

In 2006 Haun launched his first video production company, directing and producing music videos, documentaries, commercials and short films. His talent for building heavy visual environments using only the resources around him, small crews and little financial backing helped him gain regional success. Haun's dark comedic short "Hank and Jim" premiered at the Texas Blood Bath Film Festival in Dallas in 2010.

Haun's passion and grit caught the attention of several well known Texas filmmakers who hired him to work on several feature films, including Richard Linklater’s “Bernie” (2011) and two William Kaufman features, "One in the Chamber”(2012) and “Daylight’s End” (2016).

His latest short film, “Requital,” a psychological thriller, is scheduled to premiere at festivals in the U.S. and abroad in 2020.

Haun currently lives near Dallas, has three children and co-owns a boxing gym in Forney, Texas.

Find him on IMDB at: https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3918438/

story:
It’s Just Us is inspired by love and all the challenges that come with it. It comes from a place that many will be able to connect to. Love can be seen to many as a double-edged sword because love comes with its highs and lows. This short film grasps both the beauty and the darkness that love can encompass. It's Just Us brings to life the misconceptions and expectations surrounding Love.

 

SO WHAT IS IT? HOW IS IT PORTRAYED IN THE FILM?

 

Love is its own revolution, it's unconditional, it's a universal language we all speak. In a society that still has a long way to go, understanding why this love is valid and how it is the same language we all speak regardless of gender is very important. This film provides a space for love to be perceived differently. Love is genderless. It is powerful. It is fierce. 

 

DOES EVERYONE UNDERSTAND THIS LOVE?

 

We have all asked ourselves this question and felt abandoned, lonely, unloved and pushed aside for whatever reason. It's Just Us is a safe space, an intimate space, a private place that we all know too well. This film brings deeper questions to the forefront; gender equality, LGBTQ+ rights, woman empowerment, and humanity. 

 

 

This film's goal is to provide a voice to the unheard, marginalised and suppressed. It stands with every Arab queer woman whose life is a fight for love and acceptance. Together, through this expressive short film, we can revolutionise love in a society that is very much in need of it. We need to appreciate and see the Arab queer community as part of society, people within their own right.

It is urgent. It needs to be visually experienced. We need to be seen. We need to be heard. This journey can be experienced by everyone. Our hope is for it to reach traditional Arab audiences so they too can see and feel its utmost rawness. A journey not just of feeling, but a chance to awaken deeper compassion and understanding of what love really is.

 

THE BUDGET

 

To ensure this film gets off the ground, a certain amount of funds are necessary, we're looking at 13,380€. This will be divided between necessary shooting equipment, such as cameras, lenses, and lighting, as well as securing the locations necessary for this shoot and abiding by the COVID guidelines in place.

If the minimum budget isn't reached, all the funds raised for this film will go to charities helping the LGBTQ community in Lebanon.


 

 

“It’s Just Us” is a short queer film about two women who meet in the heart of Beirut and go through a journey of love, lust and fight. Beirut symbolises all of it. The euphoria, the pain, the destruction, the fear and the hope or hopelessness that both women have to venture through. They embody this love - this is how they spark a love revolution.

 

 

Beirut is an important element of the film. She is love, elation melancholy, pain, destruction, anger, strength, hope or hopelessness. Ayla and Leila embody Beirut. Beirut is the symbol of every emotion and feeling they go through together.

 

THE TEAM

 

Stephanie Moukarzel (Director): Also the scriptwriter behind this film, she's an independent artist that's worked on documentaries and short films with Beirut as their focal point. She's worked on several personal projects from start to finish on her own.
https://vimeo.com/stephaniemoukarzel

Sophie Ghaziri (Producer): She's is a highly skilled individual with a Masters in International Journalism and Politics, bringing her versatile talents to this short film. She’s passionate, zealous and is the host of the LevantX Podcast.
https://open.spotify.com/show/2LxaIeKaNQ5TZ0F2C...

Ralph Mrad (Director of Photography): He brings his experience and a unique eye for visuals to this project, utilizing his talents as a multi-skilled digital content creator.
https://vimeo.com/ralphmrad

Camil Abi Najem (Production Manager - LevantX): He works behind the scenes to ensure that production proceeds apace and is on schedule. Part of LevantX, he was brought on board to manage the inner workings in the making of this film.

 

 

This short film comes from the depth of my heart. The film has a life of its own. A life that many queer people would connect with. I started writing “It’s Just Us'' at a time when my soul was recovering from a day that destroyed the lives of an entire population - the Beirut explosion on the 4th of August 2020. Beirut lives in my heart. Everything we had was taken away from us - our home, our souls, our being. The pain Beirut makes me feel is as powerful as love. Love is euphoric. Some days you feel a number of good vibrations running through your body and other days it feels too painful to carry. It’s painful when you love something that is constantly being taken away from you. Something the world doesn’t want you to have. When I first started writing the film I called it “Isn’t Love a Revolution” as a way to express what I was feeling - an abundance of emotions, from anger to fear to pain to passion to sadness to love to hope or hopelessness and to pain again. “It’s Just Us” became part of a process of growth. As I evolved, the film evolved. It has its own muse - a muse that created a love revolution in my soul. The process matters as much as the film and its afterlife. When I was writing the script, I imagined Ayla and Leila being icons of love. The icons that would inspire love, acceptance and freedom in a society that is yet to understand that love is a universal language. It’s about people falling in love with other people regardless of their gender. Love has no boundaries. Love does not comply with any religious or cultural beliefs. It is its own belief. Creating “It’s Just Us” is my way of sparking a love revolution in people’s hearts and minds. It’s my way of fighting with the queer community. I want this film to express itself loudly and allow me to create a safe space for every Ayla and Leila and make sure they know that this love is valid and real and that they are seen. It is a piece of art but also a piece that screams for itself, is emotionally charged and comes from an intimate and sensitive place.

 

 

Socials:

https://www.instagram.com/itsjustusshortfilm/?h...

https://twitter.com/itsjustusshort1

Playlist:

https://open.spotify.com/playlist/5OtKmjmGY6wEu...

Sophie's LevantX Podcast:

Her interview with Stephanie (Director) https://open.spotify.com/show/7IVncRdEKFBDNonTd...

https://open.spotify.com/show/2LxaIeKaNQ5TZ0F2C...

https://youtube.com/channel/UCQNa2QFrDyP9pOUI9u...

story_txt: It’s Just Us is inspired by love and all the challenges that come with it. It comes from a place that many will be able to connect to. Love can be seen to many as a double-edged sword because love comes with its highs and lows. This short film grasps both the beauty and the darkness that love can encompass. It's Just Us brings to life the misconceptions and expectations surrounding Love. SO WHAT IS IT? HOW IS IT PORTRAYED IN THE FILM? Love is its own revolution, it's unconditional, it's a universal language we all speak. In a society that still has a long way to go, understanding why this love is valid and how it is the same language we all speak regardless of gender is very important. This film provides a space for love to be perceived differently. Love is genderless. It is powerful. It is fierce.  DOES EVERYONE UNDERSTAND THIS LOVE? We have all asked ourselves this question and felt abandoned, lonely, unloved and pushed aside for whatever reason. It's Just Us is a safe space, an intimate space, a private place that we all know too well. This film brings deeper questions to the forefront; gender equality, LGBTQ+ rights, woman empowerment, and humanity.   This film's goal is to provide a voice to the unheard, marginalised and suppressed. It stands with every Arab queer woman whose life is a fight for love and acceptance. Together, through this expressive short film, we can revolutionise love in a society that is very much in need of it. We need to appreciate and see the Arab queer community as part of society, people within their own right.It is urgent. It needs to be visually experienced. We need to be seen. We need to be heard. This journey can be experienced by everyone. Our hope is for it to reach traditional Arab audiences so they too can see and feel its utmost rawness. A journey not just of feeling, but a chance to awaken deeper compassion and understanding of what love really is. THE BUDGET To ensure this film gets off the ground, a certain amount of funds are necessary, we're looking at 13,380€. This will be divided between necessary shooting equipment, such as cameras, lenses, and lighting, as well as securing the locations necessary for this shoot and abiding by the COVID guidelines in place.If the minimum budget isn't reached, all the funds raised for this film will go to charities helping the LGBTQ community in Lebanon.  “It’s Just Us” is a short queer film about two women who meet in the heart of Beirut and go through a journey of love, lust and fight. Beirut symbolises all of it. The euphoria, the pain, the destruction, the fear and the hope or hopelessness that both women have to venture through. They embody this love - this is how they spark a love revolution.  Beirut is an important element of the film. story:
Summary

We’re long-time New Mexicans with (collectively) decades of professional experience in the film and television industry.

Director Dyanna Taylor is a 5-time Emmy-winning cinematographer and documentary director, whose compelling and beautiful imagery has brought stories from the Nazi-occupied Warsaw ghetto to the stark landscapes of Georgia O’Keefe’s New Mexico to the haunting Depression-era iconography of legendary photographer Dorothea Lange (her grandmother!).

Writer and Executive Producer Terry Borst is an award-winning screenwriter whose credits span film, television, and videogames; he’s authored several books on aspects of screenwriting and also has served as a screenwriting professor at Ringling College of Art+Design and Santa Fe University of Art and Design.

Executive Producer Claudio Ruben is a producer of feature films, documentaries, music videos, commercials and more. He’s also managing director of Santa Fe’s Garson Studios.

Lead actor Bailey Chase's screen credits include playing the beloved Deputy Sheriff Branch Connally in Longmire, Eddie in Queen of the South, Thomas Locke in 24:Legacy and dozens of other film and television roles the past two decades.

Feature film drama 2-WAY is a meditation on marriage, fidelity, mortality, and second acts in American lives. The story’s in the tradition of Richard Linklater’s Before Sunrise trilogy; Blue Valentine; and Paris, Texas. This movie is aimed at an adult audience hungry for challenging and emotionally riveting content in the feature film format. (To find out much more about 2-WAY, visit us on Facebook, where we've been actively posting for more than a year.)

The creative team is passionate about bringing this story to the screen -- and it’s also passionate about further developing above-the-line film/TV infrastructure in New Mexico. In the past decade, New Mexico has become a major center of production for feature films and television series -- but very few of these projects ever originate in the state. 2-WAY hopes to be part of a movement that turns that around.

With the recent passage of New Mexico Senate Bill 2, there are even more reasons to develop the state’s film infrastructure outside of Albuquerque and Santa Fe. Up until now, Las Cruces has been an underutilized region, despite the city’s energy and creativity.

2-WAY’s executive producers have both taught in higher education, and are also excited about involving current students and recent alums of New Mexico State University and Dona Ana Community College in all aspects of the film’s pre-production, production and post-production. From catering to publicity to on-set internships, our hope is to intersect with numerous academic programs.

Success breeds success. Homegrown films produced in Las Cruces and other under-utilized regions of New Mexico will help to keep creative talent in the state, contributing back to the local economy and local educational development. Film production is an economic multiplier, as local vendors (providing everything from food to supplies to haircuts to hotel rooms) directly and indirectly profit from the presence of cast and crew.

Though no one can predict the overall outreach of any one film project, we also know what happens to a region when it’s prominently featured in successful films and TV series. Films wind up marketing their shooting locations. Southern New Mexico possesses breathtaking visuals, compelling recreation activities, and entrepreneurial opportunity. As more and more film projects are undertaken in the Las Cruces, economic activity can be sure to increase (as it has in Albuquerque and Santa Fe).

But in order to make this happen, 2-WAY needs your help. Our film is completely independently financed. We’re looking to private investment and product placement as a couple of our revenue streams. But your contribution to this campaign will go first and foremost towards the employment of local artists and vendors in the greater Las Cruces region. You’ll be contributing not to a single film, but to the future of southern New Mexico.

What’s the Story, Anyway?

We can’t tell you too much, of course. But our characters embark on a roadtrip from Los Angeles to southern New Mexico, relocating because of a job offer at New Mexico State University. While the film ends just before they arrive at NMSU, the job offer drives their actions throughout.

We’re excited about making Las Cruces and NMSU a key underpinning to the story. And if you’re an NMSU student or alum -- or know one -- we hope you share our excitement at featuring this key component of Las Cruces’s economic and cultural landscape.

What We Need

In this campaign, we’re seeking $100,000, which will contribute considerably to our half-million dollar budget (some of which has already been raised).

These funds will help provide jobs and experience for local film crews, will pay for housing and meals from the local hospitality industry for the actors and non-resident crew, will offer training opportunities to young graduates from NMSU & DACC, will pay for construction and transportation supplies from local industry -- and much more.

What You Get

To incentivize your contribution, we’ve developed a number of special perks, including:

  • An invitation to the red carpet premiere in either Santa Fe or Las Cruces!
  • A chance to call out “Action!” on the first day of the shoot!
  • Breakfast with the executive producers during pre-production!
  • A background extra role!
  • A raffle ticket for a romantic quick weekend in Mesilla, New Mexico. (Just outside Las Cruces.)
  • A weekend hotel&dine package in Santa Fe!
  • A customized jewelry piece used in the film!
  • And even an executive producer credit!

This is only a partial list of the incentives we’ve developed for every contribution level, and we're still developing more perks (so stay tuned!). Select this link for an extremely complete overview of our incentives.

What Happens If the Campaign Falls Short of Its Goal

We’re confident that we’ll reach our goal, but even if we fall a little short, the money will still all be earmarked for local production and local vendors and residents. Your contribution goes to real people in New Mexico. And the perks you’ve secured with your contribution will, of course, be delivered.

The Impact of Your Contribution

We’ve stressed the importance of this campaign to New Mexico and New Mexicans. But this project is equally valuable if you care about independent film and quality storytelling.

Look, Disney doesn’t need to crowdfund to make another film in the Star Wars or Marvel universe. Mass-audience films such as these are great eye candy with a built-in audience, and their business model is highly successful.

Independent films are very different. They’re too small for large media corporations to underwrite. They’re not likely to generate vast returns on investment.

This is why your contribution to 2-WAY can make a real difference: you’re helping to diversify storytelling and make this world just a little bit more interesting.

2-WAY is a deep consideration of marriage, love, fidelity and commitment in our lives. All of us make choices throughout our lives, with no roadmap for our individual destinations. When’s the last time a film story has really made you think about some of the important decisions you’ve made? We’re not going to tell you that 2-WAY will change your life -- but it may offer you a unique vantage point for considering your own choices, and we hope it’ll provide you a story you’ll savor for some time to come.

The Filmmakers’ Track Record

Each of 2-WAY’s creative principals has forged a career in making media (no small thing!). When the opportunity has arisen, each filmmaker has seized the opportunity to create media that makes some small difference in the world:

  • Dyanna Taylor has traveled the world lensing and directing films, documentaries, and television specials on social issues and environmental/wildlife concerns. A Buddhist, lover of animals and the natural world, Taylor also co-leads the “Wisdom of No Technology Media Makers” retreats, and just completed the 4th annual media retreat in the mountains of New Mexico.
  • Claudio Ruben has produced several ENDWI commercials to keep the roads safe and reduce drinking and driving in New Mexico. He produced a promotional film on the value of Tibetan culture in the modern world that helped raise $1 million for the Institute of Tibetan Classics (a library of all Tibetan knowledge and culture for the world), and he co-founded and ran the Sun Valley Spiritual Film Festival from 2005-2007, a festival that presented films that explored spiritual traditions from around the world and that cherished the human spirit.
  • Aside from his work in the entertainment sphere, screenwriter/executive producer Terry Borst has scripted training videogames that taught firefighters to be better situational commanders, and military officers to be better leaders when deployed overseas.

Dyanna, Claudio and Terry are passionate about making 2-WAY because the big questions it asks are precisely the questions they ask about their own lives.

Risks & Challenges

Any film project offers risk. There is always the possibility that the production won’t go forward, or that post-production won’t be completed. (For example, something could happen to BOTH of the executive producers; but fingers crossed, it won’t!)

However, we think this risk is minimal, and here’s why:

  • Each member of the creative team is an experienced industry professional who has brought many media projects to completion.
  • The crowdfunding is one of several revenue streams we’re pursuing. We’ve already been in conversation with industry funding entities and product placement specialists. We’ve spent 18 months laying the groundwork for our film funding.
  • The budget is lean and mean, and we know how to meet deadlines and work within budget lines.
  • The state of New Mexico’s film incentives, and the cooperation of the community of Las Cruces, makes meeting our funding needs even easier.

Our challenge is assembling the totality of our budget as quickly as possible, so we can get to production. We believe we can accomplish this before the end of 2019. Because of our collective professional experience, we know we can put together cast and crew quite rapidly -- that's actually the easy part!

Other Ways You Can Help

We know money can be difficult to spare (but know that even a $10 contribution helps us move forward: all contributions are valuable)!

But no matter what you can or can’t contribute financially, you can also contribute in other ways:

Spread the word about 2-WAY through any social media you use, and any emails you send out to people. And feel free to mention 2-WAY when you’re conversing with people face-to-face!

Encourage your friends and family to “like” 2-WAY on social media, and view 2-WAY’s website (2waythemovie.com). They can sign up for exclusive email blasts about the film!

Use Indiegogo’s share tools! “Heart” us to follow the campaign to receive email updates posted by the campaign team; share the campaign through your Facebook page; tweet the campaign out to your Twitter followers; copy the campaign URL and paste it into an email or social media update.

Know How Grateful We Are

Your support means the world to us, and we’re honored to have it. We’re going to make a terrific independent film that will also showcase southern New Mexico, Las Cruces and New Mexico State University. We’re going to further Las Cruces’s film infrastructure and crew base, which will only help to springboard other film and television projects in the region in the years ahead.

And you’ll be a part of all of it, in a very crucial way.

story:
Teaser Trailer

 

 

Short Summary

After completing my award winning short film TABULA RASA (2012) I had to step away from filmmaking and devote myself to a family crisis full time. During that time I kept writing and developing both features and shorts to have options at different levels to work towards when I returned to making films. During that time I planted the seeds of numerous projects. Among them, my previous short film THE DISAPPEARANCE (2017) (successfully backed at Kickstarter), this film A QUIET THUNDER, and several more. A QUIET THUNDER is a personal passion project of mine and that passion has extended to everyone who has come aboard the project since it's inception.  Each person on the production put a lot of physical, emotional, mental and financial efforts into it's creation. So, it's essential to us to raise funds to be able to finish it and put it out into the world right via festivals and streaming platforms.  Check out the film's trailer and for more insights, consider contributing to the campaign with our gratitude. The themes and ideas of this film come from personal experiences in relationships, my love for nature, it's role in symphonic desire, my respect and interest for ecology and my belief in the possiblilty of second chance. 

~ John David Levy

I've been pledging to numerous project campaigns here at IndieGoGo and several other platforms for the better part of a decade.  And it has always brought me tremendous joy to be able to help fellow creators realize their visions. I hope and imagine I am not alone in that feeling.

You're contribution to this short film would mean us being able to finish it, by flying our actors back to location for pick-up shoots and most of all pay for film festival submission fees and give it the exposure it deserves in the festival circuit.  

If we succeed and give the film the exposure it deserves it could help the film reach other platforms, open doors for cast and crew and put us in the same spaces as other like minded artists or potential collaborations. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need at least $2,500. Where the majority of that money goes is to film festival submissions which are roughly $50 a pop (give or take) and increase in cost after each missed deadline. So, if you figure 40-50 film festivals it adds up. 

A smaller percentage of the funds will go towards flying our actors back here, which we feel confident we can do for a reasonable cost.

Our backer perks range from the usual; DVD's, links, posters, screenplay, digital behind the scenes content and credits to more personal shares like a CD mix of music I listened to while writing the screenplay, a list of cast and crew filming locations and favorite hikes and even dinner at the crews favorite meet up.

We set our goal based on what we need to finish the film and begin the exhibition phase. If we manage to reach our goal on time we will qualify for INDEMAND funding, allowing our campaign to continue raising funds without a set deadline. This would ensure the wide net we envision for festival submissions or attention that maybe needed to technical needs. 

If we fail to reach our goal here we will work with what we have to complete the film and begin festival submission process and then turn to another platform to finish raising funds for the exhibition phase.

CAST & CREW

Lovelle Liquigan as Ku Riley and Erwin Tuazon as Lucien Landres

Lovelle Liquigan has been acting for 20+ years. She has worked with a variety of theatres and companies in Los Angeles and Orange County; South Coast Repertory, East West Players and Independent Shakespeare Company being among them. Directors that she has collaborated with have been Kate Whoriskey, Laurie Woolery, Tim Dang, Matthew Harrison, Melissa Chalsma, Larry Biederman, Jessica Kubzansky, Nancy Keystone, Cecilia Fannon and Erin Li. Lovelle was granted a scholarship from Primary Stages in NY, asked to audition for the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art and for the Public Theater’s Shakespeare Lab, and was contacted by the EVP of casting at NBC, Grace Wu, after her office attended a performance of, Steel Magnolias, in which Lovelle played Annelle. She is interested in and influenced by seeing women as messy, contradictory, angry, bright and complex versus the roles and characteristic often attached to them by the media and mainstream culture. The character of Ku is an off the beaten path rebel of ecology who gives herself over both professionally and personally to her love for nature. And Lovelle fleshed out both her independent and yet, captured heart with great care.

Erwin Tuazon started acting in high school and has been involved in theatre or film since. For the  past ten years he has been a reoccurring cast member of the Independent Shakespeare Co., one of Los Angeles’ most popular theatre festivals. He was also Co-Artistic Director of the Declan Adams Theatre Company, creating modern and adapted interpretations of classic works. Other notable collaborations include working with Range View Productions and East West Players. He is a graduate of University of California, Irvine, receiving a Bachelor’s Degree in Drama and Acting. Erwin brought to the character of Lucien the nuances in his understated observations of both his professional and personal life, bringing the character to his potential surrender to the wildernesses of the heart. 

Both these actors are huge talents in equal parts with the ferocity they can bring to the stage and the restraint and naturalism they bring to the screen. It was an honor to have them shepard the roles of Ku and Lucien.

(Left) Producer Nik Oczkus, (Center) actors Lovelle Liquigan and Erwin Tuazon (Right) Cinematographer David Woodfin

David Woodfin is a filmmaker and cinematographer. Alumni of California State University at Monterey Bay, he holds a Bachelor’s Degree in Cinematic Arts and Technology. Native of the Bay Area, David enjoys working on films and uniquely capturing local and foreign landscapes. He is skilled and experienced in varying formats including narrative, documentary, and experimental films. David's eye was a crucial contribution to A QUIET THUNDER because of his keen attention to the natural world - a major theme and character in the film. His honed visuals for nature and the patience that comes with photographing the unpredictible was invaluable to the production. 

Nik Oczkus has experience in many fields of filmmaking such as writing, directing, editing, sound, and now producing. In recent years Nik has been a part of many different award-winning projects  that have all strived for excellence. After graduating from San Francisco State University with a Bachelor’s Degree in Cinema, Nik had earned the opportunity to attend the 71st Cannes Film Festival to participate in the short film corner with his latest work in short narrative format, TO THE WRITERS. Since then Nik has remained dedicated to various phases of production on numerous film projects, from development, pre-production, production, post production and exhibition.

Risks & Challenges

Seeing the film through will require us to have a real chance with succeeding in this campaign. We all work a lot, some with multiple jobs, have kids, I myself am losing my home of 20 years this Summer, so we're definitely up against it. But the bulk of the work is done, we have plans in place, and we need to see this post production and exhibition phase through.

If you are not in a position to contribute, please share this campaign with your network and/or put the campaign badge in INDIEGOGO tools on your website or social network. We deeply appreciate it! Thank you!

Much love,

John David Levy
story_txt:
Teaser Trailer

  

Short Summary
After completing my award winning short film TABULA RASA (2012) I had to step away from filmmaking and devote myself to a family crisis full time. During that time I kept writing and developing both features and shorts to have options at different levels to work towards when I returned to making films. During that time I planted the seeds of numerous projects. Among them, my previous short film THE DISAPPEARANCE (2017) (successfully backed at Kickstarter), this film A QUIET THUNDER, and several more. A QUIET THUNDER is a personal passion project of mine and that passion has extended to everyone who has come aboard the project since it's inception.  Each person on the production put a lot of physical, emotional, mental and financial efforts into it's creation.
