story:
Play the Trailer!

 

What is it about?

It's a story of justice and vengeance and where the lines become blurred. Can the characters avoid losing themselves on this journey, both metaphorically and literally? It's an action thriller, not everyone's going to make it. Who will you root for?

Two kidnappers, a dealer, a group of college kids, and a killer converge in an abandoned school. Once they cross paths, chaos ensues, and it's a race to survive the night. 

Meet the Creators

Zane Hershberger - My name is Zane Hershberger, and I am a fan of films in general, but especially films in the horror/thriller genre. I've worked on 5 feature length films in the past several years and have been accumulating a wealth of knowledge as I've moved along. The film FORCE TO FEAR is important to me because it's a fun, twisted story that my collaborative partner, Chad Bruns, and I created together and we feel that there are enough thrills and interesting characters to keep audiences glued to their seats.

Chad Bruns - Hi I'm Chad Bruns, I've been an actor for 10 years, as well as working behind the scenes, in various roles on projects. Zane and I want to bring you a fast-paced action thriller that you'll want to watch over and over again. I have worked on over 16 films, web series, and TV shows the past few years. For more information on my work, check out www.chadbruns.com

 

What We Need 

Our goal is to give you quality big budget action while doing it safely. Any donations, even if they are small, help us get closer to making this a possibility, and are truly appreciated!

We want to avoid distracting the audience from the story with cheesy effects.

Where is the money going?

  • Weapons 
  • Normal Props/costumes
  • Crash pads
  • Basic tools and supplies to build objects to throw people thru or off of.
  • Special effects
  • Practical effects

Tricks or Treats?

Why should you believe in us, or this project?

  • We have the support team of Justin Seaman (The Barn) and Rocky Gray (10/31).
  • We have the location, cameras, lights, editing software.
  • We have the crew from "The Barn" and "10/31" working with us.
  • We have a team of talented actors. 

So no tricks, only treats.

Check out our Perks section for the TREATS!!!

Risks & Challenges 

Zane and I have worked on some good projects but we have also learned a lot from projects that missed opportunities. Your contributions ensure that we can take the time on the big action scenes and get them right.

  • Our 18 years of experience in the film industry has given us many examples of what pitfalls to avoid. 
  • Chad has over 7 years experience as an Industrial Engineer, which deals with maintaining tight schedules on projects, efficiency, and staying under budget.
  • Our fight choreography is being rehearsed ahead of time so we don't waste any time on set.
  • The majority of the film is set in a centralized place to avoid having to travel to multiple sets all over the area.
  • If the Pittsburgh weather won't cooperate with us for the outdoor scenes, we have the ability to build some of the sets indoors to stay on schedule.

Shout "FORCE TO FEAR" from the rooftops.

The most helpful thing you can do outside of donating is spread the word! If 1,000 people donate $10, we hit our goal!

Meet The Cast

Sable Griedel  - NOVA, credits include 10/31, The Barn, Cryptids.

April Yanko - ANOMALY, credits include Murder Made Me Famous, OK Grey, Reckless, Dogwood Pass.

Chad Bruns - SOCKS, credits include Who Killed Jane Doe, 10/31, Cryptids, Devil's Night, Warrior. 

Joe Setticase - CLINT, credits include Paterno, Site 22, Homicide Hunters.

Mitchell Musolino - RYAN, credits include The Barn, 10/31, Cryptids, The Men Who Built America.

Ted Opalanski - THE TARGET, credits include Escape at Dannamora, CastleRock, House of Cards.

Se' Marie - SARAH, credits include Careful Not to Cry, Cryptids, Significant Other, The Sapphire Diaries.

Arjun Kumar - WATTS, is a theater actor best known for his roles in Arcadia, UBO ROI, Street Car Named Desire.

George Saulnier - NICK, is an award winning theater actor, currently starring in Cutting Ball Theater's Uncle Vanya in San Fransico.

Ginny Griedel - VEGA, is a newcomer to the film industry, her performance is sure to pack a punch.

Nexus Lyons - PIT,  credits include Lion's Den, Batshit,  and the Decisionists.

story:
What It Is

We're the cast & crew behind the UNLV Johnny Brenden funded feature film Shellfish--a story about a young man who is scrambling to complete a short film within a week in order to win a chance at producing a feature film. Told partially through stop-motion, think of Shellfish as Scott Pilgrim vs. the World meets Me and Earl and the Dying Girl.

In his early life, Keller worships his older brother, Kane. Kane teaches him and their younger brother, Bailey, to love and make films, and instills in them a sense of individuality and creativity. But once Kane leaves for the military and never returns, Keller and Bailey are left to make films on their own.

Fast forward to modern-day Las Vegas, where our story follows the journeys of these two brothers and their best friend and artist, Harper. The three filmmakers enter a short film contest, sponsored by an alumnus of the same university that Harper and Keller attend, in hopes that they will win a grant to make a feature film. During the production of their short, however, Keller, Bailey, and Harper face challenges in regards to artistry and friendship, and the way they see the world will never be the same.

Stop Motion Aspect: Since Keller prefers to make films through stop-motion, the story is partially told through stop-motion elements that convey how characters feel. For example, the increasing stress Keller faces is depicted as stop-motion coral growing within his throat.

Because the story is so personal to all of the students in our cast and crew, everybody is willing to volunteer their time, talents, and efforts to make this film happen. We just need help to fund the money needed to finish our film.

What Do We Need?

UNLV Film Alumni Hunter Hopewell was awarded a grant from Johnny Brenden of Brenden Theaters, given every other year to one UNLV Film student to turn his or her script into a full-length movie. Much of the budget was spent on equipment, licenses, permits, insurance--all the non-fun stuff you need for movies (note: equipment can be fun, depending on who you are).

That leaves us needing help with things like:

  • Food (for cast, crew, and our many, many extras)
  • Transportation/Lodging
  • Insurance
  • Renting Equipment
  • Emergencies
  • Post Production
  • Software
  • Hardware/Media Storage
  • Locations
  • Film Colorist
  • Promotion
  • Film Festivals
  • Distribution
  • And finally, all the perks that we're offering our contributors

“How else can I help?”

Please spread the word about our campaign! We’re going to need to reach as many eyes as possible. Also, for more updates on how the film is coming along, visit our Facebook https://www.facebook.com/shellfishfilm and Instagram pages to get announcements and a behind-the-scenes look at what’s happening with Shellfish!

Our Production Team:

1st Unit

a. Lukas Guamen, Grip b. Noah Kiriu, Sound c. Tyler Yarbro, Associate Director d. Nadine Natividad, Producer e. Monserrat Martinez, Camera P.A. f. Jonathan Keiffer, Production Assistant g. Veronica Castillo, Associate Producer h. Blake Gilmore, Gaffer i. Sasha, Production Assistant j. Peter Kelesis, Key Grip k. Shane Gallo, Sound Assistant/G & E l. Cynthia Garcia, Costume m. Shawna Schiro, Associate Producer n. Hunter Hopewell, Director o. Cherr Barragan, Makeup p. Mackenzie Amar, Actor q. Brittany Deal, Production Designer r. Jemsen Yumico, Script Supervisor s. Joel Martinez, Director of Photography t. Sam Rodriguez, 1st Assistant Director u. Serenity Garcia, Actress v. Mike Williamson, 1st Assistant Camera w. Phebe McCorkle, Producer

 

Not pictured:

Johnny Brenden, Executive Producer | Warren Cobb, Executive Producer | Karla Buhlman, Executive Producer | Mike Buhlman, Executive Producer | Melissa Del Rosario, 1st Unit Co-Producer | Chuck Prater, Actor | Tom Peck, Actor/Production Assistant | Jalen Bell, Actor | Codi Musler, Actress | Tre Norman, Actor | Elle Johnson, Actress | Jeff Johnson, Actor | Michael Clark, Actor | Brooke DaSilva, Actress | Alma Perez, 1st AD | Tiffanie Ignacio, 1st AD | Rose Nordberg, 1st AD | Romance Barragan,  2nd Unit 1st AD | Sean Singer, 2nd Assistant Camera | Matthew Quiatchon, Sound | Marcus Peña, 2nd Unit Grip | Paris Monet, Production Assistant | Koben Pfau, Production Assistant | Chai Simone, Prop Artist, Poster Designer, Extra | Angela Bomarito, Prop Artist | Elizabeth Hunt, Assistant Editor | Jose Uribe, 1st Unit Associate Producer | Jade Meadows, Production Assistant | Al Almero, Second Unit Sound | Wyatt Henrie, Production Assistant  | John Bartley, Location Scout | James Schaeffer, Production Assistant | Stephanie Waszkiewicz, Second Unit Sound | Tim Harbour, Drone Pilot | Kourtenaye Monroe, Production Assistant | Prudence Tramont, Production Assistant & Extra | Paul Costolo, Actor | Michael Yosef, Actor | Richard Frazier, Gorilla | Will Cory, Production Assistant | Web Conn, Production Assistant | Anthony Mason, PA | Kevin Fitzpatrick, Production Assistant | Aaron Lockhart, 1st AD | Kenneth, PA | Kyle, PA | Genevieve Elgrichi, Extra | Stephen Grogan, Extra | Pamela Grogan, Extra | Howard Wulforst, Extra | Jeannie Wulforst, Extra | Charles Teixeira, Extra | Perry Bruno, Sr., Extra | Ryan Caviola, Extra | Chris Kliewer, Extra | Joel's GF, PA | Rick Moore, 2nd AD | Brian Bishop, 2nd AC | Karllon Musni, Assistant Editor | Kyle Moore, PA | 

Special thanks to:

Olive Garden

The UNLV Honors College

Wooden Camera

Hunter Hopewell:

Producer/Writer/Director/Actor/Composer/Editor

Working with supportive casts and crews, Hunter has written and directed over 20 award-winning  short films, including an anti-bully film that received a first place award at the United Nations. Graduated from the UNLV Honors College with his BFA in Film, Hunter works full-time as a Video Specialist for the Walt Disney Company and plans to give back through Rock*Comedy*Film Clubs and Events with a portion of all profits benefiting arts education programs. 

Tyler Yarbro:

Associate Director

Tyler is a writer and director whose short films have circulated and percolated the festival circuit circularly, along with being accepted into the American Pavilion at the Cannes Film Festival.

Joel Martinez:

Director of Photography

Joel is an award-winning cinematographer with his degree in Film from UNLV. Most recently, he was Director of Photography on a short film that showcased at the Short Film Corner at the Cannes Film Festival 2018.

Savanah Joeckel:

Actress

Savanah graduated from UNLV with a film degree and now pursues all aspects of film including acting, production design, and directing. She continues to work on a variety of projects and plans to travel in order to explore the genres and elements of what it means to be a storyteller. 

Mackenzie Amar:

Actor

Mackenzie attended UNLV and CSN where he studied audio engineering, photography, and film. He is a visual and audible artist that expresses his mediums through music, acting, and photography.

Perry Bruno

Actor

Perry received his BA from DePaul University where he studied screenwriting, acting, and improv. He resides in Los Angeles and attends The Groundlings School while continuing to craft stories with friends.

Serenity Garcia

Actress

Serenity Garcia is an actress and sketch comedy writer who plays “Angela” in Shellfish. She can be seen on Nerdist’s web series on Alpha, Taco Bell’s web series “Taco Tales”, and has studied improvisation at The Upright Citizen’s Brigade, Nerdist, Dosage, and The Second City Hollywood where you can see her being a goof in live comedy shows every week.

Shari and Michael Abdoulah

Actress and Actor

Michael and Shari Abdoulah met in L.A in an acting class 30 years ago and have been married ever since. Parents and business owners today but continue to nurse the “Acting bug” whenever possible.

Brody Dolyniuk

Actor

Brody is a multi-faceted Rock Musician/Front Man/Producer.  After 14 years of headlining with the legendary rock band he formed, Yellow Brick Road, he's nationwide now in his role  as a vocalist for Windborne Music’s touring symphony shows, singing the Music of Queen,The Who, Rolling Stones, U2 and Journey. Simultaneously he performs with ZUSA, his Led Zeppelin tribute band, and  produces several shows, like his Symphonic Rockshow , consistently selling out The Smith Center in Las Vegas.  

Francisco Menendez

Actor/Advisor

Professor Menendez holds several prestigious teaching awards from the University of Nevada Las Vegas, and two Charles Vanda awards for excellence in the arts. He has won first place for two juried screening awards from the University Film and Video Association, and as Department Chair received over a million dollars in production grants for the film program. Aside from filmmaking, his areas of research are virtual reality, stereoscopy, and emerging technologies.
story_txt:
What It IsWe're the cast & crew behind the UNLV Johnny Brenden funded feature film Shellfish--a story about a young man who is scrambling to complete a short film within a week in order to win a chance at producing a feature film. Told partially through stop-motion, think of Shellfish as Scott Pilgrim vs. the World meets Me and Earl and the Dying Girl.In his early life, Keller worships his older brother, Kane. Kane teaches him and their younger brother, Bailey, to love and make films, and instills in them a sense of individuality and creativity. But once Kane leaves for the military and never returns, Keller and Bailey are left to make films on their own.Fast forward to modern-day Las Vegas, where our story follows the journeys of these two brothers and their best friend and artist, Harper. The three filmmakers enter a short film contest, sponsored by an alumnus of the same university that Harper and Keller attend, in hopes that they will win a grant to make a feature film. During the production of their short, however, Keller, Bailey, and Harper face challenges in regards to artistry and friendship, and the way they see the world will never be the same.Stop Motion Aspect: Since Keller prefers to make films through stop-motion, the story is partially told through stop-motion elements that convey how characters feel. For example, the increasing stress Keller faces is depicted as stop-motion coral growing within his throat.Because the story is so personal to all of the students in our cast and crew, everybody is willing to volunteer their time, talents, and efforts to make this film happen. We just need help to fund the money needed to finish our film.What Do We Need?UNLV Film Alumni Hunter Hopewell was awarded a grant from Johnny Brenden of Brenden Theaters, given every other year to one UNLV Film student to turn his or her script into a full-length movie. Much of the budget was spent on equipment, licenses, permits, insurance--all the non-fun stuff you need for movies (note: equipment can be fun, depending on who you are).That leaves us needing help with things like:
Food (for cast, crew, and our many, many extras)
Transportation/Lodging
Insurance
Renting Equipment
Emergencies
Post Production
Software
Hardware/Media Storage
Locations
Film Colorist
Promotion
Film Festivals
Distribution
And finally, all the perks that we're offering our contributors
“How else can I help?”Please spread the word about our campaign! We’re going to need to reach as many eyes as possible. Also, for more updates on how the film is coming along, visit our Facebook https://www.facebook.com/shellfishfilm and Instagram pages to get announcements and a behind-the-scenes look at what’s happening with Shellfish!Our Production Team:1st Unita. Lukas Guamen, Grip b. Noah Kiriu, Sound c. Tyler Yarbro, Associate Director d. Nadine Natividad, Producer e. Monserrat Martinez, Camera P.A. f. Jonathan Keiffer, Production Assistant g. Veronica Castillo, Associate Producer h. Blake Gilmore, Gaffer i. Sasha, Production Assistant j. Peter Kelesis, Key Grip k. Shane Gallo, Sound Assistant/G & E l. Cynthia Garcia, Costume m. Shawna Schiro, Associate Producer n. Hunter Hopewell, Director o. Cherr Barragan, Makeup p. Mackenzie Amar, Actor q. Brittany Deal, Production Designer r. Jemsen Yumico, Script Supervisor s. Joel Martinez, Director of Photography t. Sam Rodriguez, 1st Assistant Director u. Serenity Garcia, Actress v. Mike Williamson, 1st Assistant Camera w. Phebe McCorkle, Producer Not pictured:Johnny Brenden, Executive Producer | Warren Cobb, Executive Producer | Karla Buhlman, Executive Producer | Mike Buhlman, Executive Producer | Melissa Del Rosario, 1st Unit Co-Producer | Chuck Prater, Actor | Tom Peck, Actor/Production Assistant | Jalen Bell, Actor | Codi Musler, Actress | Tre Norman, Actor | Elle Johnson, Actress | Jeff Johnson, Actor | Michael Clark, Actor | Brooke DaSilva, Actress | Alma Perez, 1st AD | Tiffanie Ignacio, 1st AD | Rose Nordberg, 1st AD | Romance Barragan,  2nd Unit 1st AD | Sean Singer, 2nd Assistant Camera | Matthew Quiatchon, Sound | Marcus Peña, 2nd Unit Grip | Paris Monet, Production Assistant | Koben Pfau, Production Assistant | Chai Simone, Prop Artist, Poster Designer, Extra | Angela Bomarito, Prop Artist | Elizabeth Hunt, Assistant Editor | Jose Uribe, 1st Unit Associate Producer | Jade Meadows, Production Assistant | Al Almero, Second Unit Sound | Wyatt Henrie, Production Assistant  | John Bartley, Location Scout | James Schaeffer, Production Assistant | Stephanie Waszkiewicz, Second Unit Sound | Tim Harbour, Drone Pilot | Kourtenaye Monroe, Production Assistant | Prudence Tramont, Production Assistant & Extra | Paul Costolo, Actor | Michael Yosef, Actor | Richard Frazier, Gorilla | Will Cory, Production Assistant | Web Conn, Production Assistant | Anthony Mason, PA | Kevin Fitzpatrick, Production Assistant | Aaron Lockhart, 1st AD | Kenneth, PA | Kyle, PA | Genevieve Elgrichi, Extra | Stephen Grogan, Extra | Pamela Grogan, Extra | Howard Wulforst, Extra | Jeannie Wulforst, Extra | Charles Teixeira, Extra | Perry Bruno, Sr., Extra | Ryan Caviola, Extra | Chris Kliewer, Extra | Joel's GF, PA | Rick Moore, 2nd AD | Brian Bishop, 2nd AC | Karllon Musni, Assistant Editor | Kyle Moore, PA | Special thanks to:Olive GardenThe UNLV Honors CollegeWooden CameraHunter Hopewell:Producer/Writer/Director/Actor/Composer/EditorWorking with supportive casts and crews, Hunter has written and directed over 20 award-winning  short films, including an anti-bully film that received a first place award at the United Nations. Graduated from the UNLV Honors College with his BFA in Film, Hunter works full-time as a Video Specialist for the Walt Disney Company and plans to give back through Rock*Comedy*Film Clubs and Events with a portion of all profits benefiting arts education programs. Tyler Yarbro:Associate DirectorTyler is a writer and director whose short films have circulated and percolated the festival circuit circularly, along with being accepted into the American Pavilion at the Cannes Film Festival.Joel Martinez:Director of PhotographyJoel is an award-winning cinematographer with his degree in Film from UNLV. Most recently, he was Director of Photography on a short film that showcased at the Short Film Corner at the Cannes Film Festival 2018.Savanah Joeckel:ActressSavanah graduated from UNLV with a film degree and now pursues all aspects of film including acting, production design, and directing. She continues to work on a variety of projects and plans to travel in order to explore the genres and elements of what it means to be a storyteller. Mackenzie Amar:ActorMackenzie attended UNLV and CSN where he studied audio engineering, photography, and film. He is a visual and audible artist that expresses his mediums through music, acting, and photography.Perry BrunoActorPerry received his BA from DePaul University where he studied screenwriting, acting, and improv. He resides in Los Angeles and attends The Groundlings School while continuing to craft stories with friends.Serenity GarciaActressSerenity Garcia is an actress and sketch comedy writer who plays “Angela” in Shellfish. She can be seen on Nerdist’s web series on Alpha, Taco Bell’s web series “Taco Tales”, and has studied improvisation at The Upright Citizen’s Brigade, Nerdist, Dosage, and The Second City Hollywood where you can see her being a goof in live comedy shows every week.Shari and Michael AbdoulahActress and ActorMichael and Shari Abdoulah met in L.A in an acting class 30 years ago and have been married ever since. Parents and business owners today but continue to nurse the “Acting bug” whenever possible.Brody DolyniukActorBrody is a multi-faceted Rock Musician/Front Man/Producer.  After 14 years of headlining with the legendary rock band he formed, Yellow Brick Road, he's nationwide now in his role  as a vocalist for Windborne Music’s touring symphony shows, singing the Music of Queen,The Who, Rolling Stones, U2 and Journey. Simultaneously he performs with ZUSA, his Led Zeppelin tribute band, and  produces several shows, like his Symphonic Rockshow , consistently selling out The Smith Center in Las Vegas.  Francisco MenendezActor/AdvisorProfessor Menendez holds several prestigious teaching awards from the University of Nevada Las Vegas, and two Charles Vanda awards for excellence in the arts. He has won first place for two juried screening awards from the University Film and Video Association, and as Department Chair received over a million dollars in production grants for the film program. Aside from filmmaking, his areas of research are virtual reality, stereoscopy, and emerging technologies.

story:
Official Site | IMDb | Facebook | Twitter | In the News

Updates:

1. Due to concerns from the LGBT and feminist communities, and also because of budgetary constraints and creative reasons, I've decided to drop the LGBT and feminist elements from We Put the World to Sleep's concept. Since the three main characters in the movie embark on a mission to bring everything to an end, we would have to be extremely careful to not portray the gays and the feminists as destructive, which would paralyse the creative process and wouldn't allow us to go fully psycho and do a really dangerous movie. So the best solution is to remove the LGBT and feminist elements from the concept to not risk harming those communities, and focus on the apocalyptic goal with no restraints. Adrian Țofei

2. You can now invest in We Put the World to Sleep, with a contract, and receive profit from the movie’s revenues, plus associate or executive producer credits, plus join the team at all the international film festivals! Check out the investment page for more info: weputtheworldtosleep.com/invest

3. Our Indiegogo campaign is over. Thanks a lot to all of you who supported it! We raised 1% of the movie's minimum $100,000 budget. We already have $10,000 from two investors, so we need $89,000 more to make the movie. And for that, Adrian Țofei decided to accept new investments. Let us know if you're interested in investing!

4. We're far from the minimum $100,000 goal, but we'll make the movie no matter what, by finding alternative ways of financing. Your contributions won't be lost! Every extra dollar matters and brings us closer to starting the production!

5. We'll do the movie in a way so that it cannot be used by the far-right to accuse the LGBTQ or the black community of being violent. The characters are idealistic and non-violent, their goal is positive, venturing on a metaphysical quest for ending world's pain.

6. Adrian Țofei is determined to not portray any lesbian stereotypes. Two women fall in love the same way two men fall in love the same way a woman and a man fall in love. He's also determined to not give the characters aggressive, war-oriented attributes. On the contrary - sensitivity, affection, care, vulnerability - the things that make us all wonderful. 

7. We didn't do a pitch video because we cannot be all together in it (Erisse lives in the US, Duru & Adrian live in Europe), and we do not have the time and the resources for a video that would reflect the movie's ambitions (we prefer using them for the actual film).

8. We've recently added cheaper perks and hidden the old ones that have been claimed, that's why most of them have zero claims now. Hidden claims: 1x$500, 1x$150, 2x$75, 3x$35, 1x$15. We add the IMDb credits in one to three days from being claimed.

What We Aim to Achieve

This movie has to shake the world. A world that is too comfortable in accepting the status-quo of discrimination, inequality, intolerance, speciesism, nationalism, pain, suffering, violence, abuse, irrational thinking, hypocrisy, corruption, greed, ignorance and so many other problems. The list never ends. And most likely it never will, since us as a species evolved via conflict/natural selection. We have it on our DNA. The capitalistic system is based on it. We cannot even enjoy a movie or a story that has no conflict. 

So we put together two women as the leads (the world loves male superiority), with different skin colors (the world loves white supremacy), different nationalities (the world loves nationalism), we make their characters lovers (the world loves heterosexuality only), we give them principles and ideals (the world loves messy thinking), and we make them save the world from its miserable existence by bringing everything to an end! (the world loves fighting for survival - the survival of the fittest and the crushing of the vulnerable)

We Put the World to Sleep has to premiere in one of the world's top film festivals (Cannes, Sundance, TIFF, Venice, Berlin, Telluride, SXSW, Tribeca), secure a top distributor, travel the festival circuit and enter movie theaters around the world. That's the only way it can make a difference. But it requires a relatively big budget, and no production company would invest money and let us do this dangerous movie the way we want, the way it should be done! 

For authenticity, Adrian Țofei plans to do it based on controlled improvisation, just like he did his first feature, the award-winning and critically-acclaimed Be My Cat: A Film for Anne. Because no writer can 100% imagine how an event or discussion evolves in real life, without putting himself in that situation. And also the actors would know in advance what will happen and what they have to say, they won't discover everything during filming, limiting the naturalness. And we don't want just good acting, we want audiences to be blown away by the authenticity, to say "wow, are you sure this is just a movie? it looks so real!". All this makes it very hard for us to do it with a production company. They want scripts. This and the movie's dangerous anti-system concept are the main reasons why we need and ask for your support! Join us in putting the world to sleep! 

Who We Are

Adrian Țofei | Actor & Filmmaker | Official Site | IMDb | Facebook | Twitter

We Put the World to Sleep: Director / Producer / Writer (concept) / Supporting Actor

Adrian Țofei was born on July 20, 1987 in Rădăuți, Romania. His mother, Dorina Țofei, supported him watching movies from an early age, and later, in adolescence, Adrian started spending hours each day researching film history as a hobby. He also took acting lessons, performed in high school plays and in 2007 went on to study Ion Cojar‘s acting method at Lower Danube University of Galați, then continued in 2010 with a master’s degree in acting at Spiru Haret University of Bucharest. During 2008-2010, Adrian also directed, produced, wrote and performed in various plays, most notably The Monster, a one-man-show which was selected to numerous theatre festivals.

At the end of 2012, inspired by the success of his one-man-show and a connection he made between Cojar’s method and the found footage concept, Adrian Țofei plunged into filmmaking and film acting as the director, producer, writer (concept) and star of Romania’s first found footage horror feature film, Be My Cat: A Film for Anne. The movie premiered at the 2015 Fantasporto International Film Festival and went on to win numerous awards and critical acclaim, including Best Film at the 2015 A Night of Horror International Film Festival in Sydney and Best Actor for Adrian at the 2016 Nashville Film Festival. I was called "terrifying" and "a modern Peeping Tom" by Austin Chronicle, "potentially revolutionary and dangerous" by Dread Central, a “disturbing  found footage masterpiece" by 28DLA and “the most revolutionary found footage film since Blair Witch Project” by ANOH. It was also included in Dread Central's Top 5 Best Horror Movies of 2016, Blumhouse's Top 5 New Intelligent Found Footage Films You Need to See and Audiences Everywhere's Top 50 Best Horror Movies of the 2000s. Artsploitation said that Adrian did "the most believable movie psychopath since Normal Bates". Adrian Țofei is currently developing We Put the World to Sleep and he's also set to direct the upcoming female antihero thriller drama Good Girl.

Erisse Peterson | Actress & Musician | IMDb | Facebook | Twitter

We Put the World to Sleep: Lead Actress (playing Erika) (improvised audition below)

Erisse Peterson was born on March 7th, 1993 in Stone Mountain, Georgia, USA. She got her start in acting at an early age, after her family relocated to Los Angeles, California in 1996. As a child actor, Erisse was represented by Bob Feldman (father of actor Corey Feldman) and studied ballet, tap and jazz dance.

Later, Erisse Peterson attended Mississippi School of the Arts, the state’s only residential arts high school. She intensively studied theatre arts under her instructors, Dr. Robert Brooks and Tammy Stanford, and performed in numerous stage plays. She also developed a passion for all aspects of film, including directing and film scoring. During 2011-2013, Erisse attended Mississippi State University, where she studied Philosophy & Religion. Erisse Peterson joined We Put the World to Sleep in 2015, when the project was called I Put the World to Sleep, after winning the international casting call (check out her powerful improvised audition above). She recently ventured into music as well, releasing her first EP, Somethingmissing, under the stage name Planes. 

Duru Yücel Țofei | Actress & Screenwriter | IMDb | Facebook | Twitter

We Put the World to Sleep: Lead Actress (playing Deniz)

Duru Yücel Țofei was born on July 16th, 1986 in Izmir, Turkey. A very expressive child, she always had a playful existence which later proved itself when she sang in front of the whole class in primary school and staged impressions of all her teachers during secondary school. She studied theatre for a year when she was 10, which led to her playing two different characters in the play that was staged at the end of the year. From that moment on, she came to know very clearly the fact that she wanted to be an actress.

Having inherited her mother’s talent in languages, Duru also developed a similar interest and chose to study English-Turkish Interpretation and Translation in college. But her biggest passion never stopped haunting her, and following the university years, in order to have an acting training and bigger opportunities, she moved from Izmir to Istanbul and enrolled at The Studio Players, where she received three years of acting and art education under Şahika Tekand and Esat Tekand. In 2014, she performed multiple times in the play named Becoming A Rhinoceros 2.014 with The Studio Players. During 2012-2017, Duru also acted in various TV series, commercials, and a short movie which traveled to Cannes. She also likes singing, especially jazz, and has a demo she handed out just to her family and friends. Duru Yucel Țofei is currently preparing for her role in We Put the World to Sleep and also co-writing the script for the upcoming feature film Good Girl.

Associate Producers:

Jay Sorensen | Producer & Foreign Service Officer | IMDb | Facebook

Danha Yunes | Actress & Producer | IMDb | Facebook

What We Need & What You Get

We need an ideal budget of $300,000 and a minimum budget of $100,000 to do the movie the right way. All the funds will be spent on pre-production (preparation), production (filming), post-production (editing) and film festivals. Here are some of the major expenses: cast & crew payments, filming & editing equipment, international traveling to shoot in various locations around the world, production design, rentals, explosions and/or big fires, accommodation and other basic necessities during filming, special/visual effects, preparing & submitting the movie to film festivals, attending the festivals and promoting the screenings.

Check out all the perks we offer! Depending on your contribution, you get social media shout-outs, links to stream and download the movie, official thanks, special thanks and very special thanks credits, signed DVDs, custom t-shirts (pictured above), Skype video conferences with the main team (Adrian, Erisse & Duru), and even official producer credits, with you joining us at the world premiere and all the film festivals, where you can be a star on the red carper and interact with the world's top filmmakers & actors! Of course, you can also contribute anonymously and/or without claiming any perk by clicking "Back It". If you'd like to have the items in a perk that includes Skyping, but you have social anxiety and cannot connect with video, just let us know and we'll connect via live texting or email.

What Are the Risks

In case we don't reach the $300,000 goal, we'll find ways to do the movie with less money, such as changing the concept, removing expensive scenes, using cheaper equipment, reducing the shooting locations, the special/visual effects and the cast & crew payments. But we cannot do it with less than $100,000. That's the absolute minimum required for this type of production. And just in case we don't even reach the minimum, have no worries, your contribution is not lost, we're gonna launch another campaign and/or find alternative ways of financing and make the movie no matter what!

Adrian Țofei did his first movie, Be My Cat: A Film for Anne, on a $10,000 budget, and the entire experience was traumatizing for everyone involved, despite all the awards and festivals and critical acclaim. Nobody was paid, they barely had money for food during filming, couldn't afford better equipment and visual effects, Adrian got anxiety because of doing everything by himself, couldn't submit the movie to more festivals, get a big distributor and reach a bigger audience, so it's definitely a situation we don't want to see repeating.

Update 1: We received a message from someone worried that the neo-conservatives might use the movie to point fingers at the LGBTQ community and accuse them of being violent. Creator Adrian Țofei was aware of this danger and that's why the film's characters are idealistic and non-violent, and their goal is positive. They won't go on a rampage. It will be a metaphysical quest for ending world's pain. If anyone will blame the left or the libertarians or the black community or the women or the LGBT community of being violent because of this movie, they will only expose their own stupidity.

Update 2: We've also received a concern about the way a male director might portray lesbians. Adrian Țofei is determined to not portray any stereotypes. Two women fall in love the same way two men fall in love the same way a woman and a man fall in love. He's also determined to not give the characters aggressive, war-oriented attributes. On the contrary - sensitivity, affection, care, vulnerability - the things that make us all wonderful. 

What Else You Can Do to Help

If you cannot contribute financially, or simply want to do more, please share the campaign on your social media or via email (use the sharing tools provided by Indiegogo), talk to your friends and family, write on your blog/website, talk about it on your YouTube/TV show, or do anything else comes to your mind that would help us put the world to sleep!

Duru Yücel Țofei was born on July 16th, 1986 in Izmir, Turkey. A very expressive child, she always had a playful existence which later proved itself when she sang in front of the whole class in primary school and staged impressions of all her teachers during secondary school. She studied theatre for a year when she was 10, which led to her playing two different characters in the play that was staged at the end of the year. From that moment on, she came to know very clearly the fact that she wanted to be an actress.
Having inherited her mother’s talent in languages, Duru also developed a similar interest and chose to study English-Turkish Interpretation and Translation in college. But her biggest passion never stopped haunting her, and following the university years, in order to have an acting training and bigger opportunities, she moved from Izmir to Istanbul and enrolled at The Studio Players, where she received three years of acting and art education under Şahika Tekand and Esat Tekand. In 2014, she performed multiple times in the play named Becoming A Rhinoceros 2.014 with The Studio Players. During 2012-2017, Duru also acted in various TV series, commercials, and a short movie which traveled to Cannes. She also likes singing, especially jazz, and has a demo she handed out just to her family and friends. Duru Yucel Țofei is currently preparing for her role in We Put the World to Sleep and also co-writing the script for the upcoming feature film Good Girl.
Associate Producers:
Jay Sorensen | Producer & Foreign Service Officer | IMDb | Facebook
Danha Yunes | Actress & Producer | IMDb | Facebook
What We Need & What You Get
We need an ideal budget of $300,000 and a minimum budget of $100,000 to do the movie the right way. All the funds will be spent on pre-production (preparation), production (filming), post-production (editing) and film festivals. Here are some of the major expenses: cast & crew payments, filming & editing equipment, international traveling to shoot in various locations around the world, production design, rentals, explosions and/or big fires, accommodation and other basic necessities during filming, special/visual effects, preparing & submitting the movie to film festivals, attending the festivals and promoting the screenings.

Check out all the perks we offer! Depending on your contribution, you get social media shout-outs, links to stream and download the movie, official thanks, special thanks and very special thanks credits, signed DVDs, custom t-shirts (pictured above), Skype video conferences with the main team (Adrian, Erisse & Duru), and even official producer credits, with you joining us at the world premiere and all the film festivals, where you can be a star on the red carper and interact with the world's top filmmakers & actors! Of course, you can also contribute anonymously and/or without claiming any perk by clicking "Back It". If you'd like to have the items in a perk that includes Skyping, but you have social anxiety and cannot connect with video, just let us know and we'll connect via live texting or email.
What Are the Risks

In case we don't reach the $300,000 goal, we'll find ways to do the movie with less money, such as changing the concept, removing expensive scenes, using cheaper equipment, reducing the shooting locations, the special/visual effects and the cast & crew payments. But we cannot do it with less than $100,000. That's the absolute minimum required for this type of production. And just in case we don't even reach the minimum, have no worries, your contribution is not lost, we're gonna launch another campaign and/or find alternative ways of financing and make the movie no matter what!
Adrian Țofei did his first movie, Be My Cat: A Film for Anne, on a $10,000 budget, and the entire experience was traumatizing for everyone involved, despite all the awards and festivals and critical acclaim. Nobody was paid, they barely had money for food during filming, couldn't afford better equipment and visual effects, Adrian got anxiety because of doing everything by himself, couldn't submit the movie to more festivals, get a big distributor and reach a bigger audience, so it's definitely a situation we don't want to see repeating.
Update 1: We received a message from someone worried that the neo-conservatives might use the movie to point fingers at the LGBTQ community and accuse them of being violent. Creator Adrian Țofei was aware of this danger and that's why the film's characters are idealistic and non-violent, and their goal is positive. They won't go on a rampage. It will be a metaphysical quest for ending world's pain. If anyone will blame the left or the libertarians or the black community or the women or the LGBT community of being violent because of this movie, they will only expose their own stupidity.
Update 2: We've also received a concern about the way a male director might portray lesbians. Adrian Țofei is determined to not portray any stereotypes. Two women fall in love the same way two men fall in love the same way a woman and a man fall in love. He's also determined to not give the characters aggressive, war-oriented attributes. On the contrary - sensitivity, affection, care, vulnerability - the things that make us all wonderful. 

What Else You Can Do to Help
If you cannot contribute financially, or simply want to do more, please share the campaign on your social media or via email (use the sharing tools provided by Indiegogo), talk to your friends and family, write on your blog/website, talk about it on your YouTube/TV show, or do anything else comes to your mind that would help us put the world to sleep!

story:
Firstly, thank you for taking time out of your day to read about our project. Let's dive in* and we can tell you more.

The Hook

After her identical twin is eaten alive by a shark, Juliet tries to come to terms with her sister’s unconventional death via unconventional means... (which may or may not include a sex-doll).

It’s a comedy.

Seriously.

But it's not just a "ha-ha" type of comedy.  It's a "ha-ha-hugging-heartstrings" type of comedy.

It’s a drama - a meditation on grief;

What losing someone makes us go through. What it makes us do.  And ultimately, how we can begin to find our way through it. 

Okay, you’ve got my attention. Name another film that it’s like?

Sure thing, tonally we often talk about The Lobster (2015), Swiss Army Man (2016) and The Darjeeling Limited (2007).

Directorial influences for the film also include Jaws (1975), Rust and Bone (2012), The Shape of Water (2017), The Skin I Live In (2011), Ema (2019) and Black Swan (2010).

I like at least five of those. But who are you? You seem pleasant enough but I don’t go around just giving money to strangers on the internet.

We are...

Christina Raisea Murphy a non-binary Writer/Director originally from Ireland and Steve Lennon, a producer who used to work on The X Factor before wanting his soul back ;-)

Well, you both sound charming. Who else is on board?

We’re still crewing up but our Casting Director is Virginia Kerr who works with BIFA nominated Kharmel Cochrane (Saint Maud, End of the F***ing World). We also have Korsshan Schlauer on board as Director of Photography.

You ‘sound’ experienced, but you’re only asking for £2k. Making a film is expensive, is that going to be enough?

We're in the incredibly fortunate position to have already secured £15k of funding. We’re planning a three-day shoot and the scale of production means we’ll need funding to finance the post-production/delivery stage of production, as well as festival entry/marketing

I’m tempted. What does that money actually go on?

Almost all of the £15k we have will be going towards a three-day shoot in the South-East of England, paying National Minimum Wage and above across the board.

The £2k we’re looking to raise will go towards:

  • Editing
  • Post-Production Delivery: including Colour Grade, 5.1 Sound Mix and DCP
  • Festival Entry: We're keen to get this film in to as many A+ festivals as possible and need the money to do so. We are targeting BAFTA/Oscar qualifying festivals. Your money can help make that happen.
  • Marketing: As part of our overall marketing strategy, we're working on marketing assets to include, but not limited to: Website, Poster, Press Pack/EPK.

Can’t you find the money elsewhere?

We’ve already secured £15k and have funding applications in with other funding bodies. If we’re fortunate enough to raise funds through other means, anything we raise via Indiegogo will go towards further enhancing the film’s production value through additional spend on art department and equipment.

Okay, take my money. What do I get?

Most, if not all, of our perks are digital with some very limited physical items.

We're keen to limit the number of physical perks.  It saves money on shipping and is also kinder on the environment. Nobody needs more "stuff", especially Mother Nature. 

Have a look through and see what takes your fancy. Anything you give, no matter how small will be spent on the things that really matter.**

What happens if you don’t reach your goal?

  • We'll definitely cry a little, then…
  • We’ll realise our tears taste like the sea, then…
  • We’ll discover that we actually raised ‘some’ money so will get to work and make the film.

I’ve not really got much to spare...

Given what we've all just lived through, and are continuing to live through, we understand that a financial contribution might be a stretch. But that doesn't mean you can't assist us. Word of mouth is one of the key ways that you can help us reach our goal.

Could you:

  • Tweet about us? Share a link to this page and get others involved. You can use the Indiegogo share tools.
  • Follow us on the socials and repost our content. We’re @twinstinsfins on Instagram and Twitter.
  • Email some friends who you think might like the film.
  • Have an Indiegogo Crowdfunding party on Zoom for us***

Thank you for your time and your support. You Rock!****

*Pun intended.

** Okay, we might buy some energy drinks for Day 3.

*** That might be a little bit extreme but we applaud your efforts.

****Rock Salmon, sometimes called rock eel, flake, huss or Sweet William, is a dish popular in Fish and Chip shops in Britain. It's also an endangered species of shark.

story:
Our goal in creating this film is to shift the cultural mindset that "Sri Lankan girls don't surf."

 

 

WE ARE LIKE WAVES is an intimate look into how surfing changes Sanu’s life, documenting the struggles and breakthroughs of becoming one of the first female Sri Lankan surfers. 

 

The Impact

We Are Like Waves is an intimate, powerful story that the world needs now. This story will shed light on the continued push for gender equality in the sport of surfing, and demonstrates how surfing can be used as a tool for women’s empowerment. Not only is Sanu a role model for the young girls in her village, but through the screen, she will become a role model for girls and women. We aim to create a platform for deeper discussions around gender norms, beauty standards, and family expectations within the context of surfing. 

This story is not just Sanu’s, it is the story of many female surfers around the world.

 

 

The Story

Along the South Coast of Sri Lanka, surfing is everywhere. Yet only foreigners and local men fill the lineups. Surfing is not seen as a sport for Sri Lankan girls. This is a result of cultural and societal expectations that often place women inside the household, particularly in rural areas. Young girls are expected to follow certain standards: Attend school, study, work. Get married, and start a family. Be a housewife, cook, and clean. Most importantly, stay at home and put family first.

The ocean is simply not seen as a place for women. Therefore, like most girls, Sanu grew up watching her brother surf, but never considered it as an option for herself. When Sanu turned 18, she began working in the kitchen at a surf camp alongside her brother, who worked as a surf instructor.

At the surf camp, Sanu was often invited to try surfing by foreigners, but her fear of the ocean and going against her community’s expectations made her decline the offer again and again. One day, Sanu was asked by her boss and mentor, Sophie, to join her at SeaSisters, a weekly swim and surf program established  for Sri Lankan girls to help inspire and empower through surfing. Hesitant but curious, Sanu took the risk.

This is a story of finding one’s voice in a sea of expectations.


 

What We Need & What You Get

We are aiming to raise $10,000 for post-production, distribution, and to be able to pay back our production loan. 

Here is the breakdown of  where the money will go:

$5,500 - Production: travel, gear, crew needs

$3,000 - Post-production: color, sound design, mix, original score

$1,500 - Distribution: film festivals, tour screenings/events, educational curriculum 

*To make a tax deductible donation, email wearelikewaves@gmail.com

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Follow us on Facebook and Instagram.
  • Like, comment and SHARE as many of our posts as you can. That will boost the visibility of the posts in the social media algorithms.  
  • Subscribe to our email list on our website to stay updated on our progress.
  • Post in your favorite groups, message friends, and share about the campaign. 

 

"We are like waves, you cannot stop us" - Sanu

story:
Kingpen Productions LLC. and I are teaming up with Indy Wrestling Legend Malta The Damager, Julie Anne Prescott and Cult Cinema to bring you a weed and gore filled Sci Fi Action throwback classic! Come join us on the this campaign to bring "MOONROCKS" to life!

Message from the Director: New Stretch Goal $10,000!

We have a great cast but with the goal we can bring more name actors and better locations to bring you the best and most action packed Sci fi Stoner film possible!

MOONROCKS is an Epic Action Packed Sci-Fi Stoner Thriller. Inspired by some of the greatest 80's and 90's Sci-Fi, Action and Stoner films we've grown to love over the decades.


NOW WHAT HAPPENS WHEN YOU COMBINED THE GENRE’S?


PINEAPPLE EXPRESS AND PREDATOR, HALF BAKED AND ATTACK THE BLOCK, HOW HIGH AND I COME IN PEACE!
...MOONROCKS!

Here is an early 3D mockup of the alien city and some early mockup shots of the Hero's Armor and Villains helmet.

HELP US CAST A 420 LEGEND.

Shooting will take place in the NY  in June 2021 

 

We sincerely hope you can help us get this project 100% backed! Making an independent film isn't easy. It takes a story, dedicated cast and crew, ambition, creativity and last, but not least money. Like all great writers and directors, someone took a chance on them. Will you be that someone?

Thank you for your time and consideration. :)
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign. Use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it. Let's legalize this Project.

story:
Asphyxiate is a short film about a young woman, who tries to gasp for air as she drowns in the memories of a tainted relationship.

The film stars Michaela Longden & Anthony Quinlan, both fantastic actors with a great list of credentials to back them up. Michaela also wrote the film as its based upon her own experiences in a gaslighted relationship. It's really fantastic that she decided to come forward and tell her story.

We filmed most of the film at the end of August, but we still have one more shooting date to go and the whole of post-production. We don't want to rush things, but we would love to be part of the 2020 film festival circuit, so getting this complete by January is really vital for us.

STILLS FROM WHAT WE FILMED

We're looking to raise an extra £1000, on which all the money will go into the shoot and post, any further money raised then into festivals. We had a really successful marketing campaign before the film was filmed, but didn't manage to get enough funds to cover us for the next part!

It's really important we talk about gaslighting. It is a traumatic and harrowing experience for anyone who has been, or is going through it themselves. We believe that the impact of this film will be raising awareness, and, hopefully, giving hope to people in those situations to be able to move forward from it.

gaslight

/ˈɡaslʌɪt/

Learn to pronounce

verb

gerund or present participle: gaslighting

manipulate (someone) by psychological means into doubting their own sanity.

story:
For six days in July and August 1990, the people of Trinidad and Tobago watched in fear and disbelief as the single most deadly – and arguably the most shocking –  event in the modern history of the country unfolded. During the attempted coup of 1990, members of the Jamaat Al Muslimeen, a local radical Islamic group, raided the Parliament, bombed the police headquarters, commandeered the national television station, TTT, and killed several people (the exact number is still not known).

In the four-part documentary series, ‘1990’, award-winning filmmaker and television producer, Mariel Brown, will explore the issues that gave rise to the 1990 coup attempt; take an in depth look at each day of the stand-off – in the Red House and Trinidad and Tobago Television, and in Port of Spain as a whole – which culminated in Abu Bakr’s surrender; examine the effect of the resulting amnesty and other court cases around the Muslimeen; and try to highlight the scars left on both the people who were directly involved, and the national community.
 

The 1990 coup attempt has always held a fascination for me, and as a documentary filmmaker and a Trinidadian who lived through it, I have wanted to explore the story for many years. In 2008, I made an abortive attempt to start the research, but I was younger then, and, I realise now, not ready to undertake the telling of such a difficult story. 

I picked up the mantle again in 2018 — determined to make a series to mark the 30th anniversary of what is now known colloquially as, ‘the coup’. But attempts to raise money for the production through corporate sponsors in Trinidad have proven depressingly, if understandably, futile. I wrote a post on Facebook, in July of 2020, sharing my desire to make the series, and was so pleased to get some really encouraging feedback. One comment, in particular, struck me. Calypsonian David Rudder wrote, ‘Just after the coup, a lady came up to my home and begged me to write the ultimate song, aimed specifically at the young people of the nation. The song, she said, when played, and [heard by] the nation, will wipe out all knowledge of the coup. I’ll never forget the look on her face when I explained to her why I had to decline.’ 

Difficult and painful histories — I can understand why the idea of forgetting is so attractive. And yet, how can we forget the coup? I keep coming back to the fact that people, citizens of Trinidad and Tobago, our people, were killed during the attempted coup; and many others were profoundly damaged during those terrible days. And yet, over thirty years on, we’re still not sure how many were killed.  As columnist BC Pires wrote in 2007, ‘17 years after they died, we have no idea how many people were killed by the Muslimeen. But it is a source of ongoing distraction to me, and must be a deep, unresolved pain to their loved ones.

‘On this anniversary day of the day, then, two things come to mind… The other point, or nine, depending on how, or even if, you count them, are: Leo Des Vignes; George Francis; SRP George; Loraine Caballero; Solomon McCleod; Malcolm Basanta; Arthur Guiseppi; Mervyn Teague; the people we know for sure were killed in 1990.’

For me, making ‘1990’ is about honouring, remembering, marking, questioning, understanding and never forgetting what was done to us and taken away from us that year.

 

We've assembled a small and hardworking team of researchers in Trinidad, and we're delighted with the progress they have made, fleshing out a detailed timeline of the decade of the attempted coup; sourcing and reviewing endless hours of archive footage, thanks to the support of Banyan Archives, Pixel Play Media and Visual Arts; visiting the national archives, the national library and various media houses. 

Fundraising efforts are ongoing, as we continue to reach out to corporate sponsors in Trinidad and Tobago, in the hopes that one or two companies will see the value in telling this story and give financial support. In the mean time, SAVANT Films has self-funded the research and development phase, and planning a crowdfunding campaign to help offset research and production costs later this month. It's essential that we succeed with the crowdfunding campaign to advance work on this project, and look forward to your support!


To find out more, do follow us on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter @1990docseries

 

Risks and challenges

The risks and challenges for this project revolve around the complexity of the story itself and my ability to attract sponsorship and grants to the project. As we dig deeper into the story, we are uncovering layers and layers of context, which must be fully explored in the series, as well as many, many first hand accounts of experiences from people either directly or tangentially involved. Indeed, this is a lovely problem to have! In producing historical documentaries, it's not often the case that one has access to so many first hand accounts! The process of pre-interviews which we recently concluded has been invaluable in helping guide the arc of the story, and broadening my understanding of the many facets of the coup.

The circumstances that gave rise to 'the coup' have their roots in the 1970s and the struggle for black power, and extend through to the party of 'national unity', the NAR, the fateful 1986 elections, and the recession of the 1980s. As a result, research has taken longer than I originally anticipated, but I expect to have completed this process by mid to late April.

As an independent filmmaker, I have been creating and producing independently funded television shows and documentary films for the better part of 20 years. All of my projects have required that I do extensive fundraising, and I've not let this fact deter me from completing those projects, often through sheer determination and stick-with-it-ness (my last film, Unfinished Sentences, took four years to fundraise for, and I was able to meet my full budget)! My hope is that as the visibility of this project grows, so too will my capacity to fundraise through sponsorship and grants. It's a difficult story, but most everyone I have spoken to about it has recognised its importance, and because of this, I anticipate that I will also receive many cash donations towards the project – in fact, I have already begun the process of soliciting personal donations. I expect that my budget will be made in this way – as a combination of crowdfunding, direct donations, sponsorship and grants.
story_txt: For six days in July and August 1990, the people of Trinidad and Tobago watched in fear and disbelief as the single most deadly – and arguably the most shocking –  event in the modern history of the country unfolded. During the attempted coup of 1990, members of the Jamaat Al Muslimeen, a local radical Islamic group, raided the Parliament, bombed the police headquarters, commandeered the national television station, TTT, and killed several people (the exact number is still not known).In the four-part documentary series, ‘1990’, award-winning filmmaker and television producer, Mariel Brown, will explore the issues that gave rise to the 1990 coup attempt; take an in depth look at each day of the stand-off – in the Red House and Trinidad and Tobago Television, and in Port of Spain as a whole – which culminated in Abu Bakr’s surrender; examine the effect of the resulting amnesty and other court cases around the Muslimeen; and try to highlight the scars left on both the people who were directly involved, and the national community. The 1990 coup attempt has always held a fascination for me, and as a documentary filmmaker and a Trinidadian who lived through it, I have wanted to explore the story for many years. In 2008, I made an abortive attempt to start the research, but I was younger then, and, I realise now, not ready to undertake the telling of such a difficult story. I picked up the mantle again in 2018 — determined to make a series to mark the 30th anniversary of what is now known colloquially as, ‘the coup’. But attempts to raise money for the production through corporate sponsors in Trinidad have proven depressingly, if understandably, futile. I wrote a post on Facebook, in July of 2020, sharing my desire to make the series, and was so pleased to get some really encouraging feedback. One comment, in particular, struck me. Calypsonian David Rudder wrote, ‘Just after the coup, a lady came up to my home and begged me to write the ultimate song, aimed specifically at the young people of the nation. The song, she said, when played, and [heard by] the nation, will wipe out all knowledge of the coup. I’ll never forget the look on her face when I explained to her why I had to decline.’ Difficult and painful histories — I can understand why the idea of forgetting is so attractive. And yet, how can we forget the coup? I keep coming back to the fact that people, citizens of Trinidad and Tobago, our people, were killed during the attempted coup; and many others were profoundly damaged during those terrible days. And yet, over thirty years on, we’re still not sure how many were killed.  As columnist BC Pires wrote in 2007, ‘17 years after they died, we have no idea how many people were killed by the Muslimeen. But it is a source of ongoing distraction to me, and must be a deep, unresolved pain to their loved ones.‘On this anniversary day of the day, then, two things come to mind… The other point, or nine, depending on how, or even if, you count them, are: Leo Des Vignes; George Francis; SRP George; Loraine Caballero; Solomon McCleod; Malcolm Basanta; Arthur Guiseppi; Mervyn Teague; the people we know for sure were killed in 1990.’For me, making ‘1990’ is about honouring, remembering, marking, questioning, understanding and never forgetting what was done to us and taken away from us that year. We've assembled a small and hardworking team of researchers in Trinidad, and we're delighted with the progress they have made, fleshing out a detailed timeline of the decade of the attempted coup; sourcing and reviewing endless hours of archive footage, thanks to the support of Banyan Archives, Pixel Play Media and Visual Arts; visiting the national archives, the national library and various media houses. Fundraising efforts are ongoing, as we continue to reach out to corporate sponsors in Trinidad and Tobago, in the hopes that one or two companies will see the value in telling this story and give financial support. In the mean time, SAVANT Films has self-funded the research and development phase, and planning a crowdfunding campaign to help offset research and production costs later this month. It's essential that we succeed with the crowdfunding campaign to advance work on this project, and look forward to your support!To find out more, do follow us on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter @1990docseries Risks and challengesThe risks and challenges for this project revolve around the complexity of the story itself and my ability to attract sponsorship and grants to the project. As we dig deeper into the story, we are uncovering layers and layers of context, which must be fully explored in the series, as well as many, many first hand accounts of experiences from people either directly or tangentially involved. Indeed, this is a lovely problem to have! In producing historical documentaries, it's not often the case that one has access to so many first hand accounts! The process of pre-interviews which we recently concluded has been invaluable in helping guide the arc of the story, and broadening my understanding of the many facets of the coup.The circumstances that gave rise to 'the coup' have their roots in the 1970s and the struggle for black power, and extend through to the party of 'national unity', the NAR, the fateful 1986 elections, and the recession of the 1980s. As a result, research has taken longer than I originally anticipated, but I expect to have completed this process by mid to late April.As an independent filmmaker, I have been creating and producing independently funded television shows and documentary films for the better part of 20 years. All of my projects have required that I do extensive fundraising, and I've not let this fact deter me from completing those projects, often through sheer determination and stick-with-it-ness (my last film, Unfinished Sentences, took four years to fundraise for, and I was able to meet my full budget)! My hope is that as the visibility of this project grows, so too will my capacity to fundraise through sponsorship and grants. It's a difficult story, but most everyone I have spoken to about it has recognised its importance, and because of this, I anticipate that I will also receive many cash donations towards the project – in fact, I have already begun the process of soliciting personal donations. I expect that my budget will be made in this way – as a combination of crowdfunding, direct donations, sponsorship and grants.

story:
Short Summary

The Creator

Yorgo Glynatsis is the writer, co-director and lead actor of TRIGGER. He is a Greek, Italian filmmaker born in Belgium and started his artistic journey at 14 years old acting in Belgium. He trained in Theatre at the Conservatoire of Charleroi and played several leads and supporting roles in theatre shows in Brussels. Aspiring for an international career, he moved to London in 2014 and joined the cast of the Immersive project The Den created by the BAFTA-winning director Gbemisola Ikumelo. Following that, he starred in several short films and Indian Features. Recently, he shot the feature film pilot of The Adamant Vultures of London and the feature film Remi Milligan: Lost Director. His passion for filmmaking started in 2020 when he created a series of comedy sketches, Donovan the Stalker, and several scenes before writing TRIGGER.

Inspired by watching the series I May Destroy You and It’s a Sin, he decided to talk about his traumatic experience from a few years ago in London. Feeling ashamed for allowing the experience to happen to him, he failed to report it or even tell anyone at the time.

He has now decided to speak up about sexual consent and the misinformation that surrounds it. As this topic is still considered taboo in our society, many people remain silent, suffering their trauma alone. Many LGBTQI+ people, himself included, struggle with their self-esteem and identity. This makes LGBTQI+ people, in particular, more vulnerable and prone to uncomfortable situations. Yorgo wants to normalise speaking up about this subject and raise awareness about the meaning of consent.

Making this short film is a healing journey for Yorgo and will hopefully inspire others to use their voices. Together we can create a safer world for our generation and the ones to follow.

Co-Director Statement

The concept of sexual consent only recently began to be discussed in mainstream media, raising significant awareness but still lacking essential information. Sexual assault is often understood as forced, violent sex, and this film represents the other version less spoken about. I believe it is vital to represent the realities of sexual assault, the different ways it appears and is perceived. Non-violent sexual assault is a huge and unspoken issue in the LGBTQI+ community, with 40% of gay men and 47% of bisexual men have experienced sexual violence other than rape, compared to 21% of straight men. Around half of transgender people and bisexual women will experience sexual violence at some point in their lifetimes. Now is the right time to raise these issues, when people are more open to discussing and understanding them. 

I am passionate about representing real people in my work. My prior work focused on documentaries, but I have always admired how non-factual films can tell true stories. It allows the creatives to experiment with storytelling while maintaining the truth of the experience. I explored this when writing and directing ‘Mora’, a short film about sleep paralysis, based on my experiences, told through a character’s story. I want to continue to make more films that address critical issues, such as my documentary about menstrual stigma. This story combines two issues I care about deeply, LGBTQI+ rights and sexual abuse. These are both very personal to me, and I believe the best work always comes from that.

Synopsis

Anthony, a twenty-nine-year-old mixed European actor and cabin crew member, auditions for the reality TV show ‘Dream Island.’ The casting director immediately asks stereotypical questions; about his sexual orientation and consequently his taste in men. The questions become darker and more disturbing, triggering a flashback to a London house party, and a traumatic event in his life.

The Team

Director

Chloe Potamiti is a 23-year-old, Greek filmmaker, living in London. She studied film and TV at university with a focus on short, experimental films and documentaries. Her experience in the industry has varied, from being a videographer to painting sets, to working in a post-production house. She has also worked in photography, theatre and events. Her dream is to write and direct, making films and art about personal and real experiences which raise awareness of important issues. She is particularly passionate about the representation of women and LGBTQI+ people in film and aims to contribute towards increased and accurate representation.

Producer

Lisa Geurts is originally from the Netherlands but has lived in England for nearly 10 years. Having originally studied and specialised in the craft of Screenwriting, and while she is still persuing that, when she started getting the opportunity to produce and direct her own short films, she took the chance and since then hasn’t looked back. Lisa is particularly interested in the correct representations of less represented groups in films. She is also currently researching mental health representations in horror films, and television and hopes that this research will be valuable for screenwriters in navigating this.

DOP

Raised on a healthy diet of video rentals, Matt Thomas’s love of film began to spiral out of control until he learnt that you could actually make a living from making them – a realisation that finally brought together his childhood interests in music, art, and photography into a single goal and ever since, he’s been crafting stories through a lens. A versatile and imaginative cinematographer, Matt has worked on a wide range of projects including short films, documentaries, web content, and music videos. Graduating from The London Film School MA in filmmaking has allowed him to hone his technique and develop his visual style, drawing from a wide range of influences that help him bring stories to life. The one thing he loves as much as cinema is cake.

Assistant Producer

Leena Makoff - actor, writer, sexual assault survivor, bisexual woman, Slavic powerhouse. Since moving to London in 2017, Leena trained her acting skills with Gary Condes, with Faye Beck at Actors Doors Studio, at Identity School of Acting, Maktub Theatre Company and Anarchy Actors Studio. Makoff performed in many fringe shows at Drayton Arms, Theatro Technis, Camden People’s Theatre and more. Together with 5Go Theatre Co. She is preparing a new show Miss Margarida’s Way planned for the next autumn. Before leaving Poland, Leena wrote a play - Hummus i bigos; a show based on the text is planned to be staged later on this year in Warsaw. Currently, Leena is focused on improving her screen acting abilities and general filmmaking skills. She has recently been cast in BBC Wales and Amazon Prime productions.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise around 10K for the film. This will ensure that Yorgo's vision can become a reality and that we can reach as many people as possible. The budget includes distribution to the relevant national and international festivals, as well as compensating all our cast and crew fairly for their work.

Even if we don't reach our goal, we will still try to make this film, simplifying the script if necessary. We think the message we are trying to convey, and the awareness we are trying to raise is so important, that we would rather make the film on a small budget than not at all.

The Impact

We would be so incredibly grateful for any help you can provide. The whole team whole heartedly believes in this project, and believe that if there was more awareness around sexual consent, in particular in the LGBTQI+ community, that more people would speak out. We don't just want to make a film for us, we want to make it for everyone.

Once the short has done the rounds at national, and international festivals, we plan to use it as a proof of concept in order to get greenlit to make this into a limited series, giving the story additional time to explore different themes. Some themes we wish to explore in the future when fleshing out this story are:

  • Lack of self-esteem and self-love in young people in the LGBTQI+ community
  • Sex and drug addictions
  • Lack of commitment in relationships
  • Sexual consent
  • Depression
  • Suicide and toxic relationships within the LGBTQI+ community.

 

 

Risks & Challenges

As experienced filmmakers, we know it won't be an easy ride. We have already had to overcome challenges, and that's before even launching this campaign!

One challenge will be not receiving the funds we'd like. The budget is based on the current screenplay, and the ideal crew and locations to do the screenplay and Yorgo's vision justice. However, we have already created three separate "what if" budgets. While we hope we can make the film we want to make, we want to ensure that your money is used in the best way, and we are already looking and will continue to look at ways to make any money we receive stretch as far as possible.

Another risk is what would happen if COVID-19 cases go up again, and if there would be another lockdown. Most of us have worked on film sets and have experience keeping sets Covid Safe, including our trailer shoot. Our crew will also have up to date ScreenSkills certificates in 'Coronavirus Awareness on Set'. When we shot our trailer, we stuck to a group of six people indoors, and all got tested within 24 hours prior to shooting. All members of the cast and crew also signed agreements to ensure COVID safety on set, but also to ensure the reporting of positive tests or contact within 10 days of the shoot. Once we know what the rules around COVID will be when we start shooting (this Autumn), we will do a risk assessment and ensure our cast & crew's safety.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that we are still in a pandemic, or in general that you may not have money to help us. If you still want to help, we would so appreciate you sharing the link to our campaign around on your social media, or sign up to our email campaign and forward our campaign.
