story:
Synopsis

A short film that explores control and freedom...

"The Hum is a name often given to widespread reports of a persistent and invasive low-frequency humming, rumbling, or droning noise not audible to all people."
- Wikipedia

Monotone. Dull. Normal. Evelyn's existence is all of these things and nothing more.

That is until she becomes aware of a humming noise. It starts to dominate her otherwise normal life. Driven to distraction, she hunts frantically for the source. When she finds an ominous metal box from which the hum emanates, her decision to ignore the simple warning sign – ‘Don’t’ – will have a lasting effect on her life, exposing the comfortably sinister, frighteningly normal forces that control our lives.

 

 

Director's Message

Hi! 

Welcome to this, the campaign page for DON'T: a short film project the story for which has been kicking around in my head for more years than I’m willing to count. Stories can be weird, tricksy things that defy being nailed down. They can build you up with their potential, only to turn your brain to mush as they refuse to reveal the way the story should be told. Short story? Mmmm, not quite right. Comic? Nah – too long for a short one, too short for a long one. Weird indie video game? Much as I love ‘em, oh heck no.

The final form came after I started adapting it into an adventure for a certain Time Lord (not an official adventure, I hasten to add). It suddenly struck me that it was all in my head as something filmed, not written and read. D’oh! So obvious.

And here we are. DON'T, the short film.

I am stupidly excited to be announcing over the coming weeks the cast and crew we’ve put together for this project. The chance to bring you along on the adventure is a gloriously intimidating thing, but it is going to be so much fun. And work. But fun work. You’ll see what I mean. And not just on this particular film, not just on DON'T. We’ve got others planned, Stewart and I, and we’re looking forward to letting the backers of this one in on those too. Onward!

Be well, be safe, be excited!

Supplemental:

I'm very excited to confirm that filming of 'Don't' will go ahead. For further details, check out the latest update. :)

 

Cast

CHLOE SMITH

Chloë Smith is a performer and performance maker based in the northeast of England. She performs professionally in both her own and other people's work around the UK and also works across a variety of community and educational projects. After studying Choreography at Dartington College of Arts, she now works across theatre, film, dance, and visual art. 

 

KRISTOPHER BOSCH

A native son of Canada, singer and actor Kristopher is a graduate (BA) of the Randolph Academy for the Performing Arts, and of Glasgow’s Royal Conservatoire of Scotland (MA). He has appeared on stage around the world, including China, Dubai, Toronto, London, and at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. As well as commercials for television and both feature and short films, he appeared as a feature vocalist on John Barrowman’s Tonight’s The Night on the BBC. His talents as a singer saw him tour with The 12 Tenors in Europe and South Africa, and sing with Adele at Wembley stadium. However, it is for his extraordinary performance-captured portrayal of the android Jerry (multiple Jerry androids, in fact) in the QuanticDream/Sony PS4 videogame Detroit: Become Human that Kristopher is best known.

 

ANGUS MACINNES (IMDb)

Angus was born in Windsor, Ontario, in Canada, but has lived for many years in the Scottish capital, Edinburgh, in a house looking out over the Firth of Forth. In his long film and television career, beginning with a role in Norman Jewison’s ‘Rollerball’, Angus has worked with a veritable who’s who of directors, including Stanley Kubrik, Guy Hamilton, Paul Greengrass, Louis Malle, Peter Weir, Michael Apted, and Guillermo del Toro. He appeared in three films with Harrison Ford including the one that he’s best known for amongst sci-fi fans – George Lucas’ ‘Star Wars’. Indeed, it’s Angus’ appearances in genre films such as ‘Superman II’, ‘Hellraiser II’, ‘Judge Dredd’, ‘Hellboy’, and ‘Outland’, as well as television classics like ‘Space: 1999’ and ‘Space Island One’, that have made him so beloved. There was considerable delight amongst ‘Star Wars’ fans in particular when, in 2016, Angus returned to voice Gold Leader Jon ‘Dutch’ Vander in ‘Rogue One: A Star Wars Story’, with unused footage of his 1970’s self from the original film used to bring the character back to the big screen.

 

EUAN DUTHIE

Euan is a QC at the Scottish Bar and a tribunal judge. He chairs the Maltings (Berwick) Trust, an Arts Council England National Portfolio Organisation which operates England’s most northerly cinema, theatre and arts centre. After 13 years as a Royal Naval Reserve officer (which saw him spend six months working on the trials of Somali pirates in Kenya and also work with the Royal Marines in Sierra Leone), the Maltings allowed him to rediscover a childhood love of acting in his fortieth year (he rejects as absurd any accusations of a mid-life crisis). Acting credits include a nice line in narcissists and psychopaths (‘Oliver!’ (Bill Sikes), ‘Made in Dagenham’ (Robert Tooley), ‘9 to 5’ (Franklin Hart Jr) and ‘72 Hours in Moscow’ (Alexi Ostrovski) with the occasional more palatable character (‘The Sound of Music’ (Captain Von Trapp), ‘Accrington Pals’ (CSM Rivers)). This will be his second film credit, having previously appeared in F.M. (2020).

 

ROSS GRAHAM (IMDb)

Acting from the age of 14 in local theatre shows, Ross went on to attended Newcastle College and York St. John University where he studied Performing Arts followed by Theatre, Film and Television. After graduating, Ross returned to Theatre and has performed in a whole host of productions from straight plays like Spring and Port Wine and His Dark Materials up to big musicals including RENT, Beauty and the Beast and The Producers as well as performing in Berwick-upon-Tweeds Professional Pantomime each year since 2010. Ross is one founding member of the Berwick based Improv Comedy Group – Damp Knight Comedy who have been performing shows and making videos since 2015.

 

DAVID SIMPSON

Discovering performing at the age of 16 and having had no formal training, David has performed in countless local productions across most theatric genres and mediums. David can lend his hand to dramatic pieces and has performed in productions of His Dark Materials, Phantom of the Opera, and 72 Hours in Moscow (TLR) but is most comfortable providing the comic relief where his back-catalog of appearances includes Hairspray, The Producers, and One Big Lie (TLR). David is a founding member of Damp Knight Comedy who gigged across the country with their brand of high-octane, left-field improvised and sketch comedy since 2015. His film credits so far include "The Case" (2013) & "F.M." (2020).

 

SARAH KWAN (Website)

Sarah Kwan Artist is a freelance Illustrator based in Edinburgh who specializes in portraits, food illustration, design, murals, and signwriting. Her most recent ‘East Meets West Series’, explores the connections between Scottish / British and Chinese culture in a fun and playful way - with decorative patterns and pops of bright color. She is also co-founder of East and Southeast Asian Scotland (ESAS), a non-profit organization aimed at supporting the diverse East and Southeast Asian community in Scottish society.

 

Crew

IAIN LOWSON - Writer, Director (IMDb)

A few months short of a quarter of a century writing official Star Wars material, some fifteen years writing for videogames, and with a family old enough now to make their own lunches, Iain decided to do something different. The friendship, tasers, and professional support of Stewart Jones and Slink Jadranko, coupled with a lifelong passion for film and tv, gave Iain the push to start directing. An option he’d been toying with for years, this midlife-switch has so far generated a documentary for the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland, a number of short film projects at various stages of production (including ‘The Cliché’), and a feature in early planning. As a result of all of this, Iain’s kids’ friends think he is cool. This makes his wife laugh a lot, as she knows the truth.

 

STEWART JONES - Writer, Producer (IMDb)

An award-winning creative professional with over sixteen years of experience in film, television, commercials, and video games working with Disney, 20th Century Fox, Warner Bros., Cartoon Network, Nickelodeon, and DC Entertainment, amongst many others. Stewart has been creating engaging content and narrative stories for international audiences, involved with some stuff you'll see on screen and other stuff you can read on Amazon. He's an advocate for disabled filmmakers and disabled gamers.

 

LAUREN DECICCO - Writer (IMDb)

Passionate about different forms of writing, Lauren is a published poet, songwriter, playwright, and screenwriter. Recently, she completed the Master Screenwriting Certificate at ScreenwritingU. A lifelong lover of movies and music as well as theater, she just had the opportunity to act in a live production on Zoom. Lauren is a certified luthier through Roberto-Venn School of Luthiery and hopes to return to guitar building one day. Her film experience has been in post-production as an assistant film editor.

 

ALAINNA MACPHERSON - Assistant (IMDb)

Alainna was born and raised in sunny San Diego but now resides in the Pacific Northwest with her husband, three children, cat, pup and small farm. She started writing in grade school but procrastination kept her from publishing her work until after she had her second baby. What a smart planner! On top of novels and short stories, she also writes scripts. Creating other worlds amongst ours between changing diapers and catching the school bus on time, Alainna is always on her toes.

 

ANTONY JOHNSTON - Executive Producer (IMDb)

A New York Times bestselling author, screenwriter, and podcaster. The Charlize Theron movie ATOMIC BLONDE is based on his graphic novel; his critically acclaimed BRIGITTE SHARP thrillers are soon to be a major TV series; and DEAD SPACE, his first videogame, redefined its genre. He wrote and directed the 2020 ‘lockdown short’ CROSSOVER POINT, and continues to work on books, film, and videogames.

 

SLINK JADRANKO - Director of Photography (IMDb)

Slink Jadranko has been a professional photographer for many years, as well as working extensively with local charities, drama groups (with whom he also performed), and others. He is part of the tech team behind Damp Knight Comedy, filming their live shows and sketches. He cannot, however, commit to having flocks of owls flying out of sleeves. Slink is also an accomplished editor, sound recordist, prop-maker, cook, homebrewer, dog walker, cat feeder, and mediocre (he says) multi-instrumentalist. Iain and Slink worked together on The Cliché and the hastily assembled documentary The Captured Actor (for the Royal Scottish Conservatoire) and have since gone on to shoot various other things that exist at various stages of completion.

 

RICHIE MORGAN - 1st Assistant Camera (Website)

Richie Morgan is a professional filmmaker with over 12 years of production experience in directing, camera operation, and editing. Sometimes working alone or as part of a larger team, he is well suited to a variety of working styles. His career has taken him through a wide variety of situations, from interviewing film stars on the red carpet, documenting major festivals and events, working with some of Scotland’s top food and drink brands, and creating music videos for a number of prominent independent record labels. With a real passion for production, Richie is always happy to talk to you about filmmaking. In fact, your biggest challenge will be getting him to stop talking about it.

 

GAVIN HARRISON - Composer (Website)

From his early days experimenting with his grandparents’ piano to later years raiding his dad’s record collection, Gavin has always had a passion for music and its ability to instill emotion. Throughout his teenage years, he developed his skills both as a bedroom producer and by playing and songwriting in gigging bands. It was also at this time that he began dabbling with old synthesizers (an interest that continues to this day) and creating music for computer games. Personal highlights are seeing full orchestras perform his compositions at top recording studios, including Abbey Road, and hearing his writing played on numerous TV and radio programs. Nowadays, he continues to write music commissions for publishers, and his games credit list grows and grows, as he works on the music and sound design for award-winning and top-selling games. He has also worked for the National Theatre of Scotland, as well as for interactive children’s books. His studio, filled with vintage synthesizers, overlooks the Suffolk countryside.

 

GRAHAM MILLER - Poster Designer

Having gained a degree in Design & Illustration at Manchester University, Graham Miller started as design junior for Visual Imagination Ltd working on titles such as Starburst and Shivers. He moved onto become a designer at Summertime Ltd, and senior designer at IMP overseeing various Star Trek magazines. In 2008, Graham was one of the founding members of a new partwork packaging company, Continuo Creative Ltd. He initially worked as its head designer, becoming Design Director in 2018 where he realised a dream by designing several Star Wars magazines, including ‘Build Your Own Millennium Falcon’ which won a Disney Publication Award. Graham is now a freelance magazine producer, with a side hustle in movie poster design.

 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest risk we face is the unknown factors relating to the Covid Virus. Luckily, our team has prepared themselves by taking necessary courses so that we can create a safe and sterile environment to work in. The comfort and safety of our cast and crew is the highest priority for us, and we will delay shooting until we can be confident that everything will be safe for all involved.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Right now we are all going through hardships and challenges that are bringing difficulties in ways that couldn't be imagined just a few years ago. We understand that giving a contribution to this project may not be possible, but if you believe in what we're doing and want to see it become a reality, then sharing is the next best thing! We'd be grateful for any exposure you can give us by sharing this campaign and making some noise about what we're creating all over your own social media channels and websites.

 

Thank You

We cannot thank you enough for your contribution to this project. We are excited to bring you this story and can't wait to welcome you to our team.
story_txt:
Synopsis
A short film that explores control and freedom...
"The Hum is a name often given to widespread reports of a persistent and invasive low-frequency humming, rumbling, or droning noise not audible to all people."- Wikipedia
Monotone. Dull. Normal. Evelyn's existence is all of these things and nothing more.
That is until she becomes aware of a humming noise. It starts to dominate her otherwise normal life. Driven to distraction, she hunts frantically for the source. When she finds an ominous metal box from which the hum emanates, her decision to ignore the simple warning sign – ‘Don’t’ – will have a lasting effect on her life, exposing the comfortably sinister, frighteningly normal forces that control our lives.
 

 Director's MessageHi! Welcome to this, the campaign page for DON'T: a short film project the story for which has been kicking around in my head for more years than I’m willing to count. Stories can be weird, tricksy things that defy being nailed down. They can build you up with their potential, only to turn your brain to mush as they refuse to reveal the way the story should be told. Short story? Mmmm, not quite right. Comic? Nah – too long for a short one, too short for a long one. Weird indie video game? Much as I love ‘em, oh heck no.The final form came after I started adapting it into an adventure for a certain Time Lord (not an official adventure, I hasten to add). It suddenly struck me that it was all in my head as something filmed, not written and read. D’oh! So obvious.And here we are. DON'T, the short film.I am stupidly excited to be announcing over the coming weeks the cast and crew we’ve put together for this project. The chance to bring you along on the adventure is a gloriously intimidating thing, but it is going to be so much fun. And work. But fun work. You’ll see what I mean. And not just on this particular film, not just on DON'T. We’ve got others planned, Stewart and I, and we’re looking forward to letting the backers of this one in on those too. Onward!Be well, be safe, be excited!Supplemental:I'm very excited to confirm that filming of 'Don't' will go ahead. For further details, check out the latest update. :) CastCHLOE SMITHChloë Smith is a performer and performance maker based in the northeast of England. She performs professionally in both her own and other people's work around the UK and also works across a variety of community and educational projects. After studying Choreography at Dartington College of Arts, she now works across theatre, film, dance, and visual art.  KRISTOPHER BOSCHA native son of Canada, singer and actor Kristopher is a graduate (BA) of the Randolph Academy for the Performing Arts, and of Glasgow’s Royal Conservatoire of Scotland (MA). He has appeared on stage around the world, including China, Dubai, Toronto, London, and at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. As well as commercials for television and both feature and short films, he appeared as a feature vocalist on John Barrowman’s Tonight’s The Night on the BBC. His talents as a singer saw him tour with The 12 Tenors in Europe and South Africa, and sing with Adele at Wembley stadium. However, it is for his extraordinary performance-captured portrayal of the android Jerry (multiple Jerry androids, in fact) in the QuanticDream/Sony PS4 videogame Detroit: Become Human that Kristopher is best known. ANGUS MACINNES (IMDb)Angus was born in Windsor, Ontario, in Canada, but has lived for many years in the Scottish capital, Edinburgh, in a house looking out over the Firth of Forth. In his long film and television career, beginning with a role in Norman Jewison’s ‘Rollerball’, Angus has worked with a veritable who’s who of directors, including Stanley Kubrik, Guy Hamilton, Paul Greengrass, Louis Malle, Peter Weir, Michael Apted, and Guillermo del Toro. He appeared in three films with Harrison Ford including the one that he’s best known for amongst sci-fi fans – George Lucas’ ‘Star Wars’. Indeed, it’s Angus’ appearances in genre films such as ‘Superman II’, ‘Hellraiser II’, ‘Judge Dredd’, ‘Hellboy’, and ‘Outland’, as well as television classics like ‘Space: 1999’ and ‘Space Island One’, that have made him so beloved. There was considerable delight amongst ‘Star Wars’ fans in particular when, in 2016, Angus returned to voice Gold Leader Jon ‘Dutch’ Vander in ‘Rogue One: A Star Wars Story’, with unused footage of his 1970’s self from the original film used to bring the character back to the big screen. EUAN DUTHIEEuan is a QC at the Scottish Bar and a tribunal judge. He chairs the Maltings (Berwick) Trust, an Arts Council England National Portfolio Organisation which operates England’s most northerly cinema, theatre and arts centre. After 13 years as a Royal Naval Reserve officer (which saw him spend six months working on the trials of Somali pirates in Kenya and also work with the Royal Marines in Sierra Leone), the Maltings allowed him to rediscover a childhood love of acting in his fortieth year (he rejects as absurd any accusations of a mid-life crisis). Acting credits include a nice line in narcissists and psychopaths (‘Oliver!’ (Bill Sikes), ‘Made in Dagenham’ (Robert Tooley), ‘9 to 5’ (Franklin Hart Jr) and ‘72 Hours in Moscow’ (Alexi Ostrovski) with the occasional more palatable character (‘The Sound of Music’ (Captain Von Trapp), ‘Accrington Pals’ (CSM Rivers)). This will be his second film credit, having previously appeared in F.M. (2020). ROSS GRAHAM (IMDb)Acting from the age of 14 in local theatre shows, Ross went on to attended Newcastle College and York St. John University where he studied Performing Arts followed by Theatre, Film and Television. After graduating, Ross returned to Theatre and has performed in a whole host of productions from straight plays like Spring and Port Wine and His Dark Materials up to big musicals including RENT, Beauty and the Beast and The Producers as well as performing in Berwick-upon-Tweeds Professional Pantomime each year since 2010. Ross is one founding member of the Berwick based Improv Comedy Group – Damp Knight Comedy who have been performing shows and making videos since 2015. DAVID SIMPSONDiscovering performing at the age of 16 and having had no formal training, David has performed in countless local productions across most theatric genres and mediums. David can lend his hand to dramatic pieces and has performed in productions of His Dark Materials, Phantom of the Opera, and 72 Hours in Moscow (TLR) but is most comfortable providing the comic relief where his back-catalog of appearances includes Hairspray, The Producers, and One Big Lie (TLR). David is a founding member of Damp Knight Comedy who gigged across the country with their brand of high-octane, left-field improvised and sketch comedy since 2015. His film credits so far include "The Case" (2013) & "F.M." (2020). SARAH KWAN (Website)Sarah Kwan Artist is a freelance Illustrator based in Edinburgh who specializes in portraits, food illustration, design, murals, and signwriting.
